author: @teacherjosephkuan
text:
üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 üß† *Stress and burnout are prevalent, with 72% of people struggling with stress and 70% experiencing features of burnout.*
04:15 üìä *Stress levels have risen significantly, affecting people across all ages and industries, becoming a global concern.*
10:29 üö´ *Burnout is no longer limited to traditional symptoms; it can manifest as an inability to disconnect from work, even if you enjoy it.*
18:57 üí™ *True resilience involves honoring boundaries, self-compassion, and rest, while toxic resilience focuses on productivity at all costs.*
21:17 üåç *Generations like Gen Z are not necessarily less resilient but face different challenges, including collective trauma and hyperconnectivity.*
22:24 üê¶ *The "canary in the coal mine" is a metaphor for physical manifestations of stress, like palpitations, headaches, and more, which act as signals of underlying stress in individuals.*
28:09 ü©π *Admitting to stress is not a sign of weakness, and even resilient individuals can experience burnout if they don't acknowledge their stress.*
30:10 üß† *Stress affects the brain and body through the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, leading to the release of hormones like cortisol, resulting in the "fight or flight" response.*
32:22 ü¶† *Stress itself is not contagious like a virus, but emotions and vibes can be "contagious" in social situations, primarily through nonverbal cues and the voice.*
36:08 ü§ù *Creating a therapeutic presence involves factors like making eye contact, being at the same or lower eye level, mirroring, and most importantly, authenticity in human interactions.*
43:54 üß† *Our brains can struggle to sustain positive changes under stress, as they perceive even positive changes as stressors.*
45:01 üìö *The "Rule of Two" suggests focusing on making only two new changes at a time when dealing with stress or major life events.*
48:51 üéØ *When stressed, it's crucial to get clear on what matters most (M.O.S.T.), setting motivating, objective, small, and timely goals.*
54:23 üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è *Even a small amount of daily physical activity, like a 20-minute walk, can significantly reduce stress and increase self-efficacy.*
58:33 üì± *"Popcorn brain" is a term for our brain's overstimulation due to excessive smartphone use, often driven by stress and constant information streams. Setting digital boundaries is key to managing it.*
01:06:29 üß† *Stress management requires recognizing when you're in control and when you're not, allowing you to regain agency over time.*
01:07:12 üîÑ *Closing the gap between knowledge and action is crucial for effective stress management.*
01:08:38 üèãÔ∏è *Small, consistent actions, such as short walks, are more effective than ambitious, stressful goals in managing stress.*
01:09:46 üßò *People often exercise for mental health benefits more than physical ones, emphasizing the importance of stress management.*
01:12:49 üß™ *Taking regular breaks, even as short as 10 seconds, can help manage stress and boost productivity by aiding neural consolidation.*
01:26:29 üß† *Multitasking is a misnomer; it's actually task switching, which weakens the prefrontal cortex, affecting problem-solving, concentration, and mood.*
01:27:10 ‚è≥ *In a complex world, it's essential to practice monotasking instead of multitasking for better brain health.*
01:28:08 üçÖ *Time blocking (Pomodoro Technique) helps protect and strengthen the prefrontal cortex by focusing on one task for a set time, leading to reduced stress.*
01:30:38 ü´Å *Diaphragmatic breathing, inhaling through the nose, and exhaling through the mouth slowly can help reduce stress by activating the parasympathetic nervous system.*
01:37:36 üìù *Therapeutic writing, expressing thoughts and emotions about a traumatic event for several days, can improve mood, sleep, and reduce stress.*
01:47:23 üì∞ *Consuming excessive news, stress, and doom scrolling can lead to mental health issues, including PTSD.*
01:48:04 üì¢ *Being an informed citizen is crucial, but setting digital boundaries and limiting exposure to graphic content is essential to protect your mental health.*
01:50:04 üì± *Hyperconnectivity can lead to loneliness, which is associated with various health risks, such as heart disease and a shorter lifespan.*
01:52:27 üíî *External appearances often don't reflect internal struggles, so it's important to be kind and empathetic towards others.*
01:54:03 üåü *Chronic stress should not be glamorized, and finding a balanced approach to stress is essential for happiness, fulfillment, and connection.*

author: @donnaallgaier-lamberti3933
text: I am a 73-year-old senior citizen/retired. I take care of my 78-year-old husband with increasing ADHD, cognitive decline and mobility decline as well my rescue dog that requires a lot of time and energy. I make it my PRIORITY to go to my senior center two days a week in order to prevent depression, stress and isolation. I try to stay in touch with friends and family. I do pretty well in the summer when the sun shines, and I can get outside and enjoy exercise, sunshine and fresh air. However, I live in Michigan, where we have 6-7 months of cold, high winds and snow which also combines to isolate us in our tiny condo. I also prioritize a monthly massage as an additional stress reducing technique. I diffuse lavender essential oil day and night as another way to relax my body. I eat a nutrient rich diet. Aging, health issues and financial issues are hard to manage but I do the best I can on a tight retirees budget.

author: @fluentinoverthinking
text: I've got a PTSD after having been living under chronic stress for 1 year. When I quit my job the first 2 weeks seemed like the best time of my life - I even slept well (I quit because of insomnia). But then after 2 weeks the real damage kicked in and I started feeling the aftermath - I couldn't relax at all, haven't slept for 5 days and was afraid it will make me insane. It took me 1 year of visiting a psychiatrist to be able to fall asleep without medications again. I am still working on it because I only sleep for 3-4 hours per day but I've learned my lesson. Never ever work more than 40hours per week (even this schedule is stressful) and avoid night shifts at all costs. Especially is you are a highly sensitive person.

author: @anomalyraven
text:
When you started listing up all the things you should do to be stressed at 1:22:10 it sounded like the perfect description of my roommate.

We've been sharing a student apartment since 2021 and it was pretty good in the beginning when I worked from home during the pandemic. Because I took time to have breaks, do some chores and make plans for both of us while he went to classes at university.

But when I got back to office everything went to shit, so to speak. My roommate stays inside of his room all day, he wakes up between 5 to 7PM when I just get back home from work, he lives on energy drinks and take-out, every time the door to his room opens a sweaty smell spreads across the apartment. He gets no daylight or regular exercise. I talked to him about it several times, but it got progressively more difficult to speak when he's being shut in all the time ‚Äì it's like trying to talk to a wall.

I had some compassion for his depression in the beginning, but it started to affect me as well, making me a bad friend who won't tolerate any of his negligence and that's why I decided to look for my own place this year. He knows my decision so it won't come as a surprise when I do get an offer, but I honestly can't wait to move out. I'm sad to say it has ruined our friendship.

author: @BoldStatement
text:
üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 üß† *72% of people are struggling with stress, and 70% have at least one feature of burnout, indicating a significant rise in mental health problems.*
00:53 üì± *Increased rates of depression, sleep disorders, fatigue, and burnout are observed due to higher stress levels, with 60-80% of patient visits having a stress-related component.*
01:20 üîÑ *People experience an inability to disconnect from work, with statistics showing individuals checking their phones up to 2,600 times a day, contributing to a sense of burnout.*
02:24 üåü *Dr. Aditi Naruka's journey as a stress expert began when she, as a stressed medical student, couldn't find help. She became the doctor she needed, uncovering solutions beyond mere relaxation.*
03:34 üåç *Unprecedented levels of stress are observed globally, affecting all industries and demographics. Mental health, stress, and burnout are gaining recognition, breaking taboos in various sectors.*
04:29 üìä *Stress rates are at an all-time high, with 70% of people experiencing burnout, and 72% struggling with stress. The recent years have been noted as the most stressful in many professionals' careers.*
07:57 üß† *The difference between acute and chronic stress is explained, emphasizing that chronic stress, leading to burnout, doesn't allow the brain time to rest or recharge, impacting overall well-being.*
10:29 üíî *Burnout symptoms are evolving, with 60% of cases showing an inability to disconnect from work. Atypical burnout can manifest in seemingly engaged individuals who struggle to unplug.*
11:50 üîÑ *Addiction to work can be a sign of burnout when it interferes with sleep, relationships, and daily life, highlighting the changing face and definition of burnout.*
17:47 üîÑ *Toxic resilience, characterized by productivity at all costs and a mind-over-matter mindset, is contrasted with true resilience, emphasizing the need for rest, recovery, and self-compassion.*
21:04 üîÑ *The societal glorification of toxic resilience, reflected in messages like "Keep Calm and Carry On," contributes to the misconception that dealing with discomfort is the essence of resilience, which needs to be debunked.*
21:58 üîÑ *Resilience is discussed in the context of different generations, challenging the stereotype that older generations were more resilient due to harder labor, with the acknowledgment that each generation faces unique challenges.*
22:24 üê¶ *The "canary in the coal mine" analogy explains the physical manifestations of stress. It refers to our body's unique signals indicating stress, like palpitations, headaches, or gastrointestinal issues.*
30:10 üß† *The HPA axis (Hypothalamus, Pituitary, Adrenal) is the brain's stress information highway. Chronic stress keeps this axis active, leading to persistent hormone surges, especially cortisol, causing various health issues.*
32:51 üö´ *Stress is not contagious like a virus, but emotions and vibes can be. The heart's electromagnetic field may influence how people perceive each other's "vibes" or emotional states.*
36:23 ü§ù *The therapeutic encounter in healthcare involves creating a sense of equality, compassion, and empathy. Simple actions, like sitting at eye level, can enhance the perceived care and engagement in medical interactions.*
39:35 üéôÔ∏è *Authenticity in the human voice plays a crucial role in building connections. The voice triggers deep-seated instincts from infancy, fostering a sense of authenticity, vulnerability, and likability in human interactions.*
43:29 ‚öñÔ∏è *The "resilience rule of two" explains how our brains adapt to change. Positive changes require embracing discomfort twice: first, accepting the change, and second, adapting to the new situation, fostering brain plasticity.*
43:54 üß† *Positive lifestyle changes, such as reducing stress, can be challenging to sustain due to the brain's limited capacity for simultaneous changes.*
45:01 üìä *The "Rule of Two" is based on a study by Holmes and Rahi, suggesting that positive life changes also stress the brain, advising to focus on two changes at a time for effective adaptation.*
47:05 üîÑ *In clinical practice, incremental changes by focusing on two aspects at a time are emphasized for managing stress and achieving long-term goals.*
49:05 üéØ *The first reset involves getting clear on what matters most (MOST: Motivating, Objective, Small, Timely) to combat stress and engage the prefrontal cortex for better decision-making.*
51:07 üìà *The stress score helps in the first reset, understanding the patient's stress level, while setting MOST goals (Motivating, Objective, Small, Timely) creates a roadmap for stress management.*
54:37 üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è *Exercise, even in small amounts like a 20-minute walk, has significant benefits for stress management and mental health, improving self-efficacy and reducing anxiety.*
58:35 üçø *"Popcorn brain" is a term for the brain's overstimulation due to excessive online activity, driven by a primal urge to constantly scan for danger, especially during stressful times.*
01:00:35 üì± *To combat "popcorn brain," it's essential to establish digital boundaries and reconsider the relationship with the phone, rather than seeking complete abstinence, aiming for a healthier use.*
01:04:20 üçî *Stress-induced emotional eating is a biological response; the amygdala, focused on survival, craves high-fat, high-sugar foods during stressful periods. Understanding and managing these cravings is crucial.*
01:06:43 üöó *Acknowledge the struggle with stress but focus on regaining control; practice and knowledge help.*
01:07:12 üîÑ *Closing the gap between knowledge and action is crucial for habit-building and stress reduction.*
01:08:38 üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è *Start with small, achievable actions for stress relief, such as a 5-minute walk, to build momentum.*
01:10:28 üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è *Exercise for mental health rather than cosmetic reasons; even a 2-minute walk positively impacts stress biology.*
01:12:49 üï∞Ô∏è *Honor breaks in the workday; Microsoft study shows that 10-minute breaks reduce stress and boost mood.*
01:13:57 ‚öñÔ∏è *Not all stress is bad; differentiate between adaptive (good) and maladaptive (bad) stress for a healthier life.*
01:21:33 üçè *Foster a healthy gut-brain connection through sleep, diet, exercise, and stress reduction; focus on prebiotic and probiotic foods.*
01:23:29 üì∫ *Humorous but poignant: The "30-day plan to maximize anxiety and stress" involves habits like late-night screen exposure and irregular eating.*
01:27:55 üß† *Multitasking weakens the prefrontal cortex, impacting problem-solving, concentration, mood, and engagement. Monotasking through time blocking is a more effective approach.*
01:30:27 üå¨Ô∏è *Diaphragmatic breathing, also known as belly breathing, is an effective stress reduction technique. Inhale through the nose, expand the belly, and exhale slowly through the mouth.*
01:34:21 üõë *Stop, breathe, be: A quick mindfulness technique to switch from the sympathetic to the parasympathetic nervous system, reducing stress and promoting presence.*
01:36:29 üìù *Therapeutic writing, expressive writing for 20-25 minutes daily about a traumatic event, has been proven to improve mood, sleep, anxiety, and even increase GPA.*
01:41:16 üåà *"Live a lifetime in a day": Incorporate elements of childhood, work, solitude, vacation, family, and retirement daily to bring fulfillment and meaning into life, countering the hustle culture.*
01:43:55 üì± *Implement a media diet by setting time limits, keeping the phone away during work, and creating logistical boundaries, reducing stress and enhancing mental health.*
01:46:55 üåê *Consuming graphic content, such as videos and images, increases the risk of PTSD and mental health conditions, emphasizing the need for moderation and awareness in media consumption.*
01:48:04 üåê *Being an informed citizen is crucial, but establishing digital boundaries is equally important for mental health.*
01:49:10 üß† *Overconsumption of news, especially graphic content, can lead to mental health issues; seek counseling if experiencing distress.*
01:50:30 üì± *Excessive phone use contributes to a sense of hyperconnectivity but actual disconnection, fueling a global loneliness epidemic.*
01:51:39 üíî *Loneliness is a health concern, equated to smoking 15 cigarettes a day, increasing heart disease and stroke risks.*
01:52:27 üòî *Internal experiences may not align with external appearances; kindness is vital as everyone is facing unseen struggles.*
01:53:34 üîÑ *Stress and resilience terminologies need reframing; chronic stress should not be glamorized, and a nuanced middle ground is crucial.*
01:54:57 üéôÔ∏è *Empathetic communication is key; understanding the humanity in individuals' work fosters connection and success.*
01:55:53 ü§ù *Feedback is valuable; continuous learning and reinforcing beliefs through feedback contribute to personal and professional growth.*

author: @v9b23j
text: I faced criticism for not conforming to the idea of "toxic resilience" in the workplace. Recognizing signs of burnout in both my team members and myself, I expressed concerns about unsustainable working hours and workload. I proposed solutions such as increasing manpower or reevaluating project priorities, recommending the deprioritization of certain tasks. Furthremore, my doctor diagnosed me with adjustment disorder, highlighting the impact of workplace stress on my mental health. In response, my line manager conveyed that my work style was not aligned with the current phase of the company's business at the time.

author: @‡∏Å‡∏∏‡∏®‡∏•‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏£‡∏°‡∏ö‡∏ó10
text:
BUDDHA

I have heard that on one occasion the Blessed One was staying among the Kajjangalas in the Bamboo Grove. Then the young brahman Uttara, a student of Parasiri[1] went to the Blessed One and, on arrival, exchanged friendly greetings & courtesies. After this exchange of courteous greetings he sat to one side.

As he was sitting there, the Blessed One said to him: "Uttara, does the brahman Parasiri teach his followers the development of the faculties?"

"Yes, master Gotama, he does."

"And how does he teach his followers the development of the faculties?"

"There is the case where one does not see forms with the eye, or hear sounds with the ear [in a trance of non-perception]. That's how the brahman Parasiri teaches his followers the development of the faculties."

"That being the case, Uttara, then a blind person will have developed faculties, and a deaf person will have developed faculties, according to the words of the brahman Parasiri. For a blind person does not see forms with the eye, and a deaf person does not hear sounds with the ear."

When this was said, the young brahman Uttara sat silent & abashed, his shoulders slumped, his head down, brooding, at a loss for words. The Blessed One ‚Äî noticing that Uttara was sitting silent & abashed, his shoulders slumped, his head down, brooding, at a loss for words ‚Äî said to Ven. Ananda, "Ananda, the development of the faculties that the brahman Parasiri teaches his followers is one thing, but the unexcelled development of the faculties in the discipline of a noble one is something else entirely."

"Now is the time, O Blessed One. Now is the time, O One Well-Gone, for the Blessed One to teach the unexcelled development of the faculties in the discipline of the noble one. Having heard the Blessed One, the monks will remember it."

"In that case, Ananda, listen & pay close attention. I will speak."

"As you say, lord," Ven. Ananda responded to the Blessed One.

The Blessed One said: "Now how, Ananda, in the discipline of a noble one is there the unexcelled development of the faculties? There is the case where, when seeing a form with the eye, there arises in a monk what is agreeable, what is disagreeable, what is agreeable & disagreeable. He discerns that 'This agreeable thing has arisen in me, this disagreeable thing... this agreeable & disagreeable thing has arisen in me. And that is compounded, gross, dependently co-arisen. But this is peaceful, this is exquisite, i.e., equanimity.' With that, the arisen agreeable thing... disagreeable thing... agreeable & disagreeable thing ceases, and equanimity takes its stance. Just as a man with good eyes, having closed them, might open them; or having opened them, might close them, that is how quickly, how rapidly, how easily, no matter what it refers to, the arisen agreeable thing... disagreeable thing... agreeable & disagreeable thing ceases, and equanimity takes its stance. In the discipline of a noble one, this is called the unexcelled development of the faculties with regard to forms cognizable by the eye.

"Furthermore, when hearing a sound with the ear, there arises in a monk what is agreeable, what is disagreeable, what is agreeable & disagreeable. He discerns that 'This agreeable thing has arisen in me, this disagreeable thing... this agreeable & disagreeable thing has arisen in me. And that is compounded, gross, dependently co-arisen. But this is peaceful, this is exquisite, i.e., equanimity.' With that, the arisen agreeable thing... disagreeable thing... agreeable & disagreeable thing ceases, and equanimity takes its stance. Just as a strong man might easily snap his fingers, that is how quickly, how rapidly, how easily, no matter what it refers to, the arisen agreeable thing... disagreeable thing... agreeable & disagreeable thing ceases, and equanimity takes its stance. In the discipline of a noble one, this is called the unexcelled development of the faculties with regard to sounds cognizable by the ear.

author: @withfeelingthistime
text: Hm. this makes me think about my negative self-talk, adhd, and insecurity. as dr. k described how he views and organizes his week from the big picture, i was also starting to think about my weeks from a bigger picture. it was then that i realized that the big picture view is a place that's really uncomfortable for me. personally, i get weak in the knees and anxious whenever i run into any problems. i usually berate myself over being incompetent, which i learned from my mom. but this ability which i know i possess--reaching into the big picture, is where i felt most vulnerable and attacked. it might be exactly where the culprit lies, in terms of what my insecurity is sourced from, and what my negative self-talk is attacking. the part of myself which goes into the big picture view is worried about being belittled for my efforts at organizing my life, so i back down from even trying. this is the mechanism which my mom would exert control over me--putting down my will and making organizing seem like too big of a task for me. even though she's not here, i default to putting myself down too. it's her signature that she left as i was developing. now i feel like life is out of my control, and my internal will is suppressed in fear that trying at all is dangerous. so with this new insight i'm going to intentionally put myself in to organize my life with my own will, until i bust the thought-patterns which inhibit me.

author: @TES-541
text:
This comment section is so wild, so many people looking for excuses not to apply what he's saying. First off, if you're saying "well my job sucks or is so tedious I can't" well then the goal for you is to pursue a different career if you want. Secondly, usually with work there's a ton of different types of tasks within that role. So if you have a shitty retail job, you can still work on other things on the weekend. Like he talks about doing tedious stuff like that HR training on the weekends, stuff that relates to the job but isn't the same.

We all know this we've all went to school and worked at the same time where none of us had a full day off. And if your job is so stressful or awful that you can't work on or create anything outside of it, like I said, try to get a different job because most people don't feel that way about their jobs even if they dislike it. Hell, as a kid when everyone I knew was in a band, we all went to school, worked a job and still put in tons of times to play shows, write music, promote, etc. Comment sections would have you believe we don't all have the same 168 hours in a week. I get that the mental health epidemic sucks now, but a part of it is that we have easy access to everything but we'd all rather sit and game for 10 hours and complain.

author: @azarak34
text:
A few points though: 
1. you can do worst tasks early in the week or as soon as it appears. It's called "eating the frog". If you are employed on 40h contract you shouldn't need to work on your weekends. Just do it during your work time and don't let it occupy your mind by postponing it.
2. Using of subconscious is a good hack, but it is a two way street: if you DON'T want to remember something just cram it into one day and use the method for things you do want to affect you on more fundamental level.

11:35 personal timestamp - edit: mental compositing
this is something that i practice in school (i call it "incubating") but do not realize would became something i would miss later in life. people would often see that as procrastination, and would remind me of my tasks. i am aware that it does seem like putting off tasks, but i know i did better so. or at least my mind operated better when i give time to analyze or just twice-checking matters. this would differ with anyone though! i know some folks who prefer to do their work as fast as possible, as it gives them mental comfort.

author: @alexsemyonov6993
text:
In school/university time I used to read 5 books simultaneously.
Read one, two, three chapters, ask questions to yourself, and look for answers in the world, For the next 4 days you'll load up other parts of your gorgeous neural networks. So the initial information can be processed unbothered by new information on the subject,.
But this chunk of knowledge will influence your study of 4 other books. Your subconsciousness will find and form connections between topics/subjects! That is the real superpower.
That's why in soviet style universities interconnected subjects are studied in the same semester. That way you learn faster and understand how the fuck math will help you be a good engineer. Because you use that level of math in Theoretical Mechanics,  Material resistance, Physics, and the Basics of Scientific Methods. So you learn math methods just ones and get your chance to practice this new skill in 4 other subjects.

author: @matthewr7593
text:
People in the comments are pretty ridiculous. Everyone's like "I can't do this because I work a job we're I'm constantly forced to do specific, draining tasks by a boss for every hour I work and I can't determine my schedule." Well then, duh, this video isn't for you. Read the caption. He asks "Are there ways to better organize your work to make your life better?" if the answer for you is no then these tips won't help you. But they will help some people that have jobs they can be more flexible with. Creative freelancers, entrepreneurs, etc. Just because you don't work that kind of job doesn't mean they don't exist, and no advice will be universal when it comes to jobs and careers, which come in a million different forms. 

And even if you don't have a job that this applies to, there are lessons here for those that have creative pursuits. If you're a writer, a musician, etc. that want to produce great work, get better at your craft, stay disciplined, this is the kind of stuff that people use for creative productivity. 

It seems like people in the comments are really just looking to vent that they have a job or career that they hate. If that's the case I'm sorry, unfortunately most of us have gone through that at some point.

author: @roozoe
text:
I don't disagree, but this video seems to have a very serious blindspot about the labour market. 

The beginning of this video is spot on, in terms of framing the struggle many face, but then goes to assume that all jobs have these different levels of tasks and that we are free to manage how we use our time. This is often not the case since the invention of the division of labour. If you are in telemarketing, if you're a barista, if you're a delivery guy, if you're a janitor or cleaning lady,  ect... you have no research, you have no finding creative solutions, that's the stuff you're expected to do on your own time. Many people choose to take on jobs which offer some time flexibility, (eg:  barista) with very limited income so that they have some time for creative projects. The jobs that are the next tier up, often pay a little better, but you are expected to work 40 hours on one type of work with little self-management. Its as you get higher up to jobs that are  more competitive and/or require higher levels of education that problem-solving, research, creativity and self-management apear.

author: @MikaTuukkanen
text: One thing I like about my job is that I can work almost whenever I want (tho I need to be reachable during some regular working hours). I too sometimes like to work on weekends. I don't do much work, but like starting a day with 1-3 hours of work does not really use much of my time and I may even get decent results in those hours, as I don't work out of necessity, but because I am in the correct mood. But this leads to another issue: We have way too much work. Most of us don't like our work and most of the hours is the kind of work that leaves us exhausted. And even when we like it, 8 hours is way too much. It is just an useless time waster. We should drastically reduce working hours. And no, we don't need to reduce pay. Just look at graphs that show how we are greatly more efficient than ever, but we are paid pretty much the same type of money than in the 80's, when the shift to efficiency happened. Workers deserve more. Investors and CEOs should stop leaching our results. Especially investors creeate absolutely nothing.

author: @DJTS1991
text:
I edit videos for a living.

When the video is a priority, fantastic, I have all the support I need from a client, and the job gets done quicker.
When the video is not a priority from the client, the lack of communication drives me to use up more mental energy and resources to get the job done.

And I get exhausted.

I end up being massively burnt out (and even taken advantage of) when I'm expected to do things that don't fit within the scope of my job.
And when I explain that their expectations are unreasonable, and I need to get paid more or being given more resources, they (understandably) get upset.

Often what happens is that they'll find someone else who they feel is better qualified to do the work, but what usually happens is the pattern repeats itself.
The last two video editors in my position quit due to mental health issues. That's a pattern. That means there's a problem with the leadership, or the environment.

The more people give me, the more I feel excited to give them something in return.

author: @chaosknighthd3138
text:
I incorporate hobbies into my work and enforce a mindset that what I'm doing at work will make me a better person for my next job until its my dream job. For example I work as a barrista because its my first job and at the end of the day I am tasked to mop and sweep the floor of the small shop I work in. I took that job willingly because I've associated mopping and sweeping with exercise. And just with proffessional life if I become strong enough to handle my job effortlessly, its time to look for a bigger fish to eat. At times this task gets more difficult when children are making more mess or an accident took place but over time I accepted that the responsibility to work is also a part of my responsibility to be a stronger person for the next step in my life. I don't plan to be in hospitality for the rest of my life, so why not turn it into a meaninful story arc. 

Notice how I don't rely on praise from my boss or co workers, external motivation from the pay (my parents do this a lot), or even the time I don't have to wait for to work on my future career. The job is simply now a outlet to work on something I was already doing before I got my job. The "end of the day" is simply a continueation of my current routine. I go home, work on my Esports, wind down and go to bed. If there's no growth to be had at your workplace, then its the wrong workplace for you.

author: @TomYoungster
text: This is fascinating. I often hear and feel that "2 day weekends are simply not enough rest", which, when they are your ONLY days you give yourself permission to rest, they aren't. However, this 7 day work week kind of unlocks the idea that you CAN rest 7 days a week BECAUSE you are also applying conscientious effort towards work or goals. The 2 days of rest into Monday "catch up" is setting up for failure, but only a couple hours of effort in those same 2 days makes both the days feel better, AND the work week feel less stressful. Truly a win-win.

author: @Tabby3456
text:
Working at fast food does not give you that option.
Mainly because its a job were you're suppose to deliver a service or role and be able to give it consistently and fast.

 Some jobs like doing the dishes in the back is easy; no real rush and you can listen to music and podcasts because no one will see you either than the manager and your co-workers and it doesn't require you to listen to someone else, so what I like to do is just before work like the night of my day off, I would take all the music I like and put it in a collection list and have it on autoplay, then when I goto work and I get put back on dishes; I can simply just put on my headphones, my cleaning gear like gloves and apron and clean away while listening to my favorite music. Because of the simplicity of doing dishes: I can listen to music without impairing my ability to do the dishes.

However if you're a cashier, fry cook, or responsible for making sure the order a customer ordered is right and delivering it to them, you can't just listen to music. You can't hear orders, Customers will complain and then the manager will have to inform you that you can't wear headphones at work or play music, even if you're the only one playing it out loud, because nobody cares about your taste in music. With the flexible scheduling where the employee has control over their own schedule, you can either end up being so overstaffed that the managers just send some people home or understaffed where they have to either close half the store like only allowing drive thru orders to be taken or close entirely and  in instances where the drive-thru is the only thing that's open; now we have even more complaints over their order taking so long to be made.

I don't have much faith in my workplace, Letalone for fast-food employment anymore since work is already draining in of itself and making food really fast seems not only like the most unproductive compared to what I could be doing, but also like an impossibility, considering the fact that the food I usually eat takes more than 15 minutes to make and i find that more enjoyable than whatever I do at work. we're understaffed, and that no one gets paid sick leave so they end up going to work and hiding their illness and bring down an illness onto nearly everyone that works there, and to top it all off: a person in line that is going hangry because he didn't get his order the moment he parked at the window where he would get his meal  .

author: @GosuKitten
text:
The only gripe i have with this is that the kind of job you have impacts this tactic a lot. If someone works retail, you can't do this. If you work a standard 9-5 and you need to do your work within those times, you can't do this. My point being, the only time you can really do this is if you're lucky enough to have work that does not have strict restrictions on time and days you work, and has that breakup between different kinds of tasks. You, Dr. K, are in a very privileged position to be able to create the kind of work week you wish to have, and adopt to your needs. Many people lack that position. The video lacks that sensitivity, which can feel quite sad to those people who can not break up their days like you. 

That said, i highly appreciate your input and this is definitely still very valuable. I have experienced the idea that not all work is equal, and that different times and different tasks tend to feel better or worse depending on the combination. I am greatful for having a position at my work that is a bit more freeing to let me reorganize my tasks, although i am not enough so to be able to change on what days i do what tasks. 

For anyone reading that's not in a position to do that, i sympathize and i hope you can view this as a way to look at work or necessary things to do in life outside of work, as this information can still be helpful there. 

Thank you Dr.K and the community. You are all awesome <3

author: @definitelynotavinash
text:
*Notes*

> What does work mean?
Something that produces value in the external world. 
Work is heterogenous in nature. Tasks that you like and tasks that you don‚Äôt like doing. 
Some tasks are easier to do at particular times. 
Some tasks you can do at any time, because it gives energy. Even when initially tired.
Some tasks that can make you tired, no matter how energetic you are. 

> Not all work is the same. 
Creative work. Ideating, brainstorming, planning, writing. 
Creative energy battery which regenerates, longer yields in a single session create diminishing returns. 
It can make you feel productive and create energy for the rest of the day. Dr K does this on the weekend. 
Reading on a focused topic where there is curiosity. 
Doing research on something you‚Äôre curious about. 

> Mental composting
Ideas get consolidated through sleep.
If you research something and then sleep on it, the information gets stored better to be of use to you. 
It‚Äôs hard to brainstorm at the end of a day full of meetings. 
Give the mind the time to maul over things. 
Mental composting yields a lot of efficiency if you space out the creative work. 
Being able to execute and write content for a video easily, because of the research that has done several days before it. 
This creates the ability to do a 6 hour task in 3 hours instead. 

> Work the we hate doing
Imagine on Sunday night, that the least favourite tasks were actually taken care of. 
How would that change how you feel about the upcoming week?
It‚Äôs the little time you spend on these kinds of tasks, that can make you feel tired. 
Working 7 days a week can be quite invigorating. Doing some work for next week, can really be invigorating. Taking advantage of the creative energy battery through mental composting. 
The tasks that burn us out, if we actually work at it for 30 minutes the mental resistance is way less. 
What really burns you out, is having to worry about those tasks or expected results. 
Working 7 days a week can be more productive, even though that might sounds unnatural.

author: @ShazySoft
text:
I think that the effectiveness of this approach is heavily dependent on how self-directed you are in your work. I've had jobs where every single moment is rigidly accounted for. Doing boring clerical work on the weekend just meant that I would be expected to do even more work over the week. Thus, increasing the amount of clerical work I'd have to do to begin with. It would cycle like that until I'd just burn out.

Contrasting that with now, when I work for myself, I actually do a lot of these things. They work much better in this situation.

author: @Lyraden
text:
I think people are misinterpreting the point of this video.

This video is not trying to solve every single problem for everyone‚Äôs specific situation related to burnout. For all the people saying this doesn‚Äôt apply to a 9-5 position, or that this video is only for self employed workers, that is sort of the point. Dr. K is trying to talk about a specific type of burnout while also showing us new ways to think and engage with it. 

If you don‚Äôt think this applies to you because you are stuck in a position where your tasks don‚Äôt provide value, then that just means this video is not the next step for you. 

HealthygamerGG has a lot of educational videos on how to transition into a work environment that is better suited for you such as ‚ÄúWill I be Stuck at a Crappy Job Forever?‚Äù or ‚ÄúI Hate My Job.‚Äù 

HealthygamerGG has never tried to make one single video to address every single situation.

The purpose of having all these videos is so that we can build our own individualistic roadmap to create the life that we want to move towards.

author: @MiketheNerdRanger
text:
Somehow I was very confused when watching this. Questions I had immediately was "wait, what's the deadline of these tasks? What if you don't know what the topic is going to be before they told you to write a lecture in 6 hours? What if you didn't have a choice to do a certain stupid task any other day than the day the boss told you to do it? How is it you have room to plan your work like this?" Then I realized; this video doesn't apply to people with a regular job. 

Regular jobs have strict deadlines, and usually piss poor management. You couldn't do all the stuff Dr K. is talking about in a regular job. It seems that while Dr K. still works for people to a degree, he has a lot more control over his topics and deadlines, room to stretch, if you will. Not so in most other places. I think this would apply better for people doing independent work, or at least jobs that have a high level of autonomy, both of which are *very* privileged positions. I don't see this video helping most people.

author: @josxxiv
text: This only really applies if you have a series of tasks to check off. Burnout comes from the endless treading of water, of it not mattering how much you get done, management will always find more for you to do. Burnout comes from finishing a task only to be told that actually that task is no longer needed and you now have to start over on something that is just dissimilar enough that nothing you just did is recyclable. Burnout comes from weak leadership, uncaring management, and from people who have achieved a position that allows a healthy work life balance lecturing down on you as if they‚Äôve discovered this wonderful silver bullet that is only applicable to people in their similar situation

author: @SloMoMonday
text:
I think this advice speaks to a very spesific group of people who are self employed or in a more flexible position. For me, this way of thinking falls down at the first step because the most work that needs to be done does not always create value. And even then, the value-generating work needed to be feasible is escalateing to the point of impossibly.

My partner and I are coming to terms with the fact that after half a decade of grinding, hard work and forgoing many luxuries, we are effectively further away from even our most conservative goals. And it's because life involves family responsibility work, and medical emergency work, and social work, and trauma work, and unforseen accident work, and global pendemic work, and child care work. You could argue that there is value there, but it is not transferable. 

Hell, I would kill to have time to do something creative, or to take time to learn things that could put me in a better position or to financially benefit from the things I'm passionate about. But that means I'm risking rent or I'm coming up short for my meds or I'm sacrificing meals.

author: @hannahwhite7227
text: The amount fulfillment and satisfaction you get from the work (no matter what I kind of job it is) can determine how much time and work you‚Äôre willing to put into it. If someone enjoys doing the task required for a job and is compensated fairly for example it‚Äôs more likely that someone will want to excel at that job and put in more hours. The opposite often demotivates people and builds resentment towards what or who is making them feel dissatisfied or unfulfilled.

I would take a little bit of time every day to look at my setup and go "Hmm if I buy this I can move this and free some space.. etc etc." without really committing to anything. Seeing ideas online in my downtime between work and when pay day came a week from then; I was prepared to get exactly what I needed and adjust my room how I wanted. I think this kind of thinking is applicable to many things in life not just work; because there are a endless amount of things we want to do so tackling them in the most relaxed effort way possible is a boon.

author: @RorySmith-x5o
text: work-life balance has always been tricky for me, especially diving into consulting. like, the case interviews were way out of my league! i tried winging it alone, but oh boy, it was a flop. then, The Thinksters came along. they showed me how to break down cases logically. now off to McKinsey, can you believe it? back then, they even had these no-cost intro sessions... not sure if thats still a thing!

author: @bendt-k2o
text: This is such a crucial message, especially now when so many are struggling with burnout and feeling like work is consuming their lives. It's not just about finding the perfect balance, but about finding a job and company that values your life outside of work and helps you integrate the two. Thanks, Simon, for giving us the language to talk about this more effectively.

author: @TiffanyLewis-q4s
text: It's about finding a company that respects your life outside of work, but it's also about setting your own boundaries and knowing when to disconnect. The video makes a great point about integrating work and life for a more fulfilling existence, but we also need to acknowledge the privilege inherent in that idea and advocate for better conditions for all workers. Let's hope more companies realize that happy, well-rested employees are ultimately more productive.

author: @LisaSanchez-u6s
text: While the integration of work and life sounds ideal, it's a privilege many don't have, and we need to advocate for policies that make decent work-life balance accessible to everyone, regardless of their job. Let's remember that fair compensation and reasonable working conditions are the foundations for any meaningful integration.

author: @sawaomoncrief
text: It's a valuable perspective to consider how work and life can be integrated, but we also need to acknowledge the systemic barriers and advocate for equitable working conditions so that everyone has the opportunity to prioritize their well-being, not just those with privilege. How can we create systems that support this for *all* workers, regardless of their industry or socioeconomic status?

author: @DenaHarris-u2t
text: While the ideal of integration is inspiring, it's important to acknowledge the reality that for many, work is purely transactional, and true integration feels impossible. Let's advocate for better working conditions and fair compensation for everyone so that this concept becomes more accessible. Maybe then the choice becomes a luxury, not a fairytale.

author: @sheilah-e1y
text: It's a vital message, and it highlights the need for companies to genuinely support employee well-being, not just pay lip service to the idea. Creating workplaces that value people over pure output is the real challenge. Let's hope more leaders start listening and acting.

author: @nanice-p8c
text: This is a great reminder that "work-life balance" isn't about a perfect 50/50 split, but about integrating the two in a way that brings you fulfillment and prevents burnout. It's a privilege to have the option, but something we should all strive for, even in small ways. Let's not forget the importance of advocating for better conditions for those who have no choice.

author: @kasmira-q3l
text: This video highlights the importance of shifting from "work-life balance" to integrating work into a meaningful life, but let's not forget the privilege inherent in that discussion; many struggle with simply surviving, where flexibility remains a distant dream. We need to advocate for policies that support *everyone*, not just those with already flexible roles, to achieve a healthier and more fulfilling existence.

author: @KellySantiago-z5z
text: This resonates so deeply, especially the idea that work and life shouldn't be opposing forces. The biggest hurdle is creating workplaces where this integration is genuinely supported and not just a buzzword. It starts with leadership valuing their employees' well-being as much as productivity.

author: @jaelanamontez
text: Simon's message is powerful, but it's important to acknowledge that this ideal is far from the reality for many workers facing economic pressures and limited job options. Let's strive for a future where "work-life integration" isn't just a privilege, but an accessible standard for all. Shifting the focus from mere "balance" to genuine integration requires a fundamental change in how companies value their employees and prioritize their well-being.

author: @lundy-l5j
text: Simon, you've articulated the need for a shift in perspective perfectly; it's less about balancing opposing forces and more about integrating work into a life that feels meaningful and sustainable. The challenge lies in how we empower individuals to prioritize their well-being within varied work environments and societal expectations. This video is such a refreshing perspective!

author: @janessemitchem
text: It's easy to talk about harmony when you're not struggling to make ends meet; for many, work is just a means to survival, not self-actualization. Maybe the goal shouldn't be seamless integration, but fair compensation and humane conditions so people can actually *afford* a life outside of work.

author: @heidemariesanmiguel
text: The key is finding a company culture that values employees as humans, not just cogs in a machine, and having the courage to prioritize your well-being, even if it means making tough choices. It's inspiring to see how reframing our perspective can lead to a more fulfilling life, even if it's not always easy to achieve.

author: @wanaaowalmsley
text: It's great to hear about companies embracing a more human approach, but let's not forget the many for whom "work-life balance" is a luxury they simply can't afford. We need to keep fighting for better conditions and fair compensation for *all* workers, so everyone has a chance to integrate their lives more fully.

author: @TherapywithouttheTherapist
text: I'm not going to name any names... but I have recently started working for a very popular outdoor sporting goods store here in St Louis Missouri. I actually interviewed and was hired for an entity of the store which is through a well-known credit card company to get credit card accounts for this store. I was there through grand opening and got this store going and we became number one in the nation in the credit card department. As soon as this happened they made cuts and since I was one of the people who had the most hours they cut me. The sporting store that this entity was in recognized my accomplishments and wanted to keep me but the only position that they could give me was a cashier's position. I have worked 30 years in retail climbing a ladder so I would never have to be a cashier again. To keep myself from having to find another job I agreed because they said that they would give me full-time with benefits however they have been forcing me to work what they call a "cashier's schedule"basically having no work-life balance whatsoever. I have been struggling with PTSD and trying to work this schedule has put me in a position of being triggered all day long. I got into therapy but work would not allow me the day off for the only day that I could do therapy so I had to email HR and threatened that they were keeping me from getting medical attention. They allowed me Wednesdays off but they still would not give me a work-life balance scheduling me hours such as 11:00 to 8:00 1:00 to 9:00 sometimes 9:00 to 6:00... I never knew exactly when I was going to be working. I finally reached the point of burnout and had to go on disability. My doctor and the disability program headset restrictions and or stipulations for me to work a specific schedule upon returning to work. My work is not wanting to comply with this schedule. I had to have my doctor and disability program reach out to them again because they were trying to say that they never received this information. They said that they will review it and get back to me.

author: @asiriaarba6916
text:
ùóõùóºùòÑ ùóóùóº ùó¨ùóºùòÇ ùó†ùóÆùó∂ùóªùòÅùóÆùó∂ùóª ùóÆ ùóïùóÆùóπùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ ùó∂ùóª ùóüùó∂ùó≥ùó≤?

The still, vegetative and animate levels of nature are the only ones in a state of balance, because they have no free choice. They make no decisions as to whether they should behave one way or another, but they behave according to their inborn nature.

We people, however, act according to our decisions that are higher than our inborn nature. We thus use these levels of nature‚Äîstill, vegetative and animate, which are below our human level‚Äîegoistically, bending them however we wish for personal benefit.

We thus destroy and empty the planet, plant life, animals, and eventually also people, due to the egoistic way we relate to each other and nature.

The system we live in was set up so that we reach a state of mutual consideration, encouragement and support. That is the key to entering into a state of balance with nature.

By acting contrarily, with calculations of self-benefit overriding those of benefiting each other and nature, we then knock ourselves out of balance with nature.

Then, we experience this imbalance as suffering on personal, social and economic scales, and also as ecological blows, whether it be earthquakes, floods, wildfires, pandemics and several other phenomena that we call ‚Äúnatural disasters.‚Äù

The more we head into the future without transforming our attitudes to each other and nature‚Äîfrom egoistic to altruistic‚Äîthen the more we will experience our tightening interdependence negatively.

However, if we start relating in a considerate, supportive and encouraging way to each other, then we will see how nature also relates positively to us. Accordingly, we will unlock a new balanced, harmonious and peaceful existence.

author: @travis8229
text: I worked for a company nearly two decades and there was literally no work-life freedom for many years. My second year at company manager brings me in tells me I've got to be really committed to the job now, extra responsibilities etc, but where was the pay? At the time was only making 9 bucks an hour. Then I started going to school that same year, big mistake. Because of this commitment the manager had spoken of I was called upon many days to work overtime. The job itself was a strict 8-5, Monday-Friday, but with the overtime and the school schedules, this was before online schooling was popular, i basically had to drop all my courses for two semesters. Then there was overbearing work some years that was like wtf. Really. The managers said to be committed to job, but the only people who were making bank at the company were the owners, millions a year, then they retired, the only people from that company who benefited from the commitment. It really made me aware too late in life, that a worker should not be loyal to a job if it's a hostile work environment but I was loyal for way too many years.

author: @ChillingD-k8b
text: Work-life balance is about finding a healthy and sustainable way to manage both your professional and personal responsibilities. It's important to set clear boundaries and prioritize your time according to your values and goals. Take time to recharge and invest in your well-being through activities like exercise, hobbies, and spending time with loved ones. Additionally, communicate your needs and limitations with your employer and colleagues. Remember, work-life balance is a continuous process that requires ongoing evaluation and adjustment. By finding a balance that works for you, you can enhance your productivity, creativity, and overall happiness.

author: @ahmadhafis4
text: So, when you're going on vacation, are you obliged to attend some meetings that it will affect your vacation plans? Will you be penalized for not attending meetings during your vacation? Where do you draw the line. How to ensure work-life integration does not morph to work 24 hours? As long as the choice is in the employees hand, I have no issues with it. But if an employee is burdened with tasks and tight deadlines and asked to deliver all of them, while being told to manage your own time when really there is not enough time to the point you are forced to work more than business hours, that's where it becomes an issue. If its not broken, don't try to fix it. I will stick with work life balance with clear boundaries than without boundaries where it can morph into working all the time without extra compensation. Thanks

author: @ashleyrossgoingmerrily
text:
Thank you for normalizing this Simon! I think work-life balance is crap. It paints the wrong picture and, yes, sets the two things against each other vs. encouraging collaboration between the two. Just like we don't all learn the same, we don't all work or live the same either. Which is ridiculously obvious, but society's structure doesn't support that. 

So if you are a freelancer or business owner and you are realizing you've built a business you hate because it's exactly like what you left, try writing out some lifestyle goals and boundaries along with your business ones and readjust the way your work and live accordingly! It's never too late to find joy in life again.

So too with my peers and the highly educated people who report to me. For the people who clean the office, do maintenance, work in the cafeteria, etc., life isn‚Äôt so flexible for them. It‚Äôs all too easy for people to ignore them because they are an invisible class of people to those on top. They aren‚Äôt you neighbors, friends, or colleagues. author: @thepsychologist8159
text:
"I am uncomfortable with this concept of work-life balance"
- Of course you are, because your position in life is to make opposing/radical comments so that people will listen, because you say what most people want to hear.
"because balance is achieved with two opposing forces"
- Genius, absolutely genius ... how does he do it?
"And why should work and life be in opposition"
- Hello! Wake up and smell the roses.  Do you think most people love to work? Do you think most people love their job?  They'd sooner just live and enjoy life.  However, if you don't work, you don't have any money. It's a mundane ritual in the pursuit of gaining the ability to sustain yourself physiologically, to provide safety and then the more stimulating social things in life.
Like a mother who wants to be at home with her children, but can't because she has to work.  That, my friend, are what you call 'opposing forces'.  It's all well and good to be this guru saying all these things and giving these wondering opinions, but I'm afraid in reality, they don't mean a pinch of sh!t to the common person.
"We used to have a thing called duvet days"
- But then he goes on to describe that they are 'constrained' to 5 days a year and that in essence in taking a 'duvet day' is simply delaying the inevitable of going to work the next day, and for the next week, making up for all the work that piled up on the day you were down at the beach.
- Honestly, Simon Sinek makes some brilliant comments, and has some brilliant ideas, but in reality they just don't work and these words of inspiration are actually for those who lack inspiration and will never have it.

As a single parent I preferred this because I worked evenings and not going in fri meant I could have three days in the week off instead of two because I could go in through the day Sat. My last boss rocked with this flexibility. As long as I got my contracts done by monday 8 am he didn't care when I went in. author: @smvishnukanth
text:
At times, DOING NOTHING helps a lot. I practice this technique, whenever possible, be it 5mins or anything plus or minus, just sit (or even stand but NOT in sleep position as it quickly induces sleep) and do nothing. No observation of breath, no body scanning.. nothing. Just let your mind wander, as time goes by you can feel the gravity of thoughts are not as bothering as it was before. For me it takes a min of 20mins for the thoughts to calm down.

Our brain (or mind I don't know) really needs some quality rest. A rest like a baby or toddler gets. Our brain has got natural capacity to heal itself or in other words to organize its compartments and all it needs is some idle time.

author: @cbsteffen
text:
When you have stress so hard to relieve, you feel as if you have a boss with the following conflicts/traits:

-The boss insists you work for 140 hours a week for more than a few years without any days-off. Otherwise, he threatens to kill you for sure!
-Whoever overhears the threat calls the cops, and the cops try shooting him, but every bullet bounces off of him and back at the cops because the boss has 200% armor for flesh and therefore takes no physical damage whatsoever (and therefore also destroys sharp weapons and stingers of stinging insects and even breaks hard, heavy objects and any wild animal‚Äôs teeth and claws). He immediately destroys handcuffs for the same reason.
-Then the cops and neighbors try scaring the boss, but nothing scares him because fury is literally his only emotion!
-When trying to outrun him, he always runs faster unless he gets tired and therefore needs sleep, but he only sleeps for at most 2 hours in every 24-hour period and is a seriously light sleeper, so even the quietest noise ever can wake him, and it takes him too long to get back to sleep!

author: @huzefahamid9339
text:
My notes:

1.	If memory and focus aren‚Äôt working how you want them to, it can be stress related.

2.	Stress affects two areas of the brain: the frontal lobe (the area for working memory, keeping emotions under control, goal setting, making plans, prioritizing what to do first, next, etc.) and the hippocampus, which is the core of our memory.

3.	High-stress hormones shrink the cells in the frontal lobe and hippocampus.

4.	The best thing you do for your brain is to be physically active. When we‚Äôre working out, it‚Äôs not just good because our heart starts pumping and we get oxygen to our brain, but while we are physically active, our brain makes growth factor that stimulates the outgrowth of the branches in brain cells. They re-establish contact with each other, maybe even new cells are formed.

5.	It doesn‚Äôt have to be a marathon. Research shows that people who do a brisk 45-minute walk 3 times per week gave a bigger hippocampus than people who only do stretching exercises.

6.	Sleeping well is the second very important thing you can do. Sleep loss is a chronic stressor. Even after one night of poor sleep results in poorer concentration, memory and irritability. During sleep, our brain reorganizes itself: good connections are strengthened, and bad connections are removed. Sleep washes the brain clean of waste products. We need that for a good working brain.

7.	Your brain needs good building blocks, i.e. food. It‚Äôs hard to pinpoint which vitamins or minerals are good for your brain, but for a whole eating pattern, it‚Äôs clear that people who eat a Mediterranean diet have a brain for a longer time with better memory and concentration.

8.	A Mediterranean diet is large amounts of fruits & vegetables, fish which provide omega-3 fatty acids (we cannot make them ourselves), other proteins and grains, and healthy fats (olive and nuts‚Äîin some studies, these seem to be the two secret ingredients that keep your brain healthy for a long time). Red wine is not good for your brain!

9.	Meditating is the fourth thing you can do for your brain. Increased scientific research shows that daily meditation can benefit your focus and attention. In a basic way, meditation trains your attention and emotional control. You can start with five minutes a day and see how it goes. You can try it, for example, five minutes daily when you wake up or before bed.

10.	These four adjustments can counteract the devastating effects of chronic stress and make your brain resilient to it.

11.	Nilki built these areas into her routine after getting burned out through work. She feels her brain works well again, maybe even better than ever. And she now knows it‚Äôs perfectly fine to work hard and long hours as long as she takes good care of her brain.

12.	Be good to your brain. It‚Äôs the crown of who you are. Treat her like a queen!

author: @suhailansari132
text:
One of the most effective-proven way to reduce brian stress is through brain conditioning. According to this, whenever you don't feel good or positive due to any reasons(emotional, financial, or any type), just tell your brian that it is the best possible situation that I am into, things can get even worse, I am destined for such challenges or huddles or situations in my life, and that I am required to be happy despite such hardships or setbacks. If you master the art of being happy in any kind of situation, detach your happiness from any achievement or success then you don't feel stress.
Nothing is like stress or happiness, it is our mind conditioning  that perceive any situation or things good or bad and based on that we would be stressed or delighted.

author: @TLDR423
text:
Tl:dr; be good to your Brian. 

1. Niki Korteweg is trained in neuro biologist and a science journalist. She knows what she‚Äôs talking about. 
2. Goes on to explain how brain works. 
3. 4 most important ones for your Brian and reduce stress 

A. Be physically active, exercise or even walk briskly. Don‚Äôt need to run marathons. 
B. Sleep well 
C. Eat smart - no processed foods, green leafy veggies, eat Mediterranean diet (Fruits/veggies, fish, nuts, olive oils etc.,)
D. Meditate - daily meditation scientifically proven to be helpful. Just close your eyes and focus on your breath. Don‚Äôt worry about thoughts, they come, they go, you just focus on your breath for 5 mins. 

If you do this, you can counter chronic stress. 

All the best!

author: @shyaaammeneen63
text: Very useful video.  To feel better reduce negative thoughts. Your breathing is closely related to the brain [mind] and gives good relief from stress-anxiety.   To relax sit on a chair or lie down, neck straight,  eyes closed  and observe the sensations of your incoming--outgoing breath at the entrance of the nostrils  for  5-10-15 minutes or more. Don‚Äôt fight your thoughts. With daily practice the mind will relax.  No deep breathing needed. When taking a walk,  at office, in college, when reading, before sleep etc  observe your breath sensations.  Make this a lifetime daily  habit to have a better life. Reduce negative social media  and avoid constipation as it affects the mind instantly. Best wishes--Counsellor.

author: @atriyakoller136
text:
I'm a teacher, and while I largely agree, I'd also say that a 30-hour shift is not innocent when it comes to burning out. Hell, I was dying after an 18-hour day when I only made a break on my way home and played some games for another hour, so, a 2-hour break, because I was literally working all the time, including while eating. Shove a tablespoon of food in - check the tests, edit them, check the ones from the previous class. Woke up at 8 am, started work immediately, worked through the breakfast and morning routine and the commute, did double work while my students were doing the tests by checking for cheating, and checking that everything worked on the platform they were working it, and being a tech support at the same time, lunch, then more classes, commute to the second job, a bit easier there, finished at 10-10:30 pm, came home at 11:30, ate, played games for an hour and worked until 2 am...all to wake up at 6 the next morning üò¢

If you ask why I hadn't done the tests earlier... that's because I didn't have time or energy. While my usual Mondays were about 14 hours, I still lost almost every weekend to work and by that time I worked an 18-hour day it was the fourth week without a weekend

author: @dag1704
text:
Reminds my of my University experience...
Came there with a small imposter syndrome, although I finished my trainees with nearly straight A's. 
In Uni it was different, worked 80h a week,  barely made it through the first semester, then second semester I was so stressed, that directly before the exam phase I completely burned out and failed many exams. Tried to push through the third semester and crashed completely.
I had no enjoyment what so ever in that university although I loved the topic and was super curious, but the University killed that completely...
Its awesome if you have imposter syndrome and life "proves you right" in that feeling :D

I am so happy I left this phase behind... Healing needed 4 years...

author: @fr89k
text: I am an engineer and I work quite a lot. However, last year I tried to ship a prototype to one of our suppliers in the US. The FDA gave me such a hard time, because we didn't have proper certification for the "product". Yes, that is because it's a prototype to show our supplier where he has to improve and give us more support. It's not a product to be sold in the US, at least not yet. That probably just cost me a few hours, but it really drained my energy. It's not a natural problem to be solved. It's a guy at the FDA who says "No" and I have to fight with him to let my package pass through customs. Just annoying. Unnecessarily draining my energy.

author: @LoneWolfMikoto
text:
I got burned out because of my college and had to fight depression for three years now.

They made us work way too much... And I was getting an animator education... I had to spend almost all of my time on bullshit only to get 3/5 grades and survive to graduate... The fun part is I could learn all the things they tried to teach me by giving me tons of work to finish in month by doing one or two things for it.

And animation? Haha! Our teacher was just giving us an assignment and leave for the whole "lesson". It felt like we weren't students, but workers who had to work for nothing.

I am trying to get back to drawing now, but it's just so damn hard to after being abused by your college for three years and yelled at because you and 99% of your classmates couldn't finish all the work on time because it's inhumane.

I damn know what causes burnout...

author: @luxinvictus9018
text:
This is why a lot of artists burnout.

A lot of artists and musicians will work for years without success or acknowledgement or even money because they're hoping for a "big break". And then if it fails or if at some point they lose sight of what they're working towards, their beloved passion becomes a chore. 

This is why artists are encouraged to work on short timelines and not spend like 10 years on a passion project.

Also applies to writers and film makers. Any creative professionals where you don't have a salary but rather are working towards some form of recognition.

author: @cenglish7240
text: I've been experiencing this a lot lately. I put in extreme effort with minimal returns. I work in the world of assessment for disabilities in children and how they impact school functioning. I cannot tell you how disheartening it is to work for 2 months on a case (while juggling daily emergencies and another 20+ cases at the same time) just to be met with anger, distrust, snide comments, witch-hunting behavior, and possible legal action whether I write a 10 page report or a 40 page report about a child's functioning and needs for a caregiver or a colleague. Usually it's because they want some sort of a magic fix that removes the disability, they think there's something being hidden from them (like a magical placement or cure for Dyslexia), or that the findings are just wrong even if it's all based on data and statistical evidence and is corroborated by everyone involved in the assessment process of that child. Then I go home and play games and feel much better and know it's not my fault but I have to go through it on a weekly basis.

author: @Daydreg
text:
The issue with the high intelligence quality and quantity is that it comes with a very unique downside. 

You end up skipping the journey and reaching the goal almost at an incredible speed. Very hard but very quick and exhausting on your level of energy and straining on you body. 

You do it couple of times and people take it for granted ignoring all the ‚Äúsuper efforts‚Äù you do and belittle every achievement due to how easy is for you to do it as ‚Äúeveryone is different‚Äù. 

There is nothing different in how to but is different on how hard or easy or expensive that is for yourself, in what do you need to sacrifice in order to achieve it and who do you need to become in order to get it. 

The satisfaction to get the goal disappears when you assess the situation and the reward comes with nothing compared with how much you loose while getting it.

This makes you become alone and not wishing to engage with people as they are lacking essence that you need. You already know the interactions and what they will get you and you can steer any situation in your favor even if being in the wrong. I always win even when I loose. I never failed and almost never suffered the consequences of my actions due to my ability to always fall on my feet while using and abusing others to reach any goal I set up. 

The harsh reality is that I always chose to go routes that people will never choose and get the slight feeling of being alive out of it, learning something that I can not know, and never understood how stupid people can be and fought hard to become stupid myself in order to experience it. 

I discovered people aren‚Äôt good at either being smart or stupid and they lack in both of these manifestations. It got me on a road where making others do what they don‚Äôt want in order to make them better provided a small amount of satisfaction at the expense of my own life and energy. Thing that lately I stoped doing. It‚Äôs stupid to push others to become better even if that‚Äôs good for them unless a choice they make for themselves. 

It‚Äôs time I stop being stupid and it‚Äôs time to start working towards something worthy for everyone.

So here I am asking for help: please provide me with a worthy goal- a purpose that will help you and others in your similar situation. 

A purpose that will make me use my gifts for the good of everyone. Put that goal/purpose in a reply below after liking the comment and once I reach 100k likes I will work towards the most needed goal to happen from all of the comments. 

It‚Äôs time to take action towards what you want to achieve and I will be glad to help you do that . 

1 goal - from 100k likes and comments- a dream will come through and you will participate towards it. 

Many thanks!

author: @nickcunningham6344
text: For me, I have adhd and tryna get through college, which I like to describe as spending twice as long as I should working on homework with half the motivation of my peers. I'm a computer science major. A programming assignment takes at _least_ 12 hours to complete. And when you spend 2-4 hours trying to figure out a bug or understand the starter code that your professor provided, that causes burnout. When you pull an all-nighter to complete a programming assignment, only to realize you have another due for a different class in three days, and it seems like there's no end to the assignments, that causes burnout. And when you spend hours and hours on every fucking assignment, moreso than your peers, and you _still_ make shitty grades... I'm so done with this bs. But I've already spent too much time and money on this stupid degree. I don't even like programming anymore. I've been burnt out on it for far too long.

author: @Vanity0666
text:
Real as fuck, the system is set up in order to explicitly discourage patients from seeking treatment partially because it is now a legal requirement to purchase health insurance. The ACA did a lot of things right, but it gave so much leverage to the insurance industry to openly deny necessary procedures, medications, and other forms of treatment. Before the ACA it was just as bad though, with the "pre-existing condition" nonsense allowing the medical insurers to not pay out for anything they claimed existed before you had started paying in.

The whole system needs to go and be replaced with a universal single payer that isn't trading blood for profit.

author: @vigen222
text:
Both agree and disagree with the good doctor.
I Think he fails in the fact he doesn't split burnout up into their two main categories. Mental and Physical burnout.
Mental burnout: Which is his example with talking with issurance and his conclussion of working hard and being invested without being compensated sufficiently i think rings true.
But i think he's wrong concerning.
Physical burnout: Which is totally different, if we take the good doctors own example he can be totally satisfied and happy doing a 30hour shift at the hospital with no burnout. Now try doing that 5 times a week for 1-3-6-12 months and at some point your body will crash and burn without you necessarily reaching mental burnout, you can go around and be extremely fulfilled until one day  your body simply collapses.
Alot of succesful, extremely hardworking people have unfortunately fallen for physical burnout, the reason it is so insidious is you almost never see it coming until it's too late.

author: @ThunderMLG

author: @barondavisiscool
text:
As an healthcare/SEND coordinator, I get asked about burnout a lot. If you're passionate and into your job/career then burnout isnt as likely as if you're doing something just to get by.

I LOVE the satisfaction of getting a child with severe needs the right person to work with them, knowing that I'm only called on once all other options are exhausted and there is nothing more fulfilling than working on a child for a month and then speaking to the parents about how well they're getting on now. 7am - 6pm Mon - Fri, 12 - 5pm most Saturdays (I really do enjoy my work. My partner doesn't even mind because I'm tired but not burnt after I finish, and I do still find time for the gym.

Work a job to make ends meet sure, but work on yourself to find yourself in a job that you find fulfilment in. If that means working in the local to make ends meet while you study then do it. The sooner you get that out the way, the sooner you can start living the life you want
