author: @theblasteffect4499
text:
hey Dr K, here's an issue i see.

doctors go through all the college and training, but they dont get enough exprience. i see all the time so many doctors who just dont do their job right. they dont know their patients, they dont listen to them very well, they always think they know better than the patient, etc. psychologists/ psychiatrists too. 

the experience gap is a real issue in the medical field. you do a pretty good job in relating to the community, and overcoming that. youre able to be more than what you went to school for. you're not just a psychologist, not just a doctor.

I'd never imagine a certified psychologist saying the stuff you do lol. you are hip and cool, Dr K.

but i do still see in how you talk about these issues, is you do slightly view them in a way a psychologist might. 

you continuing to be a part of the gaming community, being a youtuber. keep doing this. 

the doctor/patient relationship can only go so far, and there's vastly different environments that reveal different things about people.

keep being one of us. go further into this community.

by being 'one of us', its not just to gain a familiarity with your youtube audience, understanding the patient, or anything else, gain experience and become one of us.

I'm gonna say this right now, im exhausted and im not even typing this out how i want to, and its way too long. idk. just keep going in the community.

experience really is the way to go.

author: @saladslug7432
text:
I went through 3 years of nursing school and 1 year of working in the same hospital I learned at just to burn out and can never work that job again. I was in school from 2018-2021 so I was what they like to call a "covid nurse" because we were right in the middle of all that. 

I was forced to work with violent male patients even though I explained to multiple people that I cannot because of my mental health history, no one cared. 

I was forced to work in the emergency room, Cardiology and Covid ward even though I explained multiple times that I cannot handle those wards. 

After the oncology opened up again higher ups wanted us to work with one nurse and one helper on a whole ward and take care of 10 patients all on our own. In our country a helper isn't even allowed to measure blood sugar levels. 

The whole time our bosses kept having meetings about staff shortage and limiting the amount of patients we were supposed to take but it just got worse after every meeting. 

I was making 21‚Ç¨ an hour which isn't even considered a small amount here but any other basic job can get you the same or more. 

I don't think more reward would've made a difference for me to be absolutely honest. I might've done it for a little longer but I wouldn't have lasted in those wretched working conditions. So I agree to some degree Reward is important to not burn out but if you're working under hellish working conditions nothing is going to stop you from burning out.

text: My work keeps trying to force me to be social.  I can do that one on one with little problem but in a group setting I have always had issues.  Especially in loud environments.  I can‚Äôt hear properly because my brain refuses to focus on one conversation.  It tries to hear them all, so maintaining focus in a group setting is really hard for me.  And those boisterous chatty people who love to hear themselves talk and never shut up are quite intimidating to me so I never feel like I have a chance to contribute to the conversation.  I wind up just standing there pretending to watch and use other people‚Äôs reactions as social cues.  I wish they would just accept that I am meant to be a back office worker and let the extroverts do the communicating with the clients.  I‚Äôm not the person you want out there trying to drum up new business.  The depressing part is when management won‚Äôt listen to these things I already know about myself and just let me be. author: @krystalboothe8311
text: This is such a vital distinction, and I appreciate you bringing it up. Understanding the difference between burnout and depression is key to addressing the right root causes and finding the appropriate path to healing. I work with high-performing leaders who often face burnout and are learning how to recognize these subtle signs early, so they can reset and recover before it leads to deeper emotional struggles like depression.

author: @john1215-j3k
text: I kept wondering if I was depressed. I wasn‚Äôt sad just tired, unmotivated, numb. Turns out, it wasn‚Äôt depression. It was burnout from constant overstimulation. Reset Your Body and Mind by Morgan Lane helped me see the difference and more importantly, heal from it. That 30-day reset brought my energy, sleep, and focus back things I didn‚Äôt even realize I lost. If you‚Äôre not sure what‚Äôs wrong, start with a reset. You‚Äôll feel the shift.

All she wanted to do was play politics. Ended up losing my career because I just finally had to run away. I was at the point that I didn‚Äôt care if I lived or died. In fact, I really wanted to die. So for me it was probably a combination of both. Now, three years later, I live with regret, and nightmares, about having to give up something that i had worked hard to climb too and frankly, I was pretty good at. Had to file retirement for personal financial reasons. Bummer.

author: @kristinekalapos1066
text:
These are good ideas, but unfortunately in the workplace if you can't produce to a certain extent by a certain time you'll beseen as weakening the business and be fired.  I should know - as a person on the autism spectrum whose parents wanted a normal child who could grow up, I've been fired for things like working too slowly over and over again.  I've never seen a work situationwhere the employer has compassion for autistic weaknesses and would be willing to help you implement some of the strategies given - which probably would work if tried. The employer, if your best still is not good enough, will fire you no matter how hard you try and regardless of your circumstances.  The last time I was fired, it was the day before what my employer KNEW was likely my last Thanksgiving with a mother since she was dying of cancer.  
In a way you can't blame the employer.  They may want to tolerate your shortcomings, but they need their business to function well enough to survive in a difficult economy. I think that to get employers to help workers with burnout legal policies protecting such people would be needed.  If they exist, I don't know about them.

author: @nickkswift
text: I AM burnt out. I live alone and spend most of my time alone especially since i got made redundant. My stress was at a severe level during my redundancy but luckily i found a job straightaway. Unfortunately, the job is very very stressful due to amount of workload and unsupportive manager. I was burnt out after having only worked there less than 4 months. I took a week off and finally returned rejuvenated but then it only took 2 days until i started to feel crap again. Thats when i made the decision to leave. I am now working my notice period and i think ive made the right decision to resign. The plan is to move back to my mother‚Äôs house for a few months with my savings until I am ready to work again. look after your mental health folks! You only have one life!

author: @AbdirahmanAliAdan-k3e
text: Thank you doctor,  actually I have been having problems at my job /work as a clinician in a county government, initially I started my job with the county government at a busy referral hospital, I was dedicated and I was loving my job, consultation, patient examination and admiting thro filing medical files ,working at causality and emergency, I was transferred to a remote workplace I enjoyed and served to my best .but from 2018 when I was denied a higher diploma courses study üìñ leave of my dream anesthesia, while my colleagues were allowed to go on with their courses of preference on tribal basis as they have "God fathers " people in government offices who can cover them up and are on a paid study leave , their I develop sense of exclusion due to lack of proper staff performance appraisal , I started my job immediately after my graduation and internship, 2016.some coworkers are released for study leave contrary to the Human resources policy, even some worked less than 1 year are going while I'm ignored despite having applied for and with a valid admission form from my in service course training. As if that isn't enough frequent intentional transfers from facility to facility was my order after having inquired why I'm excluded from previlege and motivational course . Their I develop lack off interest in working ,once best clinician I became the talk of the day and night as absentee ,late coming but otherwise my diagnosis and patient case management remained the best ,some senior doctors in the administration could approach me to work at their private clinics them we disagree with wages and they mark me bad and slightest mistake they serve me with a show cause letter ‚úâ, or even disciplinary measure or even salary stoppages for even a year or 8 months.  I became helpless ,mentally disturbed and some times taken to mental rehab after having developed some drug addiction, khat (catha edulis),I try back working I see my fellow work mate holding higher offices /jobs .I see myself inferior , I have no say in the government as a minority. I have been on antipsychotics ,mood stabilization. I love working but I find coming late or leaving before time due to poor crowd management in an African hospital, overcrowded, no privacy that makes me leave earlier than expected, coming late due to sleep disorder, imay find sleep towards morning, just to arrive late ,then face disciplinary measures harsh ones , being a father of 5 boys and a daughter I feel more depressed some times taking my life or harming those in offices for their irrational, enhumane measures against me despite showing all my mental health records.  I feel better if transferred to other counties hospital where I can establish my self .give me your advice ! author: @Nightlingg
text: I've been searching for videos to try to help me understand what I'm going through. I don't know what it is but it's not really related SPECIFICALLY to working. I feel like I have life burnout. Just sitting is agony because I don't want to be breathing, living, eating, showering, having to think about things. I'm too tired to move, but there's like a deeper exhaustion that also makes me too tired to be still if that makes any sense. Blinking is exhausting. Let alone working. And sense I can't work, or move or clean or shower or do anything for any amount of time, living is hell which makes me feel EVEN more exhausted. I've tried medication ( multiple kinds in the last couple of years) I've tried multiple therapists and psychiatrists. But it only seems to be getting worse. Nothing has helped. I also have not been depression free since I was a child so it just feels like there is no other possible direction to go in then to just lay down and wait for my heart to stop.

author: @fxaman
text: From what I can tell my journey started as a burnout and ended in depression. I always wanted to do more to show my dad his critique was not justified. So I quickly worked myself up to the position of Head of International Marketing. I ended up working 70 hours a week, then going to the gym, then learning languages and some more stuff. Then we took home two dogs from shelter. Then we got two kids in foster care, because we cannot have kids (gay couple). And on top of that my partner got cancer while his mother was dying of cancer. So I had to work 70 hrs a week from home, taking care of kids, taking care of partner, helping with his mom, walking our dogs, taking care of our apartment... I slept 3 hours a day and only lived on caffeine (my breakfast was red bull with coke and a cup of espresso and my diet throughout the day was very similar) until I completely broke. I started crying in the middle of work meetings and eventually I had to quit. Later it got to the point when I was planning to hang myself but I couldn't do it so once my partner got better I started gathering information about assisted suicide. When it got even worse, I finally reached out. So I'm going to therapy, I'm taking antidepressants and medication for anxiety and also melatonin. It's been 4 years since I quit my job and I'm still not functional. Hopefully one day.

author: @Wiiliam_Robinson
text: Distinguishing between burnout and depression is crucial, and Dr. Tonmoy Sharma, a distinguished mental health specialist, author, along with Sovereign Health institution, plays a pivotal role in helping individuals understand and navigate these challenges. Their integrated approach combines evidence-based therapeutic techniques with compassionate care, successfully transforming the lives of many. Testimonies from both employees and patients highlight the profound impact of their services, with individuals expressing gratitude for the guidance they receive. Dr. Tonmoy Sharma's advocacy for mental health awareness further underscores the importance of their efforts. By providing education, tailored treatments, and support, they equip individuals with the tools needed to address burnout and depression effectively, ultimately fostering healthier and happier lives.

author: @Youtuber1045
text: Reached burnout in less than 6 mo at my new job. My solution: stop talking to people, it‚Äôs got everyone confused but it‚Äôs made my job a hell of a lot easier. I‚Äôm not your friend, I‚Äôm not your therapist, I‚Äôm not your buddy, no I won‚Äôt add you on Facebook, no I don‚Äôt want to hang out with you outside of work, no I don‚Äôt want to spend 10 minutes chatting about small talk. After having people shut down my ideas, and then I shut down, and then they only reach out, I learned it‚Äôs easy to simplify my work to a transactional level. I give bare minimum, and do not ask for more- nor do I make my job harder by asking questions. You want this, you want that? Sure, I‚Äôll approve it, not sure what the consequences are but it‚Äôs not like my role is even considered half the time anyways in decision making so oh well. Worst part is I was already depressed before I got burnout and I‚Äôm not sure what is making what worse, but what I do know is I do not even want to hang out with friends and family anymore. I don‚Äôt want to go to the gym, I don‚Äôt want to make plans, I just want to be alone and sleep all day. But I can‚Äôt sleep, because I‚Äôm stressed and burnout. Love it

author: @swaggycow9198
text: I suffer from major burnout since i finished my exams and during those years i drained myself too much i exhausted my self everyday and had a very low self esteem(for personal reasons). Before covid i used to be a maladaptive daydreamer to escape the reality and be happy and didnt have proper guidance at that time cause everyone was dealing with something so the next year i had to become serious to prepare for my exams after covid decreased rapidly and was completely strict and hateful to myself . Somehow i manged to score 86%(which is not good enough at all for the kind of effort i put as i stopped maladaptive daydreaming that year) eventually just before my exams i started slacking off because i was so tired and done and didnt want to put any effort so i couldnt put more effort into my exams. Few days after my exams my college started and i didnt even have the time to properly recover from all that brutal stress i gave my self and even my parents sometimes. So i just get so scared to even read my books during college because i feel so exhausted and fear if ill not score well but end up average and sometimes fail because i procrastinate out of fear and hoplessness and i highly think due to butnout from previous year from which i didnt get a proper break and not end up scoring good. I want to be better and be smart and improve myself but it seems so difficult that i end up daydreaming and dont get anything done. Small things trigger me like if my friends being annoying or my parents ordering me to study. I realize that i have devoloped and ego so bad and i dont want to but i have this constant fear of people pursuing me as meek and the memories of my school year when i felt so judged and introverted so i end up being very defensive right now. And when my parents tell me study i get very mad because it reminds me of how they were last year and its all getting to me. But i dont want to stay like this i want to become so much better. I want to achieve all the goals and standards i have set for myself and get out of this comfort zone of procrastination and maladaptive daydreaming. And become the better version of myself.

author: @annapatton4544
text:
For me the real blessing in disguise was a write up at work. I was working myself like a horse, coming home not being able to talk to my family, not wanting to eat after not having a single bite during the day. Then we had a company's audit that we failed. The departments that I oversee all passed. But 2 depts failed badly and the overall score for the branch was just 2% shy of passing. And every senior manager got written up. Why all 3 of us? The response was - we succeed as a team and fail as a team, everyone is responsible. The worse part was that my direst boss knew about the write ups since Monday, but he waited till my day off on Friday and sent me the write up as an attachment to the email with just 3 letters FYI. He knew I always checked emails from home and was always available. I took it very hard. He did not have the guts to deliver in person. It was the last time I checked work emails from home. And they got into a habit to leave me work that needed to be done on my days off, it used to take me a day to catch up after having 2 days off. Now I have a pile sitting there since September, every single document from the days when I was off. I am not doing it. According to my latest feedback I had, my performance was graded as failed. Why should I keep busting my arse. 
I still do get angry at work, but it got easier to disconnect on my days off at least. And it got easier to not give one from time to time.

author: @Hamdreas
text: I have been pushing myself to be a good worker for so long that it now it has just sunken down to a deep depression. I was assigned 2 projects, working 100% on them, and getting the same pay as my colleagues that only had 1 project. Not only 2 projects, but within both projects I am doing more than my normal QA tasks. I am taking place of a Team leader, floorcoach and trainer. I was experiencing burnout so i talked to my bosses and explained that all of the tasks I have are too much and that I do not have time for all of it, causing me major stress and causing me to work overtime everyday including weekends. I am extremely professional and hate to leave tasks behind, so i kept pushing myself until they find a solution. The solution I asked for was to either just leave me with QA tasks even if it meant having 2 projects or putting me on one project only. I warned them, i did, until now 2 months later, still no action taken, I have gone beyond burnout. I am exhausted and depressed and I dont find joy in anything i do. This is not my normal depressions either, this is deep, this deep whole leaves me with negative and suicidal thoughts everyday. Which worries me a lot, I dont tend to act on it, but the thoughts alone are just excruciating. I have now decided I cant take it any longer. But i am not quitting, I have fought myself to misery and i dont want it to be all for nothing. Ill request my doctor a sick leave, for at least one month. They will suffer without me, but i cant care anymore... They will feel forced to finally give me a solution. Never did they pay me extra for everything that i did, never for an extra hour, or for having 5 jobs at the same time. I earn the exact same as the people scratching their balls do, it feels so unfair, that my mental and physical health was the one paying for it. Guys, please put limits on your work, never do more than you are supposed to, they will use and abuse you, specially if you are good. Dont push yourselves, be careful, mental health is not something to joke or not care about, it will eventually turn to physical problems too. I am now too, weighting 41kg as a 26 y/o woman, for not prioritizing myself.

author: @SanctifiedLady
text:
As a nurse of 25yrs, I was plugging along fine before Covid‚Ä¶after being a hospice nurse 6yrs then Covid‚Ä¶.2020 the death and dying toll was like being in a war with bare hands. Nurses quit leaving only myself and a male nurse to 300 dying patients‚Ä¶I tried to get counseling and a medical leave and was fired‚Ä¶yet they sent me a 10k check. I haven‚Äôt been the same since‚Ä¶I took time off then returned and agreed to a low patient load‚Ä¶in desperation they hired me, they tried to increase the load, increase the distance and work me later and later each day. I resisted and they simply replaced me, that‚Äôs happend twice. The thought of going back makes my body ache. I know it be difficult to find something in my field that doesn‚Äôt exhaust me. Trying to educate ppl on death is like ranking their teeth out and mine too. I‚Äôve worked in most setting of my field‚Ä¶ ppl aren‚Äôt being told the truth about illness and medicine... They are over worked, stressed, eating the processed foods and don‚Äôt believe in death. 

I‚Äôm not sure what I can do‚Ä¶I want to tutor nursing students and do health coaching‚Ä¶I‚Äôve taken tiny steps towards that‚Ä¶

My energy is so limited‚Ä¶thoughts and simple things deplete me.

My immune system tanked causing a second round of Covid then I got shingles which no one in my family ever had‚Ä¶I had an iron strong immune system all these years.

Lord, help us nurses and the rest of the world.

‚úùÔ∏èüôèüèΩüíú

author: @paula.canavezi
text: Earlier this year, I started medical residency. As soon as I noticed the signs of burnout, I told the team that I would need to anticipate my vacation, even if it was only 1 week. The boss denied my request, and went on to say that in the old days, the work was much harder than it is today, and said that he didn't think first-year residents should even take vacations. After 4 months, burnout turned into depression and I gave up on the program, on my dream. Today, I look back and see that just 1 week away from work, just playing Candy Crush in my room, could have prevented months of anhedonia, suicidal thoughts, feelings of worthlessness... I hope that in the near future there will be a greater awareness of burnout.

author: @Anto_81
text: Thanks for confirming what I thought and give a name to how I feel. I developed my first depression very young, after my father's death. Since then, it's been quite easy to fall in the trap again but I've been good at resisting. Then I lost my job in 2016 due to Brexit and I haven't been the same since. I've been struggling with settling again in a role. But Covid was the straw the broke the camels back. After losing my job again during the pandemic, I accepted a job I had never done before and I wasn't qualified for, under the promise of being trained and supported. No training or support was given, and I ended up being bullied for my poor performance..9 months down the line, I'm eaten alive by my anxiety, depressed, fragile and emotionally exhausted. I've been signed off for a month by my doctor, the diagnosis is "reactive anxiety", I believe she actually doesn't even know what burn out is. I'm not going to work now, I feel guilty as if this was just laziness, it wasn't legit and it's my fault if I haven't been able to develop resilience as usual in the past. I think I'll simply resign, hoping to find the strength to be unemployed for a while without going crazy. I don't have a family to support so I guess it's feasible. It's a very delicate balance and it's a wild job market. But ultimately it's not worth it!!

author: @taurus8263
text:
My previous work caused me depression that I never experienced before in my life.
 I lost a will to live, to do anything, I was just a slave of my work, my life. I hated the fact that you have to still live because I didn't see any purpose and sense in it. 
This was caused by working extreme amount of hours, normally 10,11 but sometimes 15 hours a day. It was also caused by complete lack of support from my employer , rather opposite as my workplace culture actually demanded people to work crazy hours (as my boss once asked me ' soo.. you don't work at night but you could'). This should give you rough idea.
Finally by complete accident I changed the departments and now I couldn't be more happy. My free time came back and my will to live with it. I actually even enjoy my life again which I already thought is not possible anymore.
Now whenever I remember those grim and sad times, it brings chills down my spine and anxiety. After 3 months I still feel exhausted, like I really needed a year off to get back to normal, previous me.

author: @treemarie3080
text: I feel like burnout can also be attributed to major life events like moving to different countries. For example, having parents in the military and moving every 2-3 years, especially in the younger years, adds an unnecessary element of disconnect, mental and emotional exhaustion, as well as other "symptoms" of burnout. I mention this because this is my story - although I thought having a career that allowed me to continue to travel the world would be beneficial, it wasn't until I was hit with severe burnout, depression and anxiety that I realized the burnout symptoms started long before I had even sacrificed my personal life for my career. I personally believe there's a deeper root cause to burnout than just work stress.

author: @viktorlionheart2690
text:
I've been burned out for years.  There are multiple people in my life with crippling depression or other severe mental health struggles,  and I am pretty much they only person the can ever go to for help.  Of course, I want to help them. I want them to be happy. But it's been over 10 years of constantly hopping from one crisis to another and NEVER getting a break.  I can't even feel empathy any more. I can barely feel anything at all.  I feel like I'm never allowed to be upset or to take a break because I have to be constantly strong for everyone else, and I'm just so tired that I want to leave everyone in y life and just disappear for a year.

Burnout, especially long term burnout, is soul destroying

author: @djkleb7645
text:
Depression is an state of the mind where brain is just focusing on a big problem, you can be at a wedding, in a party, funeral, alone or whatever, and your brain will be remembering you about that simple problem.

Burnout is an state of the mind where the brain focus on everything that need to be done for a long period of time, and the moment you take a break the brain just remember everything that needs to be done and drains your mental or physical energy.

Either way Burnout and Depression, leads to inefficiency.

P.D.: I have gone through Depression and overcome it, but I'm in a huge Burnout stage, if someone has gone through long burnout stages and overcome it, tips will be appreciated. Thank You!

author: @Joraya.
text:
"Well, I have to work", yeah, I felt that down to my bones. 
To be honest, I'm not sure if I'm severely burnt out or maybe feeling depressed. I'm just tired, and I mean that literally. I can sleep 10 hours and still be dead tired the next day. When I do have a two week vacation, I tend to - and that is no joke - sleep away the first week, to maybe get things done in the second one, just to find myself shutting out the world (and all the people in it) and to very likely watch movies or read books for the entire second week, without actually getting things done. When people message me it can take upt to a month or sometimes months for me to find the energy to reply. 
As said in the video, it seems really hard to tell apart depression from a burn out, and for me a lot of the issues on both sides fit. And it's not even that I am unhappy or feeling down all the time. I's just this bone deep tiredness that makes me shut out everyone and everything, that may require of me to take action or cope with other people's issues/emotions. And normally after a great/happy time/day, I tend to shut myself away to "balance" it out, so to speak. Probably sounds weird written down like this. 
I mean, in my head I know it, but still I need to ask, is that something that I should see a therapist about? Or might a change of job or a longer medical leave help?

author: @catstickler
text:
Plot twist: My depression led to total life burnout. 

When I struggle to get out of bed and do the things I need to do, combined with the utter lack of self-esteem and sense of anything, it compounds the burnout and I'm less functional when depressed. 

I'm mostly burned out with being a single mom. I'm fortunate enough when I got burned out by freelancing, I was able to dissolve the business and create a new one that supported my mental health and energy levels better. 

If someone puts me on a resort island, I'd probably just have a succession of panic attacks, unless I was allowed to work. üòÖ Work has become a coping mechanism to stuff away the depression and impending sense of doom.

author: @captainwalker
text:
Great video presentation! Burnout can be on the way to depression. Dr Marks differentiates the two very well. The big issue of course is whether workers need to be on the slippery slope into depression. Some may not know but mental disorders (such as clinical depression) robs people of life expectancy. So if you were supposed to live to 85, you could get 10 years less. 

Workers need to ask themselves serious questions if they score highly one one or more of the three domains of the Maslach. I suggest the following:
1 - Is it me or is my organisation doing this to me? 
2 - Are other people around me burnt out and suffering with other work-precipitated mental disorders (e.g. anxiety disorders, depression, substance misuse disorders)? 
3 - Why have I got to this point? 
4 - How long has all this been going on?
5 - Why have they not fixed the system after so long (because burnout doesn't just develop overnight)? 
6 - How likely are they to fix workplace issues in the next 6 months? 
7 - Should I hold on in this job for 6 or more months? 
8 - I'm not clinically depressed now but what if succumb and develop clinical depression? What would that mean? 
9 - Should I allow myself to be made ill on the job?
10- What should I do next? 

Obviously - I can't answer those questions for each person. Nor can I advise what to do next. But just asking oneself the questions and being honest - is better than not.

author: @Askarvi
text: This is good! In Sweden we have a more in depth diagnosis for burnout called Exhaustion syndrome. It has three phases. Prodromal phase where you start to have symptoms, acute phase where you usually fall very ill. Then the Rehabilitation phase, which focuses on returning to normal function. It is a chronic condition and there isn‚Äôt a cure, the rehabilitation focuses on helping the patient cope and manage their symptoms.

thank you for making me feel valid :( people at work just keep telling me i'm feeling what i feel because i'm a "spoiled rotten brat".. even after working hours and hours overtime regardless of whether it's weekdays, weekends, or holiday without any recognition and incentives. but maybe i am. idk.

edit: i was never able to take a leave because i would literally be scrutinized if i did, people talking behind my back, and if i -for some reason- get the virus during my leave (like literally just a leave to not work but still stay at home), instead of a "get well soon", i would get a "we don't cover your medicals because you got it during leave". i got typhoid fever twice in a year, and still worked normal hours from home during both. my medical bills weren't covered too that time because i was only a contract employee.
in the end, i did finally hand in that resignation letter. but instead of realizing what they did to me, i got showered with "you're ungrateful, people would kill to have a job". which, honestly, got to me.

"Are these really my kids?" "Who is this man in my house?" Getting stranger danger feelings from people I know - close relationships with. Recently forgetfulness and clumsiness is on the rise. Stumble frequently in shower, drop things, spilled a cup of coffee on myself just sitting and holding it in my hand unmoving- put car in drive instead of reverse - run into curbs - almost backed up and ran over someone a couple weeks ago. I feel like just laying on the floor /road and waiting for the end - exhausted, drained, hopeless, helpless. I don't know. I'm forgetful, easily overwhelmed, can't focus, avoident, depression,  anxiety, nothing is real - I'm really sleeping right now and I can't wake up - go to bed and wake up 2 seconds later it's morning and feel like I haven't slept. I dont want to live like this anymore. I honestly feel like there's something hugely wrong with me. I can't read things sometimes, it's like my brain picks up all the letters words and shuffles them until it's gibberish. 7 word sentence I read first 3 words and by the 4th I've forgotten what the first 3 were. author: @getworsetaste
text:
This is a very good video. But i think the language behind burnout is too focused on jobs, and work. Burnout can happen in non-workplace situations. Like in a demanding relationship or in school. There is also the phenomenon of autistic people getting burnout from masking their more obvious symptoms like stimming and forcing themselves to make eye contact. 

again, very good video. But I think by focusing on work alone, some people with burnout may walk away thinking they aren't, and therefore not help themselves in the ways they need.

I started to work on my time management and not answering peoples messages and calls immediately. I started telling myself that nothing is burning, nobody's life is in danger, I don't have to answer messages right now. And the main thing is that nothing is more important than my mental health! 
Now I am working better, with much less mistakes, and with not feeling burnout.

author: @lgood4970
text: HAH. My therapist says I'm depressed and meed meds. They can't prescribe meds.  My doctor says I'm not depressed, just stressed and i don't need meds.   I am burned out at my job after 19 years. It is a  high stress job which requires me to work against many of my natural inclinations.  So, I've also went back to grad school to get a degree in another area so I can be qualified to do something else.  Here is the problem...I am so down the rabbit hole of negative thoughts and misery...I find it hard to move on.  I hate my job...but won't I hate the new one too?  I am a 'different' sort of person so the idea of having to meet a building of new people gives me hives.  I tend to be overly anxious on top of it.   So am I depressed?  Yes.  Am i burned out?  Yes.  I think I may be both.  I find it hard to go on vacation...and when I go I do feel relief to be away from my job---but I ruin the trip because I worry about how work is backing up while I'm gone, is the dog sitter taking care of the dog,  will the car break down on the drive home,  am going to put myself in debt for going on this trip---and so on.

author: @sw-hg8eq
text:
For years, I can hardly function, every inch of my body hurts, I feel like a 70-year old woman when I am 30. I did so many check-ups in the early years but nothing was found. My life feels like a hell with all this pain. I am not sure if that is depression or burnout because inside I am not gloomy, I have so many life-goals that excite me but I don't have physical strength anymore, even typing this on tablets hurt my joints.

Well, listening to the island example, yes, I would love love if someone would do all the organization and planning for me, I would be so happy relaxing only. I am really tired of doing everything alone and having responsibilities.
And yes, I wasn't depressed in the early stages of this, it came later because I felt trapped in this problem and everything I did to get healthier didn't help and doctors didn't take me seriously, I cried and cried and felt alone. When my doctor did the check-ups, couldn't find anything and told me, "it seems like it's all in your head," I broke out into tears and told him, "you can't do this to me, you can't let me hang like this," he didn't care. It was slap into my face and I gave up hope after wasting so much money.

author: @Tatmanm
text: I‚Äôve experienced all this, and initially tried anti depressants to cope with remaining in my career, but the side effects made things even worse, such as a lot of weight gain and high blood pressure. I found that I was still anxious and depressed because the root of the problem wasn‚Äôt gone. After getting therapy for 3 years and still suffering, I started Transcendental Meditation which has finally stopped my panic attack that has been ongoing for years. Practicing saying ‚Äúwhatever it doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äù to intrusive thoughts for 40 minutes each day helps to train the brain to let go of upsetting thoughts the rest of the time. Medication is a band aid and not a solution. If you want to improve depression and anxiety for real, you have to make actual life changes as you say in the video. I appreciate talking therapy and cbt still, but it never really addressed my fight or flight response until I started practicing TM. Thank you üòä

author: @debblackburn4025
text: Burnout is not an employee weakness. It is different than a poor fit between employees and employer.   Temporary changes at a normally healthy workplace can expose strong employees to the point that they become burned out.  Covid has certainly stretched a number of businesses and employees to the point of burnout.  In temporary situations an employee can take a vacation or a release from a medical professional.  It can also be due to a toxic workplace. Workplaces can be rehabed too.

author: @WomanRoaring
text: I was burnt out from a job I had. I worked there for 8 years. It got toxic when my boss hired another employee (small office) she created more work for me. when I talked to him about it and he recognized the issues but wouldn't do anything about them. This caused me so much stress. I already struggled with depression and trying to not go back on meds. I would go to the gym after work and then go home and lay in bed until I passed out. I didn't sleep well and would wake up and still feel like I needed to sleep more even though I got like 8hrs if not more of sleep. I started looking for another job but wasn't finding one for over a year. After leaving that job it took me 2 years to feel better. Things in my personal life were going so much better than before so I was feeling great on the weekends but at work, the dread of being overworked and feeling frustrated and not appreciated was making me angry on top of feeling depressed at work. The work itself was fine, I loved what I did (I'm a designer) but my boss kept taking away things I loved doing and giving me responsibilities I hated doing and I told him that but he didn't want to do the things he was giving me and I was the employee so I had to do them, then having to always fix my coworkers work was so frustrating too. Things weren't like that before her and for some reason my boss let her walk all over him. She was older than us and he said, well I was raised to respect my elders (she was our parent's age) I said, ya me too but you're still the boss, you're in charge, not her. He just never put his foot down with her, I suggested he give her her own work to fix and he would on occasion but most of the time he'd just give it to me and I already had enough to do on a regular basis. She was slower at doing things so he was like, just fix it, I need it fast. This constant interruption made it hard to do my job, I had to mentally flip between things all the time and I would lose the image in my head I was trying to create and for an artist, this is the worst thing you can do to them. You can't always get the image back and then what you create turns out differently than you originally imagined it, oh so frustrating. He wasn't an artist so he didn't get that. The technical stuff he did in the office was something you could put down and pick up anytime but our work wasn't like that. His interrupting me to fix her stuff made me more inefficient and frustrated. Anyway, ya 2 years to recover from my burnout feeling. I had been in toxic work environments before this job but I never felt burnt out, it didn't affect how I felt on the weekends or at night but this job did. The only reason I felt ok the last year I was there was that I met my husband and we'd spend weekends together since we lived an hour away and traffic in our area was horrendous (bay area)...he kept me sain for that year but after leaving I can't believe how long it took for me to feel like myself again.

author: @GAMAYUNIEL
text:
This really enlightened me, it explained so much. I tend to burn myself out with art commissions and it really does feel like depression because I've been drawing my whole life and not drawing makes me feel so empty inside. But when I take a break and play video games or get into a new tv series I feel so much better, just guilty that I'm not drawing. So then I feel like I need to force myself and then the burnout drags on. Now I understand that I have to find a better balance when it comes to freelance work with my art. This only started happening when I was able to support myself financially with my artwork so maybe commissions are just not a fit for me, and my art is more of a personal thing.

Also the time boundary thing is so important. Some people really will message you all day. It's always good to establish your boundaries, especially if you set your own schedule.

author: @augustaseptemberova5664
text:
Hello Dr. Tracey, I have a suggestion for a follow-up video, if you feel like it: autistic burnout. I have received my autism diagnosis not long ago, and have been reading/watching a lot of online content on that topic. One aspect particularly resonated with me: autistic burnout, as I feel the "burnout+depression" diagnosis I received a few years back was an autistic burnout, as described in some youtube videos. However, with online content, I'm always asking myself: Is this a real thing? As in: Are the observations and the advice given there scientifically sound and statistically speaking helpful, or are they hear-say, anecdotal and circumstantial?

I have great trust in your content, as it is very similar to the psycho-education I received after my burnout. So I would very much appreciate your explanation of autistic burnout (if it is a thing) and possibly: coping mechanisms.

author: @soundslike1life
text:
First time I have seen your videos, and really like how you present things, so looking forward to watching more. 

I'm definitely depressed but burnout has also been a factor in getting there, as there has been a big conflict between my personality and the type of work I needed to do, ventured there due to no jobs on my own field and then, got stuck there. I've had a hellish few years with my health: exposure to toxins in an ill office building that started an army of symptoms that took years to get over and it all started eating my endurance under pressure/stress... then several people dying, 11 relationship ending suddenly, my dog dying, then another abusive relationship with a narcissist who completely destroyed me by gaslighting and future-faking and traumatizing me to a point that all my childhood trauma resurfaced and I fell into depression. I wanted nothing more than to just die. But I got into therapy instead. I am still very much in recovery, especially because when I was somehow ready to enter normal life again, covid-19 happened and I was thrown back into isolation, after already being in self-isolation for couple years due to depression... all of this reduced me to a mere pale reflection of who I am. I lost all my immense creativity and drive, I still feel constant fatigue. I barely recognize myself and I need to rebuild my life bit by bit, but it's been an uphill battle with all these things coming at me all the time. I just feel like I can get no break whatsoever. As a cherry on the cake few months ago my spinal disc bulged out into the spinal canal and I've been in pain and on the verge of losing function on my leg... dreadful pain for several months but the leg is fine now... but I may still end up on an operating table because things are very unstable... So yea. I had burnout, at the very beginning. But now it has been full-on depression for years. During the burnout, at the very beginning, in addition to burnout symptoms I also had physical symptoms that indicate I was already close to depression (stomach issues, feeling very anxious about even going back to work etc, followed by irregular sleeping patterns and constant fatigue). Even my thyroid went nuts due to the exposure to toxins at the work place, permanent sinus damage, three new allergies. It was hell even before I fell into depression but depression is so much worse... you just lose your will to live. I prayed in my bed at night that there would be a pill that I could swallow that would just end it all. I consider it a miracle that I am still here.

author: @jenniferstone2567
text:
I've been feeling a general 'why should I bother? Who really cares?' sporadically over the past few years but recently, it's been almost constant. Covid isolation hasn't helped, as it's been hard to get out of the house.
My husband has some serious health issues, that mean he can't help out around the house or do any day-to-day errands on any regular basis. This means I have to do them, or they don't get done; everything from paying bills to grocery shopping to arranging his appointments and prescriptions, everything seems to be 'my job'. My only respite is an hour's walk everyday, where I mostly sit on a bench and get some fresh air.
Add to this a sense of 'my life is going nowhere'. Husband and I have been unemployed for a long time, like 13 years. And while he seems happy to sit on his backside, I'm itching to do things. He says I can get work anytime, but he doesn't see the barriers that I do. 
He's been telling me 'we'll move home next year.' for about 5 years, nothing ever happens. My entire life has ground to a halt, it feels like there's nothing I can do about it. We've never been on a proper holiday, not even on honeymoon (been married 9 years).
I'm bored, frustrated, burned out and burdened upon. My husband's complacency just seems to make me feel worse.
Apologies for the long comment/rant. Guess this needed to come out of me.

author: @sachinp2165
text:
I faced a total burnout in 2015-16 and I am still recovering from it. I see many people in comments section don't really understand what a Burnout actually is. They feel being tired or unhappy or unmotivated in their job means 'burnout'. Some saying they did some lifestyle changes and burnout disappeared in a few weeks. If it disappeared in few weeks- it wasn't a Burnout.
Burnout is a beast that grips the very core of your self - physical as well as mental. It's a massive task to over come Burnout. It takes years and often you may not heal completely.

text:

But if I make a list of everything that I love, I can never have any of it, 0%, every door is locked, every path is blocked & the answer is always NO! And as soon as people around me find out what I want or which direction I want to go in, they'll work against me & actively push me in the opposite direction. They love it when I'm miserable. It brings them great joy when they see me fail. 

  That's my life, that's all I've known since 1990. Everything changed in 1990. I had a pretty normal life before 1990. Being trapped in that lifestyle will seriously fuck you up mentally, emotionally & physically. And I have no idea how to break out of it.

author: @waggypup99
text: I had a horrible boss that worked for.  I put up with this person for years. I had a supply of Ambien that I refused to take. Until late at 3:00 pm on Friday I  went to HR and quit.  I went on the sneaks and cleaned my desk the night before and lined up another job but couldn‚Äôt decide as I had been working with great people and had a pension. My boss wasn‚Äôt there when I left.  It was a relief. On Monday, people called saying things were falling apart. My boss was running around reassigning my tasks and looking for call logs. I was very fortunate to have a friend in a higher place who said I can get you in my company starting on Monday, so you can rest easy. I got a 20% raise and haven‚Äôt looked back. People out there, don‚Äôt put up with unappreciative bully bosses. Make some calls and get out.

I am financially able to cut hours and still pay my bills.  Do you think that might help?  I have approached my boss about it, but was told we do not have enough staff to cover (healthcare) so I need to know if this really would help, because if it will, I plan to tell them, rather than ask.  And if the answer is no again, I plan to quit.

I‚Äôm academically burnt out because I‚Äôve recently decided to change my major and transfer schools mid semester and now I feel like the classes I‚Äôm taking are pointless! On top of that my job is a slow drag. I‚Äôm confined to one area up to 12 hours a day with one person and it‚Äôs beginning to get the better of me. My sleep schedule is horrible, my eating habits are poor and the mental exhaustion is so real that I‚Äôm not even enjoying my life or my youth anymore. author: @DashaTheDivineDivah
text: I'm hella burnt out right now. As someone who has dealt with anxiety and depression in the recent past I was really concerned about possibly falling back into depression. But I had inkling that it was more of a burnout.  I reached the cynical phase with my job back in November when I almost booked a lead on a major network show which of course fell through. I've been in the industry for 15 years and it is highly stressful at times. On top of that with the pandemic and being on unemployment I am constantly stressed about whether or not I am going to be able to afford to pay rent, buy food or basics for myself. And in January I cut off a frenship of 26 years that had turned out to be very emotionally draining and toxic for me but I feel as if I am grieving all these things as well. So it would be really interesting to know if it's possible to have multiple things trigger these burnouts. I am just grateful that it's happening now during the pandemic when I am forced not to work as opposed to me having to go in perform for people all the time while I'm feeling drained. After watching this I feel pretty confident in knowing that I am simply burnt out and not depressed. I love these videos thank you

author: @christyevershappily4eversafter
text: What do you do when your burned lot from your family and have taken steps to manage burn out but it‚Äôs just not enough.  For example I got a week away from my family and it was wonderful.  On my drive home I felt the exhaustion and dread coming back. I ended up getting a flat tire On my drive home.  I was actually happy about the flat tire because it gave me an excuse to get a hotel room for another night so I could stay away just a little while longer.  When I did get back home the exhaustion and burnout were as if I had never left.  My husband has been helping with taking over dinner. And other things like that.  He‚Äôs helping but we do have past issues that I‚Äôm having trouble getting over. And the burn out from other areas of family life are still too much. I have 3 teenagers all with major problems  and am the only one to be there for my aging mom who refuses to hire help. I‚Äôve had a lot of losses and negative  life changing experience over the last 20 years on top of that.  I‚Äôve reached a point of life burn out.  I can‚Äôt abandon my  family and I can‚Äôt keep putting things and responsibilities on my family members.  I truly feel stuck.  I don‚Äôt have the money or good enough insurance to afford therapy.    The only thing that makes me feel better is being away from my family and yet I love them and can‚Äôt abandon them. I have a travel business and getting away for my business is the only escape I have to make me feel happy.

author: @ilovemybeard3394
text:
I don‚Äôt suffer from depression, but I will tell you what real burnout feels like when you work at a high stress job or in other words a toxic work culture

‚Äî You want to clean your room, but your body tells you no

‚Äî Your car has trash, and you say ‚Äúhmmm‚Äù I will do it later

‚Äî You have conversations with yourself, and you are your own therapist when you feel detached

‚ÄîYou start to think people don‚Äôt like you and isolate yourself

‚Äî Your body becomes real heavy and all you can think of is sleeping, but you start to have pounding headaches

‚Äî You start to watch motivational videos and you‚Äôre like ‚Äú Yeah!!! I‚Äôm going to do that‚Äù  but you don‚Äôt 

‚Äî Energy drinks or Coffee is top priority and lots of it...LOL  but? There is a cost when it wears off by the end of the day

‚Äî You cry when you feel everything is hopeless üò≠üò≠üò≠ because the cycle continues 

‚ÄîYou start to think in your mind on how to make more income and get out of the toxic work culture,  but you can‚Äôt right now because you have to have a backup plan



There is more, but hang in there guys...a high stress job has its benefits üí∞ 

But your health is more important than money any day...I know it sucks and I have been there

take care guys and hang in there

author: @hastalavistabunny969
text:
Thank you so much. I've been doing school and work fort the past few month. Studying a subject I don't care for and working a full-time job that I don't care for, to pay to study this subject that I don't care for. 
I'm a creative, but my mother convinced me that business was a good carrier choice. I knew from the start that I didn't want to do business, I don't see myself doing any of that once I graduate. I just thought I can get the degree, make my mom happy and then do what I  wanna do.
Now though, I feel myself spiraling more and more into hopelessness and dread. I've lost any and all motivation to do anything. I can't eat without overeating (I don't think I've ever been fatter), but then sometimes I don't wanna eat at all. I can't sleep most nights either (I can maybe sleep for one or two hours, but that's it), but then sometimes I can sleep half the day away.
I knew this wasn't depression. I've had depression on and off for most off my life, so I knew I wasn't feeling that. Then I started looking for psychologists in my area and came across an article detailing the effects of burn-out, which lined up with what I was experiencing.
Thank you for the insight. I think I need to have a talk with my mom and maybe visit a doctor.

author: @max.cr33p
text: Well the thing is I CAN'T QUIT MY JOB BECAUSE IM A 15 YEAR OLD GIRL AND MY JOB IS SCHOOL!!! EVERYDAY IS THE SAME. Wake up at 7:30. Lay in bed for 30 minutes trying my hardest to wake up. Join the class meeting at 8:00. Maybe it's an easy day, it's just a short quiz and I get to log off 15 minutes early. Maybe it's a hard day. I have to turn my camera on. I have bad camera/social anxiety so this is probably the worst thing. I'm shaking thinking about it. A hard day, I have more work. Maybe 2-3 quizzes. A hard day goes on until 9:30, where I immediately have to join the next class meeting. I haven't been doing my work in that class. I get on my phone, I can't bring myself to engage with the class. At 11:00, I get a 30 minute break, but it feels like nothing. At this point in the day, I haven't ate yet. I still don't have time to eat, so I have to go through my 3rd class hungry. Maybe it's an easy day and I just have to log on and listen to the teacher, maybe it's a hard day and I have 2-3 quizzes. Then the last class. The worst class for me. At 1:30, I go to Spanish class. I can't bother to try and understand another language. My brain is fried at that point. I feel awful. I try not to cry for 1 hour and 30 minutes, and at 3:00 I close the laptop. Maybe I'll get some food now, or later before I go to bed. I watch videos on my phone. I play some games. I go to bed. Then it starts all over again. Everyday. The weekends hardly give me a break. I spend my Saturday thinking about how I'm wasting time and my break doing nothing. Sunday is spent dreading Monday. And the cycle starts over.

author: @alexadellastella5247
text: As an asperger woman, i've lived with depression most of my life without any professional diagnosing it and lately i've had burn out and doctors nor psychiatrists diagnosed it! i'm very disappointed by the lack of professionalism with the psychistrists i've seen.... I'm the one who had to auto analyse and diagnose myself then find the right specialist on the subject, take many tests and then i finally got seen and have been diagnosed asperger with depression and burn out by a psychiatrist a month ago (i'm 38 years old ! and searched for help for years!).... there's been a serious lack of depth in the questions i was asked by the different psychiatrists, it was always superficial and since i'm also hyper-functioning with high IQ and had hyper functioning depression, i went under the radar for so long yet suffered with also suicidal ideas..... the bravest you are, the less professionals take you into account sadly. Why are you trained to see the obvious??? it's really something i keep wondering cos it's very damaging for many patients..... I naively thought that you were a detective of people's mind... Doctors don't listen or question with depth (at least the different ones i've seen). And by what I have read on forums, i'm sadly not the exception among people who are neurodivergent, it has to change! thanks for your video anyway, it was interesting.

author: @KamiltheCamel
text: I had a question. What if anything burns you out? I match a lot of burnout in that if I can relax and do whatever I want I feel okay and I am able to relax, but then the second school starts back up I feel burned out in a matter of weeks or sometimes days. Also, it isn't just school. It is like if I have to do anything in my life and I can't just relax and do nothing, I start to get stressed and anxious and burnout. This is where I start to feel a more general hopelessness as if no matter what I do, I can never be content. I am always just going to suffer unless I am able to remove responsibility from my life which isn't possible. I am also in the process of getting diagnosed with ADHD, so maybe it has something to do with that, but idk. It is hard to figure out what's going on in my brain when different things match parts of different disorders, but nothing perfectly.

author: @JanacMeena
text:
* People can hold up well against stress if they are getting satisfaction from their work
* The way to reduce burnout is to either change the environment or the individual
* To cope with the work setting, set time boundaries. Don't be infinitely available.
* Prioritize sleep
* Exercise
* Meditation. Headspace. 

* Consider changing companies or jobs

author: @BKLNHobo
text: Thank you for this.  I was starting to feel crippling burnout earlier in the year (a mix of a long commute and a toxic and isolated office environment) to the point where I would consistently oversleep, and feel like I had to physically drag myself to work each day.   I was trying to figure out how to address it with my employer by advocating for a partial remote schedule when the pandemic hit.  Once allowed to work from home full-time due to the shelter-in-place mandates, my overall mood and attitude to my work improved significantly.  Now forced to return to the office, my anxiety levels are suddenly back up, and I'm having mood swings, episodes of sleepless and diarrhea, plus brain fog on the days I have to go in.  It's becoming pretty clear that a minor adjustment in my schedule isn't going to fix this, and I need to find a long-term solution in the form another job.

Symptoms, typical for depression only:
Agedonia - nothing pleases you anymore, you enjoy nothing.
Psychomotor and cognitive retardation - you are unable to comprehend information and make desicions with a  speed you used to.
Rumination - constanly chewing over  all negative events from your past.
In some cases, ruminations can transform itself into psychotic symptoms, like verval hallucinations, related to your rumination themes...

author: @DemetriosMPapadakes
text: Everyone and their monkeyass is "depressed" or "burned out". These are the most overdiagnosed conditions of the western world. There are people who don't have any food to eat and they aren't depressed or burned out. The entire narrative is that you are the problem, because you can't change your work environment. The truth is we're "treating" people instead of society and the culture of work itself. Humans aren't made to live in the societies we've created and their organizational structures. That's where all the work of psychologists and sociologists should be focused, not the individual. Socioeconomic activity needs an overhaul. It's NORMAL to be fucking depressed and burned out from doing bullshit, meaningless work.

author: @gwenscott206
text:
Hi
I have a question.
Let me just fill you in a bit.
I have BPD PTSD, OCD, ADHD DYSLEXIA + ASD
my life has been upside down for years, 2013 to now has been the worst but since June 2018 i have been moving from place to place it is now almost April 2019.
I found a place/room for rent its 95% private.
The lady i rent from has BPD as well with a bit of  Schizophrenia and multiple personalities
(Im guessing, its just obvious)
I'm ok if I'm left alone and that's what i want bcuz I have many irons in the fire, im trying to get a lot of things done that are time sensitive, & all are due at the same time and more keeps pilling on. I have not had time to be depressed, so i feel awful & zone out alot, that is waisting time.
I do have meltdowns due to too much going on & is so overwhelming but i have to keep going.
Well i feel I have burnout, im getting headaches, im tired, i can't sleep good up on & off even with xanax. I dont eat right, i cant think, My financial situation has changed along with just moving here. Her rules changed so its like living with my mother, that's where the PTSD come in play.
There is more but let me get to my question.
Because I have burnout & want to be left alone, just stay in my room and sleep because i have that going on, the lady i rent from says that I'm effecting her bipolar & I'm making her feel bad...
Could that be?
And
How can that be?
I need help & your advice would be great.
Thanks for listening.

author: @khaledtaleb7191
text:
Hi Dr.Tracey, am really confused about my status and hadn't any an accepted explanation until this moment. Ok, when I was 11 y/o, my father died and we moved from a country to another .. a New life, new place and new society .. Everything and my whole life changed within few days .. Years go and go even with my bad feeling - I can't describe it but I only can say that I have it, in every part of second in my day and we only separate when am sleeping , otherwise it is with me every time and every where  - but I was coping well because I was thinking that it is with everyone and it is normal -. However,  year by year I became recognized and understand that there is something abnormal and am differ from others and I started be more aware about the changes of my mood pattern and compare myself to others

 Even though, I didn't seek for any medical or psychological or even family attention .. Then, I became medical student and started looking for any corresponding for my symptoms to any medical or psychological diseases .. I spent two years doing that , then I had a severe depressive attack that pushed me to meet a psychologist.. Whatever, I diagnosed with a moderate PDD - dysthymia - two years ago, I didn't remember when was the last time that I wasn't have this feeling. But am sure that it is more than 8-9 years and could be more longer. ( I can't remember anything about my childhood before I lost my father, I don't know if I was like now, or just everything started after him). I didn't become better with the CBT and I avoid starting the medications. 



Today am 23 y/o and upon my memories I can say that , I spent 18-17 years feel like there is nothing real in this life, I doing things just because I have to do it , and I do it just to try to convince myself that I feel it. Couldn't have any emotions with anything, no sadness no happiness no hoping, just nothing and nothing , just feel like emptiness. 

Going in this life with mind only and without anything else. It doesn't matter if life ends now or at the end of the day or tomorrow, not waiting for anything. This was a detailed history about my background so you can imagine and realised my situation.



My question is do you ever see a case like this, do you have any DDx and Could I have another psychological illness combined in the same time with persistent depressive disorder ? I hope you answer these questions in a video, it will be better .. Finally, Thank you ‚ô•Ô∏è

author: @mariajessicasusilo5162
text:
This just kind of open up my mind to what it is like in othee countries, their struggles and all, esp the very expensive rent. 

I honestly dk what to say as someone who works 1 full-time job and 5 other freelances... well, I come from a SEA country where the full-time work is never 40hrs, at least it'd be 45hrs/w , usually 50-60hrs/w on full-time only, which I know could be unhealthy. So 40hrs/w sounds like a dream to us coming from this type of culture, but seeing the people that lives in different system struggles that much might mean something is wrong with the system as they have to really work so hard just to have a decent living.

For anyone wondering, I am a Gen Z, yes, a sandwiched Gen Z (surprise) born in the 2000, I work in retail fashion head office, and do graphic design, fashion styling, makeup, tattoos, and social media marketing both freelance and my own property rent. On weekdays I woke up at 5 & do house chores & get ready, leave at 8, work from 9 to 7/8ish, back home at 9ish. Start my side jobs at 10ish usually, finish at 12-1... and the offline side jobs I do on the weekends (as usual, starting and ending the day with house chores and workouts). I def wont do all the jobs all day, I will always have designated time for all of them, some I def can do remotely. But yea things are manageable here, BUT AGAIN, we are raised this way, it's been this way ever since us SEA people were very young...

author: @SoffyHoffers
text:
People heard "entitled" and seemed to have been a wee triggered, looking at some of the comments. üòÖ What I heard from this video is that yes, things suck, it's the world we live in right now. Dr K used "entitled" in that that's what boomers will say about this generation, what some of the reaction probably was to the video he had shown. He's saying we're called "entitled" because we were told the lie "just work a little harder and things will work out," that all we needed to do was find some job and be loyal to that company and we'd see raises and promotions. So we were lied to, and when we say, "this isn't what I expected," we're called entitled.

Short way of saying it, this is what you can say to a boomer if they call you entitled, that it's because they lied to you.

author: @Salmiak
text: 15:30 I am a Millennial with parents born in the early sixties. I don't think they were lazy necessarily, but I think that the baseline of effort has shifted to a ridiculously high expectation. So their effort was a "normal", liveable effort, while our generation has to do SO MUCH all at once, just to keep our jobs - let alone stand out. An example: I work in education in Europe, and having worker's rights is already so much more alleviating than the American system, yet I am tired too. In the 1970s/80s, you could get away with just teaching from one book as a teacher - now you have to use all the digital products available, be aware of MUCH more things like differentiation, and come up with more activities in your free time. I'm happy that education is transforming, but the pay no longer matches the skill and effort - and on top of that, housing is incredibly more expensive than it used to be. We cannot afford a house even though my partner and I both make an alright amount of money and work our asses off. It's no wonder my entire generation is burnt out.

author: @ChogTheGreat
text:
Yeah, life‚Äôs better in some ways, but the problems now are way more complex. We‚Äôre constantly overstimulated by tech and ads, frying our nervous systems without even needing to leave the couch. Meanwhile, the rich-poor gap widens ‚Äî and unlike past generations, we actually see it happening IN REAL TIME.

People know wealth isn‚Äôt just about "innovation," "smarts," or ‚Äúhard work,‚Äù luck is potentially the biggest variable (where you‚Äôre born, what information you‚Äôre exposed to, what systems you land in). Effort matters, sure, but wages are SUUUUPER disproportionate to output. CEOs pocket millions in bonuses while frontline workers grind harder than ever.

We live in a world where SINGLE INDIVIDUALS could solve world hunger with only a portion of their wealth, but their assets just keep getting fatter. People SEE these issues and throw up their hands while feeling defeated. No wonder the working class feels burnt out, undervalued, and unmotivated, today, pretty  much everyone knows they‚Äôre being fleeced and there is pretty much NOTHING they can do about it.

author: @ellairax
text:
People can bear a lot of misery if they have a reason to or hope for a better future. Now, there is no economic or career mobility. And you don‚Äôt even have the time or energy to relax and do something you enjoy at the end of the day to make it somewhat bearable. The worst kind of suffering is suffering without a reason.

I have almost the same financial situation as her, but mine is student debt instead of rent. I‚Äôm lucky to be able to live with my parents or I‚Äôd be homeless. What I realized after a while of job searching was that it was unlikely that I was going to find a job where I was paid well. So really the only other factor I could control to make myself happier at work was the environment. Stop looking for the highest paying job and start looking for the one with people you can tolerate and work that doesn‚Äôt completely drain your soul (which doesn‚Äôt mean you have to love it, just not completely despise it). I think the people you are with are the more important part of that equation - the right people can make even the worst job bearable. 

What‚Äôs really giving me /purpose/ though is working on getting my dual citizenship in the EU. In four years, I can be out of here if I put in enough effort to learn the language and get the proper paperwork, due to my ancestry. I‚Äôve already had to hire a lawyer to get one of the pieces of paperwork I needed, which was expensive and stressful, but after getting that court order, I felt so proud of myself, and it renewed my energy and commitment. When there is hope and meaning, challenges can be beneficial to your mental health. Whatever that thing is for you, you need to find it and reach for it with both hands.

author: @magdalenalewandowska2862
text: Ok so I must say something here. Of course we are drained by the use of technology but the problem is mostly that young people think that things are given no effort required. At the age of 25 I moved to anothe country with my boyfriend and a suitcase. We worked terrible jobs. We were renting just one room in a dirty stinky house. We bought our property in 2016. I think after a couple of years of dead end jobs I decided that's it. I need professional career. So I was doing shiity jobs and I studied. Yes I cried over the books sometimes. But after several years of climbing up the ladder I do not cry anymore. These days I still study I never stopped learning. Now I do it from my own nicely decorated home office. People say I was lucky. All these people did not lift ther finger after finishing school. All you need these days is a strategy for technology use. Remember if there is no entertainment your brain would prefer to study than be bored. Yes. Your brain may even prefer unpleasen experience rather than no experience. You just need a few days. Just sit and stare at the wall for a moment if you have to do not switch on TV or pick up your phone that's all. It is about the stories we tell ourselves. Stop thinking that your extra effort is suffering because it is not. Stop imagining that watchin TV would be nicer than learning something new. These are lies. Just examine this really. What sort of things are you telling yourself. Good luck everyone who put away their phone. You'll find joy and purpose I assure you.

author: @ryanburchett8455
text:
Most of the time, I think these videos are great. Sadly, the economic analysis is totally inadequate. I have a background in economics, and I promise you that optimization isn't remotely close to the whole story. 

Maximizing profits is an old explanation based on the rational actor concept. Deeper studies confirmed that companies seek monopoly power over short-term profits. Wal-Mart was one of the first to be studied this way. Corporations also employed other alternate strategies to gain more power. Collusion to act as a cartel, which is a group of companies acting collectively as a monopoly, is illegal but common. Think of the rent "optimization" software that actually legally mandates, through contract law, its subscribers to charge prices they recommend. They use the data to corner the market and collectively raise pricing. Legal battles were fought, but corrupting forces have prevented legal action (in this instance) thus far. 

Price discrimination is also illegal and common. Think of 'deals' offered to buy more product at different price points. Consider ticket sales at different times, approaching date of the event. Amazon and other companies are now engaged in what they call "dynamic pricing." "Dynamic pricing" already had an economic term to describe it, though: it's called price discrimination. Even worse are the data mining operations that monitor your metadata. That's some scary stuff. You think Amazon knowing your purchasing habits is bad? (It really is.) Consider the possibility of metadata from your mouse clicking habits predicting a future disease and selling that to insurance companies who will eventually use that information to deny you coverage when you are in the hospital and can't work.


Ultimately, these are all policy choices, including the decision not to enforce policies that exist on the books. The reason new consumer and employee protections aren't legislated, or enforced when they do exist, is simply corruption. Politicians, judges, police, etc. are bought off in one way or another. No rich genius figured anything out that we didn't already easily understand as children: these people don't play fair. It's not your fault. It is the responsibility of these people not to behave like sociopaths. There has never been so much wealth and power for them to share. But, they would rather be greedy, evil monsters than help you or compensate you even remotely close to the value your labor created.

author: @brainstormsurge154
text:
Not sure if this comment will be buried or not but unfortunately this kind of problem can adequately or at least partially revealed with The Broken Window Fallacy which is well explained at the beginning of "Economics In One Lesson". It helps you understand why taxes and bureaucracy destroy real wage growth along with causing social entropy and decay as resources are squandered and parasitized.

You talk about hyper optimization as if it's the cause and not a symptom. Imagine if every day 10% of your food was stolen and there was nothing you could do about it. You would have less wiggle room to experiment or even to just relax and recuperate. Now think about that happening to an entire society and you can better picture the problem.

For understanding it even more there's reading "What Has Government Done To Our Money" and "Democracy: The God That Failed". There's also the very short read of "The Anatomy Of The State".

There are audiobooks and you can even find them all on YouTube so you can even listen while you're doing other stuff.

Hope that helps someone understand the situation better.

author: @elvinshoolbraid
text: Two things are true about this situation, only one of which I see people speaking about. 1. Cost of living relative to wages is higher than it's ever been, making a simple 9-5 life nye impossible. 2. The number of hours of work expected of you is roughly the same as it has been even in the better before times, and therefore a feeling of having no time and energy is more likely a feeling of hopelessness. It's useful to recognize that the bar for entrepreneurship, and education for better paying skills, has never been lower. If you believe it is possible for you to use these modern resources to gain skills and create value through service or product creation (which it totally is), you will be more motivated to try, and the bar is low enough that just actually trying in this domain will eventually let you find higher leverage work. If you do not quit, you cannot lose.

author: @DisguisedGray
text:
You seem to make logical points about how we're disadvantaged but ultimately are on our own. Also good on you for telling people to vote and that it matters.

**But** I don't like the way you're talking about some of this.
1. You make that comparison from how things used to be 100 years ago. This is hardly relevant anymore. If we have to live like we did back then given all the technological advancements and improvements to efficiency, then what's the point?
2. You say the word "entitled" a lot. While also saying that the capitalist meta has been optimized to take as much as it can and giving as little in return. I don't agree with being entitled.

The clip in the beginning is someone venting about a societal problem and you're just saying "look at your phone less and spread your chores out throughout the week. Expect life to be hard". That's hardly revolutionary. There is a wrongness to being robbed and enslaved like this, you could additionally focus on the broader picture of activism for worker's rights instead of trying to place so much responsibility on the individual, Jordan Peterson style.
