author: @Niaz_S
text:
I‚Äôve got a lot of interesting thoughts about this video. I am usually in full agreement with your videos, and they‚Äôve also helped me through some tough times, and led to meaningful development. 

As much as I respect your commitment to helping people with their life circumstances, I think calling this generation ‚Äúentitled‚Äù while acknowledging that material conditions are in the shitter is contradictory. How is it entitled to think that your job shouldn‚Äôt consume a majority of your time and having time to live the way you want and do the things to desire? 

Even if your advice objectively helps people cope with the terrible conditions we live under, at some point, optimization crushes us, and your advice  stops working. Employers will continue to further optimize how much they can exploit us until we will have no breathing room. 

Even if the majority of people nowadays who fail to thrive today are mentally ill or glued to their cellphone, why does that matter? It is clearly a majority of people. Call it like it is. We are being choked. This disgusting exploitation you call ‚Äúoptimization‚Äù has fully consumed us and made everything from social lives to finances objectively worse for the 99% of us. I know you acknowledge that things suck, but have the courage to call out capitalism too, man. It‚Äôs inhumane.

author: @genevievec.8002
text:
Every time I see a video about embracing personal responsibility regardless of circumstance, the comments always freak out.

What Dr K says here jives with my experience. I wasn't raises by boomers, because my mother was 17 when she got pregnant. We were also poor as hell. So I wasn't taught pull yourself up, I wasnt taught life was easy. I was taught life is exceptionally hard and that growing up poor ensured I'd be trapped in that cycle. As an adult, I just did what I could to improve my situation. Didn't matter if it wasn't fair or easy. 

Over time, life has improved drastically. I am in so much more of a comfortable spot than any of my family now. I don't have an enjoyable job, but it pays the bills well and it's not terrible. It achieves what I need it to. I never expected it to be enjoyable because I was never taught that work should be fun or enjoyable.

Maybe it's just a survivorship bias, but my trajectory has been completely typical in regards to skills and work experience, nothing unique or that required some kind of help or money or access to learning or education. So it's hard for me to get the struggle.

author: @virusdella
text:
Well. If anyone wants some advices on how to save money which I successfully do even in the current economy.

First and foremost - rent. Make it so you don't pay more than 1/3 of your salary. You might have to live with roommates, and better look for a private landlord. Avoid housing companies. Keep in mind that everyone around you is trying to manipulate you to give your money through different forms of marketing. Enjoy not giving them that. Don't subscribe to services. Look for free, open source if it's digital or used if it's physical. Thrift stores are your friends. Eat whole food plant based (you can quickly cook and combine stuff like grains, lentils, tofu and frozen greens and it's cheap, use soy sauce to make it tasty).

Track your budget in a libre office spreadsheet. Look what expenses are non-essential and can be reduced (you don't need to buy coffee every day for example). After you start saving money and build an emergency fund, you can figure out what amount a month you can spend to treat yourself. And also what your future goals are.

By doing all this you also reduce your participation in the capitalist system that relies on you spending as much money as possible.

author: @DizzyNeko
text: While I do understand the entitlement claim, it also seems a bit detached from reality/oversimplified. Hard work doesn't predict or correlate to a significant degree with financial success. Yes, if you are not born wealthy hard-work+luck is probably the only way to become financially afluent but the people that managed this feat usually suffer from serious survivorship bias. The vast majority of people work hard and don't get anything in return. They only make the rich richer. That is not leftist anti-capitalism propaganda, it's judt scientific facts across most western developed countries run by capitalism. Maybe the system is actually fucked and it's okay to call it out. Is there a better alternative, idk..

author: @ARsuffix
text: I do appreciate your clinically-informed, researched, and brutally honest  assessment of the current crisis of burnout and work exhaustion ‚Äì particularly amongst middle class and working class young people. You've shed a valuable light on something I had not considered: everything in the job market has been optimized to such an extent that it has actually become a detriment to young job-seekers at large. The older generation before us undeniably had it easier in terms of "pulling themselves up by their bootstraps" and successfully gaining upward momentum (without an insane amount of effort) ‚Äì they understandably assume that what worked for them should work for the kids. But in reality, the job market today is insanely more competitive or "optimize" that their lessons in work-life seem to fall tragically short for how difficult today's market really is. For too many young seekers, it has become seemingly unattainable to achieve the same success that their parents did in this current day in age.

author: @Shadrio
text:
I believe one could do a video where we could, not even going in depth either, just state the reasons why life feels so damn exhausting now compared to what used to be the norm, could easily fill up a 10 minute time slot.

One huge point I like to make towards the typical boomer that hits down is "My generation is THE MOST educated generation in human history, we were promised that if we put in the work in our teens then it would be easier, and yet the majority of people are barely keeping their heads above the water". Then I always get either one of two reactions:
- Either they look as if I'd just shown them how deep inside Plato's Cave we're all in, or (and this one is a bit more personal)
- "Well, you're doing better than most so why do you care?"  Putting aside the absolute lack of human empathy on display, even if I we were to condense the matter down to the most selfish perspective possible: economically speaking if we're all barely scrapping by then growth is not possible, stagnation arises and I won't be "better off" for long.

author: @KRIGBERT
text:
It's not just that the meta has been figured out, it's the fact that the owning class has been winning the class war for the last fifty or so years, and the working class has the smallest piece of the pie that they've had since the depression.

All western countries are wealthier than ever, and have more productive workers than ever, yet people have a harder time finding a comfortable home, getting the education they want, and providing for their families.

So yeah, of course, individually we have to just get it together and work - but collectively we need to work for societal change.

The most sickening thing is realizing that people who make over $120k generally end up only doing half the work that "normal" people are forced to do. E.g. software engineers/computer science jobs, administrators, HR, etc. The people making this amount are quiet about this; others are out of touch. (This is not equal across all fields, for example, doctors/surgeons work long, grueling shifts, and laborers also work long and hard).

The reason they do half the work (but are paid as if they are working 40 hours a week) include leniency, "seniority" (where their job is actually done by lower paid grunt workers), and management not understanding that their work only requires half the time and effort.

This sounds stupid, but i freaking cried driving to work because I didnt have time to play one game, because I need to go into for OT.

I already felt like my childhood got robbed from me, but now I feel like I‚Äôm being gatekeeped from it too. I thought maybe if i worked hard enough I‚Äôll have time to be a kid again. Ive managed to work OT for maybe 6 months? Now I cant help but be paralyzed in my chair before I go into work (I go in early for OT instead of staying late) So atm I‚Äôm doing a bit less OT for the same amount of fatigue. It just doesn‚Äôt make sense. 

At this point its not ‚ÄúFake it till you make it.‚Äù
Its ‚ÄúFaking it until you make or break it.‚Äù Whichever one comes first.

author: @markoanta3130
text: I think the key difference between nowadays and last century is that the general wealth grew as the difference between the wealthiest and poorest people. We got all the wealth and you still have to live from pay check to pay check. The wealthy people figured out the meta to be more wealthy and it‚Äôs to charge the unwealthy people. I don‚Äôt think working harder, being more resilient and reducing screen time will change their meta and make you feel less exhausted. It will make you think like a boomer ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù. You will feel better but not good and we live in a world where it‚Äôs possible to make most of the people feel good. They don‚Äôt have to rise their rent so high you need to have 3 jobs. They don‚Äôt have to denied 90% of health care payers because their health status doesn‚Äôt generate the amount of profit some shareholders wanna see. We got some people being able to afford everything and they still don‚Äôt get enough so the people without media and political connections, without the meta to generate more wealth have to pay it. It‚Äôs pretty clear that this circumstances create tiredness and mental health issues because you don‚Äôt have the possibilities to fight it. The only thing you can do is putting your phone away so you don‚Äôt see it so clearly and to work even more in a job you wouldn‚Äôt do if you don‚Äôt need to pay everything which creates automatic tiredness. We need a system change and this is what we need to teach the youth

author: @noheavenforsusan
text: The reason why we might feel Dr. K. is being 'harsh' here is not the disparity between financial backgrounds. It's because the problem - having to work for so long just to have basic shelter etc - is a POLITICAL problem. Dr. K. has the tools to help us manage the world *as it is*. You have to look elsewhere to find out how to actually change the working conditions. There are many incidences in history where people, facing similar odds, have absolutely switched the working conditions to a track where progress and improvement for standard of living is possible. I say this as a 42 year old who experienced such poverty as a child that I lived in a tent and spent some years as a homeless young adult. Survival mindset is a real thing and sure, we can all do it, but I would argue that you need to also trust yourself to find ways to change oppressive systems - not only adapt to living within them. If our ancestors had not done this, we would never have had weekends or primary education for our children. It's not wrong to continue to expect good living conditions! It's just not helpful to think it will happen without actually doing something about it. It's absolutely vital that we continue to stand against poor working conditions and unfair systems. It's unreasonable to expect Dr. K. to have the solutions for this, but he hints at it if you listen. GO AND VOTE but also write letters, send emails, sign petitions (all these things *do* work but only if you actually do it), stand up for each other in unfair work environments. It's difficult and risky, but it's that or settle for increasingly vanishing rights and freedoms even to just exist outside of work.

author: @lollipop1894
text: This is speaking from a purely progression based perspective, and trust me, I hear what she's saying. I feel the exact same feelings. Sometimes in order to make progress you have to be willing to sacrifice certain aspects and things in your life so that in other aspects of your life, you are able to thrive. And I want to say that with the caveat that everybody situation is completely unique and there's not one right answer for everyone. Just a couple thoughts that came to my mind as she was talking, she mentioned having a two-bedroom apartment. To me that sounds like a potential opportunity for her to sublease the apartment and get a roommate that can cover half the bill. If she has someone that is able to cover half the bill then she will be able to save that $1,000 a month and possibly free up some time to be able to go on a vacation,  take some time off for hersel, and get a chance to decompress. The other thought that came to mind is well she's in a two-bedroom apartment. Maybe she needs to downsize to a one-bedroom apartment, or maybe even a studio apartment short-term so that long-term she can be set up better financially to be able to take a breath. The other option is just putting a little bit of extra effort in the short term to find an apartment that's more affordable so that long-term, she's able to have a little bit more peace of mind. There's never a one-size-fits-all solution but there are solutions sometimes you just have to gauge short-term gratification over long-term relief. And sometimes it requires sacrifices.

author: @TheZaibs
text: I quit drinking caffeine for a month now, and I never get so tired that I can't do anything else in the evening. The problem with caffeine is that it takes your dopamine, pumps it in the first half of your day and you don't have it anymore in the evening. The problem with tiredness is not that you lack energy, you lack MOTIVATION. Chemicals inside you like dopamine work as action tools way better than some calories or rest. The problem is that people don't notice that because they are chronically using caffeine and no longer know the difference. I quit it and I have "energy" in the evening to keep going.

author: @indigosteel5702
text:
Survival was difficult over 100 years ago, but that was THEN. In our age of technology and civilization, survival should not be in question anymore. The problem is GREED; the greed of wealthy people who have forgotten that capitalism is about growing one's business by investment, innovation, and expansion, not hoarding so much money that you could never reasonably spend it in three lifetimes. If the wealthy were to well and truly invest in their employees and the community, as well as pay ALL of their owed taxes, the world would be a MUCH better place, and it would be a springboard to fix so many other issues with the world.
Thanks for coming to my TED Talk.

author: @WastelandHunter92
text:
It's frustrating to see people normalize working so much, I mean we are not made for this.
I hate to be the one pointing the elephant in the room, but this is the result of unchecked capitalism and private companies running on their own accord without anyone stopping them.
They think of us as simply as resources to be exploited until we are burned out like a used match, once we are done we can be disposed of and replaced by another.
If people would just stop and reflect things might change, but here's the catch, social network and electronics are now being used to make us feel even more tired and miserable.
We use our little energy left to doom scroll ourself into oblivion, to buy useless stuff that we don't need or to consume medias who make us even more miserable.
A perfect machine of a system to keep us "in check" miserable and somehow grateful to even being allower the courtesy to live with a roof on our heads and little food on our table.
It still baffles me how anyone could consider this normal.
We should work less, earn more and regain more time, who give a damn of the CEO who can't afford to buy his third Ferrari by pain a little more the employees who allow him/her to live a parasyte life.

author: @thermalrain_yt9725
text:
I call BS. 
You may not become a millionaire by working hard only but you will be successful. Im 40 with no higher education and am underpaid but I made 75k last year. I come to work and I work. You won't believe the amount of kids I see come in with absolutely no motivation to work hard. They get upset when you just look at them sideways. They're on their phones all day. I mean all day. 
We've been looking for months for people to take in and you are absolutely correct in saying g companies have figured out the lowest amount they can pay. We start around $20 and hour but so does Quick trip. We are a precision machine shop and we cant even pay more than the convenience store down the road. I mean qt makes a TON of money but still.
That being said a 19 year old starting at 17 an hour is pretty good money. 

I think a big part of the problem is we see so many fake rich and even rich young people who got lucky and think well I should have that too. 

Plus at the beginning she was talking about expenses. Rent phone and internet which 2/3rds of that didn't exist when our parents were young. They had rent and utilities to pay. Now we have a dozen streaming services, $300 phone bills another $100 for internet. Our $10 coffees and vapes. Bs expenses went up sky high.
Its not Donald Trumps fault üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ give me a break. 

I'll take being stressful over money than people dying all around me any day. Life is beyond easy now compared to how it has ever been in all of history. As far as this 100 years has been far easier than the past 100 years. Was it easier 25 years ago? Maybe idk but its pointless to argue about because now is the easiest time to live and yet we still complain

author: @nackedgrils9302
text:
I'd be curious to look at if as many boomers were living alone in an apartment back then vs millenials now. Sure, the current situation is making it almost impossible for those of us who are antisocial to thrive but when I look at people like my sister who has always dated and either lived with her boyfriend or roommates, she actually came out of uni with so much money that she could have had afforded the cashdown and mortgage on a small house by herself just because her average rent has always been 1/3 of mine. Meaningwhile, I'm working 50-70h/week between two jobs while also setting myself up for a side hustle and I still had to give up on the dream of ever owning a house.

My point being that the atomization of social structures is also a big driver of this crisis but there are some of us who are actually antisocial and can't even begin to imagine living with someone else and we're so fucked because of this.

author: @gregorywemyss
text:
Listen the video really helped me break the illusion that someone is going to help me, however when you mentioned going to the gym when tired I just really didn't understand the emotional logic or the logical logic, I mean maybe if your body is tired its trying to conserve energy and wait for a better opportunity, myself I am already burnt out, and you tell me go to the gym, that's not gonna restore me that's gonna waste more of my time that could be devoted to something more productive, such as figuring out a way to escape the cycle of 40 Hour work weeks, I mean instead of going to the gym ive figure out how to save a couple bucks so I dont have to work the extra 10, bring on the four day work weeks please.

Also your point about streamers not succeeding compared to being a doctor kinda destroys the point, I mean a steamer is a career doing one of the most relaxing things possible but in a very structured and organised manner that is designed to be entertaining, comparing it to being a doctor is ridiculous people become doctors due to overt pressures placed on them by family and society and can be a very taxing job, with a high entry level, think of all the people working run down jobs who's parents wished them to become doctors, 14 years of training in the uk to become fully qualified, vs 5 years of work and streaming to maybe become successful. Two different goals and entirely different kinds of people, not only that to get into university, to get money to study is much higher than trying to be a streamer and buying a webcam and a pc, also your saying your trying to help people, but people dont watch twitch for help, they watch it like generic tv these days, but we always need doctors and we always need entertainment, hopefully one day its just entertainment needed more than doctors, so your twitch career wasn't going to take off anytime soon, I do not have enough experience but as a viewer im telling you id rather watch some random play a game I like than get advice on all my problems, your bringing problems to escapism haha.

My last point I wanted to touch on is thank you for this video it provides that forward looking logic that is missing from 40 hour work weeks, but I think that for these kinds of issues maybe some financial advice or a careers advisor may come in better place, or just as an addition to your video.

edit (yeah phones are messed up man, too much nonsense that just takes it out of you, that's the kind of entertainment that's destroying you, anyway I hope you can see the passion in my reaction and not some sort of resentment to this kind of content)

author: @Grayfoxhound
text:
I believe a lot of it is "I feel stuck and don't know what I need to do to fix my situation, please someone else help me"

- upskill yourself outside of work or through work
- work smarter not harder
- find room mates if living alone (ignore pride or anxiety)
- look for a job inside the company you work for, get to know the manager of that department, express desire to work in that role (internal hire interviews are far less demanding and exacting - speaking from experience)
- apply to role, start at bottom, work way up

author: @RishanRishu-y3g
text:
My Life Story

In 2023, I passed my +2. After that, I worked for 2 months. Then I went abroad to study, but due to family problems, I had to return. In that process, I lost ‚Çπ1 lakh.

When I came back, I wanted to build my future. I thought about learning coding, so I joined a course. But within 1 week, I saw that it wasn‚Äôt the right place for me, and I came back home. I felt very lost.

I decided to try again and fully dedicate myself. But I didn‚Äôt really learn anything. I got mentally stuck. I didn‚Äôt know what to do with my life. For almost 10 months, I stayed in my room, mostly sleeping, confused and stressed.

During this time, my family pressure became very heavy. We are already in debt. I cannot even explain the mental weight I feel every day. I feel like I wasted time and money ‚Äî around ‚Çπ3.5 lakhs total.

I feel lost and don‚Äôt know what to do next. I want to change my life but don‚Äôt know where to start.

text:
In my opinon, this is where individual therapy ends and cannot compensate with the faulty system in place in America and generally speaking in Europe. We have moved towards a neoliberal economy, outsourcing much of our production. This has increased local inequality and has led to a significant imbalance of power between lower-middle class workers and private owners. Most laws voted on go against the interests of lower-middle-class workers. 
Until we reduce inequality in our countries, we cannot hope for a better life.
While there are some examples of social mobility, these tend to fall within the survival bias. Where I can agree with you is that we cannot fall into the passive acceptation of the situation, it's quite the opposite, it's time to act on it politically.

author: @JKBeck-dw7dd
text:
I worked an average of 60-80 hours per week (usually two jobs or one job while picking up as much overtime as possible) for the entirety of my 20s, telling myself if I 'just work harder' I would reach a point where it got easier or I got to a job I found enjoyable. 10 years of nonstop-two-fulltime-job grind and it never got easier. Instead, I burnt out to a point where I struggle to even feed myself most days because the effort of eating (even if it's pre-made food) is too much. I sometimes wonder if I'd instead conserved my energy, I wouldn't be at this point. And I sometimes wonder if I'd worked 3 jobs or 90-100 hours a week (which tbf, I even did that for a short while and ended up hospitalized form it) I'd have reached that point were it would be easier. Both situations feel like a losing option. 

I'm not really sure there is an escape from this, when everything is optimized to keep people working at exactly the level where they don't die, but not an ounce less. It's not even necessarily the amount of work that is making it unbearable, but the lack of time to actually live. No time to socialize and break out of isolation. No energy to even keep up with texts (I barely look at my phone these days) to maintain the semblance of social interaction. No time for hobbies or passions. It makes it hard to feel there's much worth living for when you're not even allowed to live, just allowed to survive a life you don't even enjoy. Not sure how to work harder than your hardest without completely reaching the point where a complete exit from living becomes the only real option to consider.

I don't need to own a house. I don't need to travel the world. I don't need fancy marble countertops or the newest smartphone. I just need time and energy to actually live. To have friends. To go for walks outside. To have a relationship. To enjoy my hobbies and passions. But even that is beyond reach.

author: @JordanFayter
text: I remember when I was younger, after high school, I was working 7 days a week, 2-3 jobs a day, before I went to college to become a Healthcare Assistant. Even when I was in school, I found ways to make extra income either through my actual jobs on the side, finding things I could do to bring in extra income for investments or finding ways to earn cryptocurrency, finding different things I could sell. I even worked as a Panago Pizza dishwasher for $6 an hour, which was still under minimum wage at the time, but I got a free large pizza after every shift. I would save up all my pizzas and on Friday night, when the Boys and Girls Club had a night for the teens called Nights Alive. I would get all my pizzas made and go to the grocery store across the street and get 2L bottles of pop. I would sell pizza and pop, along with cigarettes and whatever else I saw that there was a market for. Even in Elementary School, I was playing for keeps with other kids and selling or trading my winnings, selling candy and pop, and just studying people, how to read people. With all my learning disabilities, the schools and teachers didn't want to teach me. I was given a teacher's Assistant to do all my work (reading, writing, tests, and so on). I didn't even get homework like the rest of my class. I spent my day in school learning more about people and how to manipulate them if I wanted to, and when I went home, I would teach myself. I remember learning about quantum mechanics and quantum physics in my own time as an elementary school student while the rest of my class was doing their homework or enjoying their weekend.

author: @sokoloff114
text:
I've traveled a lot for work, and visiting a poor country helps me to adjust my frame of reference. Desert, +40'C outside, no trees, garbage everywhere. And people live there, and they seem to be content, even if they can't afford an AC. 
Life is hard, for every single sane person. Probably working on making it better, for yourself and for others, is the key - because it actually gets better AND you receive positive emotional feedback from 'working'. Goal is to make the struggle _worth_ it.
And if you feel that your work if futile, you're doomed. Pointless work is a form of torture.

author: @patrickrudiger8762
text:
Working harder than 40h/week is not going to cut it. Its totally naive and an idiotic position to have that working harder is a solution. Fact is: It is not ok to expect ppl to work more. Absolutely not. That ppl are poor is the result of immoral behaviour that needs to be addressed.

In the last 70years, producitity raised a LOT. And that continued in the last 20 years. So how comes, that now 40 hours is no longer enough to build something up but barely enough to survive for many people? Very simple. The share of the GDP going to capital gains and thus the already wealthy climbed and climbed and climbed. Todays billionaires are like the rubber barons. They are just more efficient, more evil, more dangerous.

And their behaviour, at least in the US, is literally killing people. Via lack of propper food, deprivation from healthcare etc.

Oh and by the way, you know what happens when all try to make ends meet by working more? Its quite simply. Without goverment regulation, for labour the same applies as for any good and service: Supply and demand regulate the price. So if all work longer, the price for work per hour will fall. In fact, it will plummet hard, because even for a lower price, there is not enough demand four labour. Thus, those owning the means of production can reduce the wages even further and increase their profit margin even more.

If you want to know how, in history, conditions like they are today got resolved, maybe google "haymarket affair" or "the new deal" or any other society upheaval that lead to the transformation of a society with a rich decadent upper class into a society that shows more equality . Workers need to stand up for their rights. They need to get the correct politicians in place. They need to make sure, that the rich folks pay their fair share.

author: @chrisanderson687
text:
Here's what you do: 1. Stop complaining  2. Get a roommate, you said you have two bedrooms, rent out the other room, rent drops in half to $830. Now you have $1170 extra each month. That will cover phone/internet and food, and should have savings left over. 3. Put money in savings, in high interest savings account. 4. Work on your career, get promoted, or leverage your experience to get a better job an another company. It's a grind, but you have to keep going to get the bigger payoffs. You are young that's why you are poor, we all have to pay our dues.

I can't believe the whining as if this is unique to her or her generation. Nope. I went through this too, as did my parents, and theirs, forever. We all struggle to survive, that's life. Stop complaining, stop crying, get tough and get focused and determined, and make something of yourself.

author: @magic369z
text:
I have been going through this for years and one thing I have learned is that when you are always tired, numb, depressed is because you are not living the way that you're supposed to. If your job makes you miserable it's because you are not suppose to do that. Your body will tell you what you need to do and if you don't follow your intuition you will suffer the consequences.

Of course it makes sense logically to work a job you don't like to afford to live but guess what trading security for freedom isn't the solution. We have been brainwashed to think that jobs will give us security but safety is only a prison. What's funny is that having a job is no longer safe you can literally can get fired any day without warning and not only that most job will disappear because of AI. 

9-5 is a scam, maybe it worked for other generations but we are the ones who are currently suffering the consequences. But we also have way more opportunities than other generations to make an income because of the internet. I don't want to be the don't settle for a 9-5 and start your own business guy but we have to accept the reality of our current world. I think a more balanced approach will be to get a part-time job and have a side hustle or just have multiple sources of income in general. It's either that or pray to get lucky and find someone who will hire you at a job that you probably want to quit couple of months from now. 

Also prioritizing your mental health is key, I see a lot of people ruining their mental health working at jobs they hate. A choice I had to make was I rather be at peace and broke than miserable and financially secure. When you are at peace you think more clearly and have more energy to put towards achieving goals that are worth it to you not tasks that other people gave to you. 


If a job is the thing you spend the most time doing that means that you means that it's literally the most important decision you will make in your life. Don't act like your work is something separate from your life because it's not. If you hate your job and you're stuck financially you might have to hit the reset button. Quit your job, sell your car and go live with your parents, go back to school if that's what you need to do. Stop settle for mediocrity and do what actually makes you happy and when challenges come up its going to be actually worth going through them.

author: @melasnexperience
text:
Doesn't help that even if you have free time, your only non-work socialization options are either not skewed to your age group (such as hobby meetups only being on campuses & implicitly just for the students or held in the middle of the workday & implicitly only for retirees), skewed towards families (such as building your free time around your kids' sports/clubs), or built around drinking/clubbing. If you want more than those options, you're expected to go online, and that's shown that it's not a true substitute for in-person socialization. And that's not even getting into how this gets limited even more if you're still a student (the way modern teenagers are basically seen as criminals to be shunned & barred from all non-school establishments is especially damaging).

Also, saying this as someone who is a single only child with aging parents, my weekends aren't even "working for myself" so much as "working for them" and doing things for them such as heavy yard work or just entertaining them (one parent is still working & has said that my visits are "the highlight of their week"). It gets frustrating because more time-intense stuff for my own place always has to wait weeks until I get a day off from work. I'm sure other people with aging parents find themselves in the same situation of going from full-time work to weekend/after-work caretaker.

author: @–ê–Ω–¥—Ä–µ–π-–π5—Ö9—å
text:
Last year I had an internship in a lab, where officially they have paid a minimum wage for interns (like 600 euros per month (which they delayed the first three months) sometimes more, sometimes less depending on the official "holidays" (which was not really applied to me, I was supposed to write my thesis on that time, other interns too)): it was calculated by hour, so not to break the French laws they counted like 35 hours a week, which we the international students could not surpass. In reality it was more than 50: get on work at 8 o'clock, get out at 19, sometimes a bit later, sometimes a bit earlier. Due to Paris Olympics it took from 2h30 to 4h total to get to work and back each day! So basically I did not have even time to cook at a dormitory (there it was just a room with a bed and a wc, a 1h-1h30 ride from Paris, but it still costed more than my whole "salary" per month). Coming back there I had no even strength to do anything, because Parisian RER system is sucking the rest of the forces out - you get at home at around 22h, a shower if there is hot water and then sleep, get up at 6h  and repeat. We did not even have food at the lab (It was reserved to those in the French system): only tonns of coffee to keep your head buzzing, so I was eating something I could buy in the nearest store to the lab,  usually cold: cold soup and bread, sometimes get-out lunchboxes, but not a lot due to prices. No normal sleep, a supervisor who shouts at you and treats you like a bug and an idiot (but still a very distinguished and capable scientist though), no food, and not even a descent chair to sit (at Sorbonne they are in deficit, so I still have pain in the back after one year). We were working some days in a clean room and imagine that you are going out from there like twice during 8 hours a day - no water or toilet, just processing, processing, processing...
 It was very interesting (without sarcasm), the topic was great, but even if you love the topic - after 6 months of such a grind you want to fucking jump under RER (which I think many people here do, because it has always perturbed traffic due to a "person accident" , several times a week), and there were some PhD students there who were doing 3 years like this (but much higher paid and mostly with a Crous governmental accommodation, which is the same price, but much closer to the lab)... - imagine that and these people are the most educated ones, what is going on with the lower classes is even worse.
PS also, I mentioned that the work was really interesting - it is true. we even had worked on a cyclotron, but there the shift was around 30 hours ( yes, without sleep) - very interesting 30 hours, but you are trading your heath for this interest.
PPS Now this experience is not even considered by HRs¬† when searching for a job...

author: @12em_roken21
text:
After 3 years of working in different abusive environments (I‚Äôve changed 6 jobs in the past 4 years), fighting the people in authority; I finally found bosses (a married couple) who appreciate hard work because they themselves have been grinding since the age of 16 (they had a child at that age), now they are planning to open a 3d restaurant. I‚Äôve only been working there for 3 months but they already have increased my wage (not by much, but still) saying ¬´¬†keep up the good work, we want our employees to be happy¬†¬ª. 

I still work tiring 10 hour shifts, being a line cook is hard, but also employment trauma is real, it feels so weird to not despise my place of work. I did get lucky this time, but I also don‚Äôt want to minimize my hard efforts, I have not had a vacation in more than 4 years and probably will not have any time soon, but at lest i don‚Äôt have to waste so much energy playing mind games with an egocentric babysitter, because I know if my current bosses have a problem with me- they will come to me directly to talk. 

Also, I usually work 1pm-12am, get home at sometimes 2am, in the morning and during the commute I study French part-time every day (for immigration reasons). I gotta say that I am tired and rightfully so, but I have already  achieved so much for an immigrant in their early 20s‚Äô. I am still just a work in progress and I‚Äôm not where I want to be rn in life, the progress is never linear. I know it might sound cheesy, but you truly only lost if you gave up trying. Hope dies last!

author: @dangerousthoughts.1591
text:
Bruh, I‚Äôm never leaving the Army üòÇ. I dread the next 13 years of bs we have to deal with every day in the Army, but I‚Äôm well off financially and get annual raises. In fact I‚Äôm getting a $532 monthly base pay raise this January. If I were to get out I‚Äôd need to immediately find an entry level job willing to pay over $100k in order to maintain the same level of compensation I get from the military. My base pay may only be around $48k but with food, housing, insurance, and other benefits it makes it impossible to get out.

Not trying to convince people to join but if you‚Äôre just getting out of HS then the military should be a serious consideration.  The pay absolutely sucks at the beginning but once I hit about 5 years I was doing pretty good financially. And even though the initial pay was bad I was a single soldier living in the barracks wasting my money on video games, alcohol, and eating out because I didn‚Äôt have to pay rent. That and I‚Äôve gotten a degree and am on my way to another one. The key to joining the military is finding a good job, I started out as a prison guard but now I work in IT. There‚Äôs jobs in the Army that don‚Äôt require you to deploy constantly and fight wars on the front line. There‚Äôs medical jobs, intel, mechanics, ATC, electricians, heavy equipment operators, logisticians, ordinance, drone operators‚Ä¶ the list goes on.

author: @Nozdromu13
text:
Well, what we used to have was:

One person per household, could make enough money to maintain normal survival for their significant other and the offspring. It took, a normal job, that needed basically commitment and will to do it. If you decided to create your own business, chances were that you will have an above average experience. Good university degree and all of the above, almost guaranteed a pretty high level of life. And if you did all that, and got lucky/took risks that didn't backfire, you might even join the ultra wealthy around 40-50. 

So basically, you could to a degree, choose the amounts of fucks given daily and receive an equal amount of wealth back. 

This is an insanely simplified example of cours, metric fucktons of luck or lack of it, influenced every single step of such journeys, and of course many failed or had misfortunes. But the reality was, a mailman who was honest and regular at his job, could bring home a salary to support having said home and family. No luxuries, just simple life with normal amount of stuff in it. 

Right now:

Hahahahahahaha, nope. Mailman with a family on single salary is just not possible. You will not manage. The salary of one grown-up person, in entry to mid level jobs, is giving you barely survival. You do not OWN the house as the previous same mailman could. You probably do not even have a partner not to mention family with children. And you give the same amount of fucks, but receive way less wealth for it. 

So all in all, most people see this and ask a very sensible question - what for?

author: @heret1c385
text:
I can identify a lot with this. 

Things with rent  are similar here in Germany. I was able to study computer science  basically for free, which earned me a well paying job at a big German hosting company. 
Rent is still crushing, since I also unexpectedly became a father, which didn't make things cheaper and definitely takes the biggest chunk of my spare time, but we can afford everything we need to. 
But I still see no real trajectory, owning a house  with a garden for my daughter to play in will probably stay a dream. I still feel like a wage slave. I can save money, but it will never be enough to go places in life. Most of my savings go into an ETF, to save my pension; since our system is deemed to collapse before I can retire. (I don't think the generations before us even had to think 40 years ahead like we do) I simply can't justify spending more than half a million euros on a decent house, especially with Russia invading Europe. If they deem Ukraine a success and are able to rebuild their military, attacking NATO is probably the next step in the next 10 years. That's another big stress factor.

I'm also quite sure that I'm depressed. I don't get excited anymore, every day feels like a waste, like a day not truly lived. It feels like I'm living my live to generate income for someone else, and then the realization kicks in, that I'm in this loop for the next 40 years. Its crushing.

I know other people have it way harder than me, but life still feels somewhat pointless. I'm glad I have my daughter, she gives me an objective reason to live, I need to provide for her.

text:
I might disagree here. 
As a Brazilian Psychologist, i think the issue is more about how capitalism, and not as an ideology, but how a failured economy model in third world countries, is driving the entire world ( and now including USA) into a hellhole to keep the billionaires wealthy, rather than solving mental issues. 

This is the same issue with the "Generation (Dragon ball) Z" pseudoscientific stuff. That we blame on the young and well educated people that is not getting 225hour/month jobs for a wage of  250USD/month and without any working class benefits. 4

You have no vacation, you must keep your presence in work every day and if you skip a day, you'll lose a day of work and therefore the money worth of working during that day, and if by any means the contractor ends your contract, you get out without any assitance. 

So, you must work until your very own life runs dry or else you can't even survive in this world. 

this sounds a little bit like the Yungian definition of hell. which is like... the entire world outside western Europe, Aussie and New Zealand ( A.K.A Middle earth on earth) and the US ( Canada is a British Colony, tho). 

So, yup... we need to discuss this looking more into a "Intern Brute Product growth vs mental health" rather than just a " just mental health" kind of issue. 

Because, like Aaron T. Beck would say, this world is so full of unique realities that even all the knowledge we have in books would be insuficient to describe this whole reality.

author: @oneness-12
text:
This might be the first time I find myself at odds with your perspective. The core issue, as I see it, is the attempt to conjure solutions from the very environment that spawned the problem in the first place.

Consider someone utterly exhausted, clearly too isolated to share their burdens. Offering them a "solution" like "if you push yourself harder, you'll eventually feel less tired" might be the most "realistic" approach in that moment, but it's unequivocally not the most humane.

You touched on the voting dilemma, and it's a perfect parallel. In this country, people are given only two options, forced to pick the lesser of two evils, leading many to simply abstain from voting altogether. Or, someone who initially couldn't fathom voting for a particular candidate ends up doing so in the next election.

Trying to find answers within the system that's the root cause of the problem will, at best, only redirect the issue. It might, in the most optimistic scenario, merely postpone it.

The truth is, the life we're living‚Äîor rather, the life we no longer have time to truly live‚Äîand the neoliberal framework we're caught in, fundamentally oppose many of humanity's factory settings. It's pushing individuals daily toward an inevitable, grim conclusion.

Those who've ventured outside the US to countries with more "normal" conditions‚Äîwhere people aren't mechanized, and social bonds remain strong‚Äîcan clearly see that the solution isn't found where the problem originated. Sadly, those trapped within the system often can't even perceive this, fading away into forgotten solitude until their end.

author: @samanthagaboo5610
text:
You're the only other person beside myself who talked about workplace optimization. I have worked in claims and insurance which is very metrics driven. At any one time your manager can see how many files you've touched, How many notes you've made on files, etc, How many calls you've made, everything. I couldn't stand the unachievable metrics and went back to school for x-ray. There are less metrics in X-ray... But managers and hospital administrators have still figured out because everything is so tracked... How many patients you should see in an hour. And they're not paying you to sit still so if they can they try to fill up as much as possible to keep you busy. For the past few weeks I've asked my family and a close friend Why is it that over 100 years ago the 40-hour work week was created but here we are still working 40 hours a week. Where is this technology.. I don't care if we get to Mars or if I have to drive my own car... Why haven't we whittled down work to a 6-hour work day... We are working harder than we have before... I'm not talking about the difference of working in a farm and on a field but I'm talking about the fact that because of these metrics and optimization the managers and owners of these businesses have figured out how to get ever drop of work they can can out of you. I don't mind pushing the pedal down and working a hard six or even 7 hours... But by the time you add commute time and shower time and sleep time.. I have learned when I work an 8-hour shift that gives me four to five hours an evening a night... When I work my 12s.. by the time I get home it gives me 2 hours before I have to go to bed. 

I went back to school last year... I had a full-time job but my expenses almost matched my incoming... I finally starting to get ahead when I was able to get a PRN job.. and basically was able to put PRN money toward debt or savings. For the next two months I will be working. 60 hour weeks to try and get ahead. I make $30 an hour in my rent is only $1,000.  Shouldn't be this difficult.

author: @DystopianDIY
text:
14:44 I strongly disagree. The Boomers were not lazy. The economy they inherited from the Silent Generation was such that the consequences for taking risks and failing were much easier to rebound from because there was an abundance of opportunity.

Then, at some point, the Boomers at the top became blinded by their success and their empathy and compassion for those less fortunate eroded. Survivor bias. Profit at the expense of sustainability became the norm. And they projected their own entitlement on Gen X, Y and Z in order to avoid any nagging sense of guilt for their insatiable greed.

I didn‚Äôt need TikTok to tell me I was being exploited in 2020 during the pandemic. I lived the exploitation first hand. I got to experience other people forcing me to risk my life just to keep the economy going so stock prices wouldn‚Äôt dip.

This is not optimization; this is a short-sighted cash grab by those who know they will not be around when everything finally collapses in on itself. And they don‚Äôt care because they will have gotten theirs, damn the consequences.

author: @flameshoter6
text:
This only works for one aspect. I used to work like 60 to 72 hours a week for a good few years (like 7 years, including my college years) on my feet the entire time. From dawn to dusk (well further than that). Not including the time it took to get ready in the morning and the amount of time it took to drive between jobs and to home. By the time I got done with work on Saturday, I still had to do food shopping, prepare for the week, and do yard work. All while looking after my mom with her health issues. Trying to clean anything was difficult due to lack of time. My Sunday was pretty much just sleeping all day. I wouldn't get up until like 1pm because I was only sleeping like 3 hours a day during the week.

Now, I only work 40 hours, but I have to clean, cook, shop for food, prepare the week, do the yard work, make repairs or maintenance, look after my mom still (while she makes all of the mess while I'm gone like 10 hours a day) and hope she doesn't manage to burn my place down. I'll make time on the weekend to do stuff like kayaking or going on a walk at a park, or playing video games. 

But during the 40 hours of work, now, I'm sitting behind a computer 8 hours a day, doing non-stop stressful projects, researching, people arguing with me for the issues they caused, training people, helping them, people taking offense over the tiniest things, etc. I had to basically start from nothing and rebuild the entire unit because it was non-existent for almost 10 years. I'm mentally exhausted each day and physically tired on the weekends.

I would say that the best shot we would have, would be to go back to the "basics", instead of white collar jobs, people can try to become well paid handymen, as even if they get replaced by robots or whatever, their skills are inherently useful. People need to start forming small communities back again, as well as micro economies.

author: @samaelfederchen9926
text:
I have to disagree where the tirednesscomes from. 40h of work are NOT the same at every place! Having a toxic workplace with unreachable expectations, no job training and too high density and responsibility leads to chronic stress. You can NOT train and adapt to that!

For more than a year I tried to convince myself once I am better in this task it will get easier. It didnt, the tasks just got even more. I ended with stress related hair loss and chronic headache aswell as untreated inflammations.

The 40h job I work now is half the workload and pays more. Sorry but saying "all ofyou are just tired because you are addicted to your phones" is a dangerous oversimplification!

Also, being always just one misstep away from homelessness prevents you from setting healthy boundaries at work - towards your colleagues towards your clients and customers and towards your boss. You stop saying no. So the risk rises to be mistreated and molested and to get even more workload. Which makes you angry and exhausted even more.

Quality of work and workplace is important yet depending where you live the number of places to chose from can be highly limited.

author: @AlsonamedDennis
text: I agree that corporate entities maximize profits now, making it tough for young people. My parents were Boomers. The idea that Boomers had it easy is ludicrous. They're the generation of "uphill both ways to a job at 14." They worked hard, had almost no luxuries, cooked meals at home, and didn't have credit cards. Yes, a car in 1960 was relatively cheap, but there were no airbags, AC, backup cameras, power steering/brakes, etc, etc. Cheaper, but far less safe and comfortable. Same with apartments. You got a bed and a toilet. Maybe a shower with good water pressure or a bathtub.

author: @CBrown
text:
What frustrates me about this situation is that we just allow it to continue. I get that it's a tough ask to expect enough individual people to take issue with their workplace, where they currently live, or do much to change how much gas costs but is it too much to ask that you stop shopping at Amazon? Stop using Facebook/Instagram? Stop buying a new $1,000 phone every other year? We entitle the biggest individual contributors to the problem to continue being the biggest individual contributors of the problem. That may be a tough ask too given how dug into our lives some of these big companies are but it's certainly not too tough to ask that we use our voting powers responsibly. 

We keep bickering over Left vs Right and getting stuck on issues that don't really matter like abortion, DEI, and transgender rights. Leave those alone and let people make whatever choices they want to make. I don't see a logical reason why we need to get involved in personal choices like that. Feel how you feel but the more important issues like the economic situation we find ourselves in keeps getting ignored. People will vote for a guy who says what they want to hear about a social issue and completely ignore that this person will raise their taxes, give tax breaks to the already ultra wealthy, and straight up not answer questions people ask them about issues. What's worse is that when neither of the two candidates from the two parties we've inexplicably boiled our choices down to fit the bill, we won't even consider a third option. If a Republican doesn't vote Republican the Democrat will win and visa versa and because our team has to win, we only vote one way forever. It's like being stuck in traffic right next to an exit that will take you home and choosing not to take it. It makes no sense and will never change and that's what's so frustrating to me. To know that we can only solve a problem if we try but see everyone being unwilling to try.

author: @markmalinowski5951
text: I thought I was doing "good" whether because of good luck, planning, or just hard work. I worked myself to exhaustion to pay off my debts, buy a house, learn how to fix my own stuff, and stay debt-free. I went back to school to try and increase my job prospects and income. I got a degree online and paid the tuition each semester with careful financial planning. I thought I was doing great. Then I had a kid and the medical bills even with "good insurance" put me into debt. I had a major car repair and even just buying the parts and doing the work myself put me into more debt. I got a "promotion" at work which meant a 5% pay raise... and 25% more work to do. Bad deal. Plus with sleep deprivation helping my wife take care of a baby. Running on pure adrenaline and lots of caffeine just to stay awake. And I'm going "good" compared to many, which feels terrible to say. It feels like my hard work wasn't worth it and I still don't deserve what I have because so many work just as hard and are struggling so much more. Feels like the whole world is heading for a crash and I am worried.

author: @KayByte
text:
Aw man i feel her so badly. I actually earn more vs rent and savings. So we've saved up and can finally buy a house as two people. But its basically now house poor to own a decent house with a 40 min drive to work. 0 money to do it up, 0 savings left, and we worked out it would take us 2 years to save a 6 months emergency fund for just the bare minimum. And thats if we spent nothing on anything, just the mortgage, food and bills for those 2 years. And we've not gone extreme on the house or anything. Its just a small bungalow with a tiny garden in Scotland. So yeah... Not ideal.


But it's the mental exhaustion after work. I notice woman struggling with this more tbh anecdotally, unless they get into a position where they are making decisions and changing things early on, or when there's some form of reward in the work you do.

I've had one role where i was really happy then they moved me and now i despise my current role because its so meaningless and task heavy. 40 hour weeks in general just burn you out, we weren't meant to do this. But less so sitting still in front of an office. But if I try to go for a creative role, i can't earn enough. If i want to pick up some qualifications for the type of roles i do want... Well AI is going to wipe those roles out in the next 2-5 years. And to boot, I'm too exhausted to study new things in my mid 30s, doing 40 hours in front of a desk not moving with adhd. I don't know how many times I've broken down crying at it like her. God the extra money stress she's dealing makes it so much harder :(

My brain is so depleted after the day, all my hobbies stop being fun and i cant do them or anything because im so exhausted and they all feel like work. So i just go to bed and that's it until the next day when i get up for work. i just have no energy mentally left at all.

This system is horrific and squeezes people dry. We weren't meant to live like this but the system makes it so we can't afford to live any other way, and have 0 energy to invest into breaking out of it.

The idea of going off grid in Scotland? Unaffordable unfortunately also. 

Life is just impossible tbh and idk how many times ive just dipped to the idea of suicide despite being a generally happy stable person, that doesn't struggle with mental health. Only burn out from the way existence and jobs are. Give me a month off and I'll be the most productive happy, stable person you ever meet. Put me in a meaningless desk job for 40 hours and no chance. Its just grinding me down non stop.

author: @zeefeet
text:
I've watched and enjoyed your content/advice for a while now and always appreciated your humane takes on the reality of the deep mental struggles in this space.

Now it's when you start to advertise your coaching class and business that makes me weary that maybe your focus is not clear. I say this after hearing you say you're not anti-capitalist nor anti-private industry. Whole sure there is nuance I just find a tad silly when most of the problems you speak on are derived from the society we're currently living in.

author: @quart-knee-lee
text: They have us tired, atomized, addicted to mindless consumption, unable to band together to get more of the fruits of our labor and the fruits of the labor of our whole society. There is no reason that in the US in 2025, people need to be just barely surviving despite working so hard and that's if you can get a job. Capitalism requires a "reserve army of labor." During the Depression, the government put people to work because capitalists are only incidentally job creators, they won't do it if it's beneficial to sit on their money and do nothing. We still have these wonderful parks built from that time. Some of us are literally not useful to the system, so they want us in prison or unemployed. While some of us can "pull ourselves up by our bootstraps" (literally a thing that is not possible, it was created as a critique of this way of thinking), most of us can't, no matter how hard we try. In Scandinavia, there is significantly more opportunity for upward mobility. They have the American dream, we don't. There are not enough good paying jobs, not enough jobs, not enough affordable places to live where there are also jobs. There isn't enough to go around and that's why we are so miserable. This is a feature, not a bug. The fact that increased productivity led to increased wages after the post-WWII boom. where the US benefited the most from a US-run world order, still haunts us. There's this assumption that student debt is legitimate when my mom went to a private university and only had to work part time to pay her tuition in the mid-70s, whereas I basically could only make enough to eat and buy books and had to work for the city government for ten years to get my $30k of debt forgiven and I went to a public university. The billionaires are hoarding it all. Nothing is meant to trickle down, so none of it does. If this budget reconciliation goes through, it will lead to more struggling and poverty and excess deaths. Us on YouTube are probably not at that end of this, but we could be at any day because there is no social responsibility taken for the fact that bad things happen, you get sick, you get laid off, whatever, and you deserve to have a way to not just die when that happens. The fact that this is happening when a loud contingent of the people pushing the cruelest policies are supposedly Christian, is just the icing on top. Jesus is too woke. He didn't actually mean to feed the poor and treat the foreigner well. He couldn't have.

author: @einveru6458
text:
0:22 Girlllll. Why are you paying for a 2 bedroom apartment on $12.50 an hour? I can barely secure a 1 bedroom on $21 an hour without a guarantor.

$12.50 is obviously peanuts but there are so many solutions to her problem.

A. Sublet the other bedroom and save yourself some money. 

B. Apply for housing assistance and or food stamps. Most cities have welfare offices/programs. 

C. When your lease ends, consider renting a smaller apartment.

If she were to get a roommate and ebt, she would be able to afford to work less hours, giving her more time to look for higher paying jobs or even time to start side hustles

i love the words "prioritize later" - you work hard now, to have it better later down the line. you resolve that conflict with your partner now, in order to have a relationship later. you put in effort now for some improvements of your life afterwards, may they be material or not. and this later improvement is the kind of gratification that makes hard or boring or bad things endurable or even enjoyable. 
work stopped fullfilling this idea. 
you used to work, to not only survive but also put something to the side, go on holiday sometimes, have a nice dinner with friends or family, buy that new shiny thing that you always wanted and worked half a year for or whatever. 
now you work to survive and all those things to prioritize for later still stay out of your reach unless you earn quite a bit above average or put in even more work, second job now sacrificing other things that are important to you that you can't buy with money later down the line: time with kids friends and family and your mental and/or physical health.

author: @AKHalex
text:
The issue is essentially that we have a job market and work schedule that is made for 1 income and 1 stay at home parent, but an economy that requires everybody to work full time. 

It used to be the case that a single income was enough to raise a family, buy a house and save up a bit. And then you could have a stay at home spouse to take care of a lot of the practical stuff at home. The one doing the house work didn't have to get a job, and then one working their 40 hour per week job had less responsibilities and tasks at home. Now, even two incomes are not always enough to just pay for rent and save up, let alone buying a house or going on vacations, and you now have to clean and cook when you come home.

author: @SaintAnimus
text: You say you aren't anti-capitalist.  Why not?  I agree that optimization is the issue here in a lot of ways.  That's exactly why I am anti-capitalist.  Capitalism optimizes profit.  What if we had a system that optimized health and happiness?  As a mental health professional you must acknowledge the suffering capitalism lays on people in the name of profit.  Curable diseases spread and evolve because people can't pay for medicine that is easily produced.  The daily drudgery of working just to survive is such a heavy weight on people's minds that *you made a video about it*.  I don't understand how anyone can say that capitalism is a positive force on this planet.  Whether the owning class forces you to do a task by putting a gun to your head or by making you homeless and hungry, it is still coercive by its very nature.  What is the difference between slavery by chain and whip and slavery by homelessness and starvation?  Capitalism has even optimized putting people in prison!  Why do the rich get to pay fines for stealing MILLIONS while a bank robber goes to prison for life?  Sure, an armed bank robber may represent a more clear and present danger to life and gets punished severely, but the CEO who embezzles a pension fund, resulting in multiple suicides, gets off with a slap on the wrist.  Make it make sense.

author: @Nermalton77
text:
I love the analogy of "the meta has been optimized". In economical terms what happens is that we live in a world where the struggle of capital vs labour has tilted a lot to favor capital, compared to how it used to be in the 50s. This way, the wealthiest shares of our society own much more of the resources, and get a much higher share of the newly generated wealth that is produced. This way, they are able to charge you much more rent for us of their real estate, while paying less for your work. 
The wealthy people in the world have managed that by "figuring the meta", that is, automating production to get rid of need for labour, finding ways to pay less taxes, increasing their influence on politics, pushing for de-regulation, removing barries for worldwide movement of capital, etc. 
I agree with Dr. K focus on trying to understand what you can do to improve your situation. But on a societal level we need to discuss how to keep this people from figuring out the meta, for example by normalizing the idea of wealth taxes

author: @Rek-Lore
text:
It's hard to square the circle of wages vs house prices. It's like trying to reconcile two fundamentally incompatible ideas or solve an unsolvable problem...

And the strangest part is that you're right Dr. K. We cannot blame the very system that caused the problem, as unfair and sad that it makes us. We cannot allow our internal circuitry to be affected by the external circumstances that are outside of our control.

Being "pissed off" or "anxious", or having "fear" about these external circumstances drains us from our internal storehouse of energy and motivation. Technology dependence, sensory over-stimulation, and stress-eating are just some examples of emotional exhaustion. These hijack our short-term, near future, emotional circuitry parts of the brain with the promise of relief from the uncontrollable external circumstances, but ends up further depleting us from the very storehouses of motivation and energy that we need to break ourselves out of this rut.

I've started waking up at 4:30am to frontload the low dopamine activities (mindfulness, writing paragraphs for my book, video editing, reading books, research) before I go to work at 9:00am. After work I'm exercising now, and trying to get into the habit of a second session of mindfulness. I haven't struck the optimal balance yet, hence why I'm watching YouTube on a Monday morning before work, but I do recognise how much more productive I've been over the last 3 weeks of adapting to this schedule.

Side note: the volume of these videos are quite often lower than standard on YouTube, so ads and other videos seem really loud, would be nice if the audio was mastered a bit better.

author: @colinkamoda9502
text:
I wish I could work forty hours. People don't realize how much free time they have working a single job. I work two iobs, one full time one part time. 9am-9pm four days a week, and two days from 11am-9pm, I get fridays off. Add an hour of driving each day, 45 minutes to an 1.25 hours of hygiene, 20 minutes of eating, I get an 1.5 hours to 2 hours each day if 'free time' where I clean or do laundry or watch youtube while being exhausted. I sleep about half of my friday away because I am worn out and the rest of my single day off is spent doing the rest of life stuff such a grocery shopping, doctor appointments, ect. I have about 2 to 4 hours free time a week where I don't feel exhausted, so its hard to motivate myself to develop a skill or find some meaningful way to live in the world today with that little bit of time. I am not using exhausted like this women from the clip, I am truly exhausted, I could (and have on my one day off) sleep for 20-36 hours.

Edit: I like my jobs. Dr. K destroyed my excuses, lol. I just don't have any meaningful relationships outside of work and definetly have some health issues. I say I watch youtube after work, but really I listen to youtube on the couch for about and hour and then go to sleep because I want something in my life besides sleeping and being at work.

text: It really helps to automate a lot of tasks you need to do as well. Like order groceries online for delivery or pickup. Clean a little bit each night when you get home so you don't have much to do on the weekend. And focus on getting through the non-negotiable tasks and not worrying so much about the rest. Put your efforts towards your passions and furthering your education and spending quality time with kids ect. So much of our tiredness comes from anxiety and stress. And that comes from worrying about things outside of our control or worrying about keeping up with society and other people. A lot of it is our mindset. As long as you have a comfortable home and have a bit of money for savings you are successful and that's something to be proud of! Yes, you can strive for more but being proud of yourself for surviving a tough world goes a long way. üòä

text:

Luckily it took me ~26 years to figure this out. 
I am 26 years old.

author: @sheolcodemonkey4027
text: I make pretty decent money, but even so, I find myself adopting a personal policy of giving the bare minimum, because I'm sick of my life being about my job. I have personal goals and ambitions that I've just been putting little to no time and effort into because work drains me so dry that I have nothing left to give most days. Since I started intentionally half-assing it to give myself more brainpower left over at the end of the day, and spending it on music and writing instead of letting the job live rent free in my head quite so much, I've been much happier and seeing actual progress in those goals. People want to ask why we don't just work harder? Simple: because why the fuck would we do that?

author: @CozyGen
text: I have been going nonstop for about two months, high stress due to having to move out of a home I absolutely adored (but way way too expensive) and the potential of losing my job. I have been in my new place almost a month. This week I had my first couple genuine days off. I promised myself I would do *nothing*, so that's pretty much what I did. And then I got a massive headache, body aches, stomach ache, brain fog, fatigue, depressed, just wanted to sleep. I talked to google gemini about it and it said "you're probably going through burn out based on the information you've given". I had an opportunity to go back to work for a few hours in the middle of my resting period so I took it, all my symptoms instantly went away. Then they came back after I got home. This is the first time I truly understood why people pass away after they retire. They finally get a chance to slow down and relax, but their body doesn't know how to do that so it just gives up. It's a terrifying reality. We really don't have a choice but to keep going.

i know you're saying that food and shelter and stuff wasn't guaranteed, but vagrancy is illegal now and wildlife is in short supply. this wasn't always the case.

our rivers are polluted and our people are surveilled. people don't talk about this, but native americans made america "easy mode" by planting blackberries EVERYWHERE.  i'm not that old but even as a kid i remember edible plants and animals EVERYWHERE and we've been eroding that year after year to the point where you could feasibly forage for survival when i was a kid and now you just can't. we pay people to poison the native and wild plants and that ends up in our water supply, killing fish. no "weeds" means no deer and rabbits and poisoning the water kills all the little bugs and filter feeders that fish eat.

we have made our environment uninhabitable and turned employment in the US into serfdom 2.0.

text: I agreed with a lot of what Dr. K said here, but I wanted to point out that, until AI or Automation fully replaces basic human labor, we will have our drug store clerks, fast food works, janitors etc. All these jobs no matter how small are still cogs in the giant machine of the modern world. If you are a single who had any sort of difficult upbringing in the lower class, you are fully aware of how hard it is to escape those roles once you are in them. Giving anecdotes and personal stories when the vast majority of people are trapped by debt traps and the "optimization" of the market is meaningless and does nothing to address the people who, no matter how hard they try, their bank balance decreases every 2 weeks. Rigged game from the greediest generation the planet has ever seen. Thanks boomers.

author: @BiggieChungulus
text:
Gonna soft disagree with Dr K here. I work 60+ hours a week in a high volume catering kitchen. He's right, once you essentially level up, the grueling hours get more tolerable. Having a baseline of fitness helps too, just more shit to do with your already limited free time. For me it's bouldering. However even at this level, it still is utterly exhausting. Because I have a pretty good balance of sleep diet and exercise I still wake up every day more or less replenished, but some days it's genuinely an uphill battle just getting out of bed. Ya know that Berserk meme with guts screaming? That's what it feels like battling my fried CNS for control over what I do sometimes. That's what it feels like to get out of bed some days. I say all this because I'm deeply empathetic to those like the person in the beginning of this video. I consider myself relatively reselient, hard working, and athletic and it's THIS hard for me. How the fuck are normal people even still surviving? 

So basically Dr K says to progressive overload. 15 minutes of work here. 15 more minutes there. Over time. Slowly working your way up. Basically this does work kind of, but just because you become more able to tolerate extremes doesn't mean you don't feel the extremeness of whatever you're tolerating.

author: @mimiminti
text:
I appreciate Dr. K approaching this topic, however I feel like this discussion is incomplete. I think the problem is not optimization as much as the price of rent is far above a fair representation of value transferred. My small landlord draws about 20K/month from all his properties but he does literally ZERO repairs and I live in a slum. I see it with big landlords too. The average rent being 1600 is the problem. They have leveraged the fact that housing is an imperfect market where tenants have no way to ensure reasonable prices for rent. I think there is no individual way out of it and that we need to talk to our neighbors to form use tenant organizations to ensure repairs, and eventually form city level tenant unions that can fight for tenant rights on a state level. Right now landlords lobby to pass the legislation, and real estate entangled governers like Jared Polis will veto solutions, such as the bipartisan bill on curbing the insanely unethical rent pricing algorithm. 

My energy comes from having a home where I can form healthy living habits, but that has gotten harder as I've had to take on roommates. There is another thing to be said about the stagnation of wages, but I think the landlords are the biggest problem in the room.

author: @hollowedboi5937
text:
Hold up, $2000 a month if it‚Äôd a 40 hour work week is like a little less than $12 an hour. $1660 two bedroom apartment with $340 left over. 

Depends state to state but that‚Äôs below minimum wage in 2025 for a 40 hour work week at a well too expensive place. Absolutely sucky situation but I‚Äôd ask this‚Äì

Is there any jobs that are minimum wage or $15 or higher for a full time work week?
Is there any other options of living that are below $1200 that you can afford that keeps your non-negotiables (ex: I will not go without wi-fi, heating, etc.) 
Do you have any support network in terms of family, friends, peers, someone or some group or organization to go to?
If all else is not possible at the moment, yeah what Dr.K says: is there any way of making work not as bad or even enjoyable? How do you spend that time outside of work, is there a lot on the phone, bad sleep, no time outside? How‚Äôs your diet? 

This puts a lot of responsibility on her, but if no one is coming to help you, what can you do in your situation aside from just endure? For how long will you endure? America sure as shit ain‚Äôt cut out for most of us, it needs reform on so many levels. And yet we‚Äôre still in it suffering at different levels, so that sounds like what Dr K is saying: to figure out what you can actionably do despite where you are and how awful it is. 

All that said, no doubt we agree that America ain‚Äôt fair and not livable most of the time. Reform and change is needed. It sucks for a lot of people rn. No arguing there.
