author: @LuisCabanzonGutierrez
text:
Many fair points have layed out in the video, but I think if she watched this she is very likely to be on the same spot in 5 years.

What she needs to hear is that:
1. It is hard to make use of your free time of you really dont know what to do with it. Find hobbies/passions and lean on friends. I've been in tjat situation where I was spending most evenings at the office because I just didn't have anything better to do, and then weekends were either some more work or regretfully watching the weekend pass by while waiting for Monday to come again. It's hard to have the motivation of having a life of you are clueless about how that life should look like for you.
2. I'm not based in the US, so I can't tell if that salary and/or rent are reasonable, but regardless of thinking how she wants her career to look like, the VERY FIRST THING she needs to address is ACCOMODATION. Either she moves back with her family (a legit choice, provided she comes up qith a longer-term plan), finds flatmates (I had some for years, evem while making way more than than her), or move to a one-room flat. Getting a flatmate would be the easiest, and that's more than $800 extra each month.

Psychology and retrospection are fine, but in the end one always has to work on practical solutions.

author: @namastest6470
text: First of all high housing prices, food costs etc. is a systemic problem from capitalism.   Housing Companys do indeed optimise the costs perfectly. But the reason why they can do this, is the system we life in. Capitalism and nonsocialistic politics. Dont blame it on individuals please. author: @Necron1018Gaming
text:
Times are definitely different and will always change. I think budgeting should‚Äôve been brought up in response to her video. Phones are expensive and there are cheaper options. How many streaming services are you paying for, why not cut down some of those expenses. How much do you eat out and not cook at home? Why does she have a 2 bedroom apartment when she doesn‚Äôt talk about living with anyone else, she could rent that spare bedroom. There are many things that we do now that our parents and grandparents didn‚Äôt have or did much less. Cut down on expenses, batch cook meals, try to ask yourself what you need to do versus what you want to do. 

I have a one bedroom apartment. I freeze food that I cook so meals are easy to heat up. I eat out once or twice a week and cook everything else. I go to the gym 4 times a week. I only have one streaming service and that‚Äôs Amazon prime (paying year is cheaper option). I track my expenses and my income and budget my spendings. I use my cellphone for years and years and rarely get a new one, I‚Äôve only bought 2 smartphones in 12 years. And I use the cheapest plan (pay as you go, not a full plan).

author: @Soaring_Penguin
text:
My dad doesn't have a college education, in fact he never even went to high school. He graduated from 9th grade and started working immediately. He has been working as a driver his entire life (truck, taxi, driving instructor, tourist bus, handicap bus, etc..) and the only time in his life he didn't have work was for a few months during the 08 crisis. He retired at 65 and is now living a fantastic life and travels abroad 2-3 times a year on mini-vacations. He's seeing the world and experiencing things.

Meanwhile, I'm 33 years old, I have 18 years of education (twice that of my dad), graduated from college with A+ in everything, and the best thing I can get is an exhausting job that I hate, earning just enough to get by. I haven't travelled anywhere for 14 years, and the last time was a trip with my dad that he paid for. I literally just want the same kind of life that my dad had, or even a little less! How did tings get so bad so fast, I just can't comprehend it.

author: @helendunn9905
text:
Bullshit! My boomer parents taught to work hard 24/7 they lived through the poverty experienced by their parents during war time and the depression. They went through 18% interest on mortgages. They only paid off anything when dad retired on a forced early retirement at 60. He was the first generation to have super, but Mum kept working through necessity. They taught me life is hard, work is hard, and it's a struggle.
This young lady is a grandchild of boomers, or an even older generation. As a daughter of boomers, I am 50. She is 25 at the most, she would be the age of my children if I had any!!

The boomers saw hardships,  no generation has ever been exempt.
It's time to stop the cycle of work being a cycle of fear. I have so much work trauma because of bullying, being AudADHD, not meeting undeclared expectations. I have tried Engineering, Accounting, Administration, Barista, Medical Secretary, Project Management, now I'm a Cleaner. Been in so many industries, building services, food manufacturing, pharmaceutical, engineering, medicine, massage, chiropractic, naturopathy, IT manufacturing, IT software, education, telecommunications, insurance, hospital, formal wear hire, retail, audiology, commercial & domestic cleaning. 
I am exhausted from trauma, from Autism, ADHD, Dyslexic, Dyspraxic and being high masking because you know no employer likes someone who doesn't fit in the box. I am so notnwhatever normal is, no matter how hard I have tried.
I have been in therapy since I was 16. Going through various issues is exhausting and make sit hard to be motivated to self care, clean, apply for work etc. 
Only discovered Autism ADHD recently but can't afford a diagnosis, which wouldn't help anyway because this label targets me as "difficult" and definitely a "risky hire".
I already trying to run up hill here ... üò¢

author: @shadoekid
text: The common thread in all of this, in unrestricted and unregulated capitalism. Capital doesn't care that there isn't upward social mobility; in fact it thrives on it! Capital doesn't care that we can't afford our houses, food, medicine, bills, and leisure time at the levels of payment available to a majority of the working class. College education, trade skills, and even starting a business or side hustle can be ways to break out of the mold but even that isn't a guarantee of success or comfortability. After all, the 2008 recession is what created the stereotype of four year degree millennials working as baristas. Housing, food, medicine, education, are all rights to life in a modern society as rich as the United States. All of this is to say that there are ways we can learn to cope under our modern society with a lack of upward social mobility, or we can unite, unlock class consciousness, and CHANGE OUR WORLD! JOIN YOUR LOCAL DSA, OR PSL CHAPTER, GET ORGANIZED, AND LETS MAKE THE WORLD WE WANT COMRADES!

author: @inigocilveti3287
text:
I'm honestly quite disappointed in dr k here. He's basically saying: the world sucks now because rich people have figured out how to extract every gram of productivity from you, but then he says "I'm not anti-capitalism" and basically "you need to suck it up" ("the more you do it, the more resilient you will become to it!") and, if not, "you might have a mental illness" or "you need to use your phone (which has been optimized for making you addicted to it) less". 

I know it's harder for americans to understand, since you have an extreme form of capitalism and have been even more brainwashed by it than most other first world countries, but the solution to this is to take wealth back from the rich, probably through taxes. This is what made the baby boomer generation have oportunitines. 

Humanity is wealthier as a whole now that it has ever been and life still sucks for most people, and the reason for this is inequality. There is a _lot_ of wealth, and the rich have most of it.

The only solution for that is organization. Sure, you can probably do some stuff like Dr K said to make your life suck less, but this will only get you so far. Voting for billionaries and expecting them to have your interest at heart is ludicrous.

Organizing to take wealth back from the rich is hard, but it's doable, it has been done before, when people got fed up. 

Take a look at Gary Stevenson's youtube channel if you find what I'm saying to be unreasonable.

For others I'd say that giving up makes it a self fulfilling prophecy and that at least today there is an appeal of being ahead of others by putting effort into improving your life, but honestly personally \i don't even know why I even continue even when I've avoided the struggles of life.

author: @flowartjuggling7772
text:
Hey Dr. K,

I've learned a lot from you so far, and I'm really grateful for that. Now that we're getting into economics and the reasons why it's becoming harder for people to make a living, I hope I can show you something in return.

The reason why we‚Äôre being paid less and less over time isn‚Äôt because of efficiency or because we‚Äôve ‚Äúfigured things out.‚Äù It‚Äôs due to the inflationary monetary system.

Technological progress and increased efficiency should actually mean that everything becomes cheaper over time, because we can produce things more effectively. But here‚Äôs the problem: let‚Äôs say people have become, on average, 30% more efficient at producing goods. That would typically lead to deflation ‚Äî a 30% decrease in prices.

However, since central banks have a mandate to aim for 2% inflation (i.e., price increases), they will actively work against that deflation. This means any natural deflation is systematically eliminated, and on top of that, an additional 2% inflation is deliberately targeted.

Unfortunately, the incentives are also set up so that central banks always manage to "achieve" those 2% inflation figures. And since they calculate inflation themselves, they also have an incentive to make the numbers look better than they are ‚Äî for example, by adjusting the basket of goods (used to measure inflation) to include cheaper or lower-quality items that have lower price increases, while removing higher-quality goods that have risen more in price.

On top of that, the CPI (Consumer Price Index) only includes consumer goods ‚Äî it excludes assets like real estate.

Since rising credit levels don‚Äôt necessarily lead to a proportional increase in demand for consumer goods (but rather for assets like real estate), asset prices tend to rise far more than the CPI does.

Because wages are usually only adjusted according to the CPI ‚Äî which, as mentioned, is both manipulated and incomplete ‚Äî real wages fall over time in terms of what people can actually afford. That‚Äôs why it keeps getting harder to make ends meet, even though, on paper, it looks like wages are keeping up with inflation.

So the real issue isn‚Äôt efficiency ‚Äî it‚Äôs the inflationary monetary system.

Much love, and please keep up the amazing work you're doing!

author: @selbie
text:
Millennial here. Something I've noticed over the years with enjoyment of work, and maybe it could be expanded on a bit:
The term "Enjoy" doesn't mean "I'm having fun and everything is smiles and happiness" - unless you are in a rare, super lucky situation. Try to frame it as "I feel my work is important, I know what I need to be competent and accomplish the work, and I have the autonomy to complete it". If you are passionate about something and are rewarded in the ways that matter to you, the time you spend working on it becomes insignificant, and the tiredness you feel each day / week is more like a levelling-up experience.
That can fluctuate depending on the context and role you are in, but when it starts to trend toward "not important", "not clear" and / or "not autonomous", then you are probably not enjoying the work. Dr. K has great videos on burn-out relating to this.
Then there is the tiredness factor of this video:
Older generations benefitted from the relative calm of life without the internet and everything was accessed through physical participation - which set up resilient habits to live well on (in general). This is what Dr K is referring to about exercise and tiredness. An athlete's tiredness is no different to an amateurs tiredness, except for the amount of practice they've had at getting tired and noticing improvements over time. 
The problem we face now is that we are oversaturated with digital access to infinite information, so the older generations have the advantage of those established habits but the younger gens are less likely to have those natural skills and some don't know HOW to step away from it - something that used to be normal AND WAS EASY TO ACCESS before the internet became ubiquitous in the late 90s / early 2000s. We might have a few select advantages, but there are so many external debuffs stacked on us that simply pushing a high amount of effort is quickly negated by the elite endgame players. 
So society now has no choice but to apply substantial effort to avoid the saturated noise so that we can fit enjoyment of things back in to our pre-internet biology. We actually have to perform work on enjoyment of work, so that the work we perform is actually enjoyable :P

author: @vincentlius1569
text:
As a 23-year-old Gen Z professional with two years of work experience, I've developed a clear "what I can do about it" philosophy for navigating my career and personal growth.

Embrace Calculated Risks
Playing it safe won't get me where I want to be. I'm choosing to embrace more risk, particularly in my investments and career path. For instance, I'm shifting away from overpriced blue-chip stocks and opting for more dynamic investments. While most of my current portfolio is in gold ‚Äì a hedge against potential global instability ‚Äì I'm also willing to job-hop more frequently. This includes taking on roles with the inherent risk of not passing probation or being among the first for layoffs.

Master the AI Revolution
I believe we're at a pivotal point, similar to how ancient Rome transitioned to a slave-based economy, ultimately leading to chaos due to unemployment. Our world faces a similar threat with the rise of AI. To thrive, we must learn to leverage AI to automate work through products and services. My focus is on deeply understanding how to build, design, market, and utilize AI.

Cultivate Hope and Connection
As highlighted in various discussions, maintaining a sense of "future prospect" is crucial for sustained energy and motivation. My personal goal is to gain experience in a developed country for 3-5 years before returning to Southeast Asia. This offers significant leverage due to currency differences. It's about finding your own version of "hope" that fuels your drive.

Prioritize "Fast Recharge" Hobbies and Meaningful Friendships
I used to maintain an intense 12-14 hour workday, including weekends, balancing a startup job and college. While I gradually built up to this workload, I found myself completely exhausted and lost after about 1.5 years. Now that I've graduated, I prioritize "fast recharge hobbies." Instead of mindlessly scrolling social media, I'm selective about consuming highly recommended anime or manga. I've also gravitated towards upbeat music and, most importantly, I dedicate time to friends with whom I have genuine connections. I'm not afraid to cut off relationships that don't serve me or limit interactions to once a quarter if that's what's best for my well-being.

author: @jouniosmala9921
text:
She has TWO bedrooms in an expensive area. It used to be here that at her age two bedrooms meant two salaries splitting the bill either through being roommates or spouses. Or alternatively there was a man who either had done the early grinding in salary ladder or did overtime and paid it all so that he would have a wife at home that handled the household chores.   Another thing that has changed is that we have more things that we no longer consider optional.  Let me state my expenses around age of 20.  Relatively cheap internet, single bedroom with shared kitchen and bathroom, macaroni with few cheap additions to it, city bus pass, electricity and water was included, but those are not much either today. It's was temporarily going backwards in lifestyle from living in parents place. And that's the sad truth. Sometimes you need to make temporarily sacrifices to have either time or money to invest in the future. 

Modern job matching is like modern dating apps. Women have to weed out too many bad candidates and get occassionally duped to pick a terrible one because most good ones already have got selected out of market.  Men have too low rate of getting selected and get disillusioned by their prospects. And those who would get selected by woman would be selected by all the women and picks hottest or picks multiple and woman thinks she could get one that had unlimited options.  The market works same way with employers and employees with very low friction application both sides having different problems to deal with.

text:

1) I try to limit my social media use at work, I noticed that using social media made it hard to focus on work afterwards and drains energy way faster

2) even if I feel exhausted after work, I understand that it is "psychological" exhaustion because most of the time i didn't do physical work so I try to force myself to do chores anyway to have less packed weekends, and guess what! After you break through that exhaustion and start doing some physical activities I feel energised for the remaining of the evening

author: @highndry18
text:
Inflation has gotten everything to be more expensive compared to before and salaries aren't scaling properly with that. People now have to work very long hours just to make ends meet, and just barely so, hence why the term "wage slave" gets thrown around so often. 
In the past a blue-collar worker and sole breadwinner in the household used to be able to support their entire family's expenditure. That's no longer the case. Housing costs also have skyrocketed to an astounding degree. Rent for even a single bedroom has also gone up a lot. 
Depression and other related mental illnesses have also been on the rise among people starting as young as during their teens due to a number of reasons as well.

The Dr didn't even offer to wean him off the meds! He left him with no meds and had him go. God so kind a friend recommended us to mushrooms (psilocybin) precisely. After his experience with shrooms five years ago till now there's no more ADHD, depression and mental disorder. Shrooms are life changing. There is no way you can put into words what it feels like...

author: @REGRIGBY5678
text:
I like how you talk about it being expectations based. An anecdote from my own life. I went though all of elementary, middle and high school never procrastinating and studying a lot and making sure I got all straight As cuz I was told BY THE SHCOOLS that I needed to do that to get into a good college so I could get a good job and live a good life. My parents never really hounded on me cuz I did get straight As all the time. So then I get into the good college, and again, I never procrastinating and studied a lot and made sure I got straight As (most of the time) so I could then get a good job. I also played a sport in college like I did in school growing up and I wanted to play more. So I took a masters program at the same college. Same thing again, don't procrastinate use all the campus resources, study hard. I graduated at the top of the class for my cohort. So then I'm like, "okay sick now I get to get a job and be set the rest of my life". A couple months go by, no real progress with interviews. "Oh that's okay its the summer and I'm enjoying having finished all my schooling thats fine". I move back in with my parents, 2 more months go by, no job. They're like, "hey man you need to have a job" and I'm like "I thought I was supposed to have one by now. I did all the steps, I sacrificed having a ton of fun because I was forwarding thinking. Trying to better my future self." A couple more months go by and I find some part time work to appease my parents. I still haven't found a job related to my masters degree after over a year. Finally after a couple more months I get an offer to work full time, its not very much pay, but at least its something. And I end up having to move across the entire country to do it. I think for a lot of people who are around my age (im 24 rn) its just sucks to feel like you followed the path you were told to follow and check all the boxes, but life just doesn't actually work that way. It kinda feels like we got lied to. And then we're expected to just hate ourselves and suffer so people who are super rich can get even richer. 

A second anecdote related tertiary to what the girl int eh video was saying. I truly and honestly have no clue how people in the generations before us had 9-5 jobs and were able to live healthy lives. I guess maybe they didn't/don't if you look at the illnesses so many people have. But like I mentioned I played a sport in college and I still play it now. And look, I wasn't good enough to go pro, but I was around people who did and we were all on the same team and so we'd do the same habits. Tracking all your calories, making sure you're eating the right macros, optimizing your sleep, working out at the gym, training sessions, mental performance work, just general therapy and relaxation time to make sure you perform at your best. Working 8 hours a day makes it EXTREMELY difficult to take care of your health. You're stuck at work for those 8 hours unable to leave, so you need to do your gym time before or after, but you also need to make sure to meal prep your lunch so you can eat something nutritious at work lunch. So you need to sort out when you can go to the gym and when you can prep your meals. That already cuts some hours out of your day. Then you have to commute to and from work and to and from the gym. You can choose to do that before work or after work. Either of those choices will impact when you go to sleep. But you need to make sure you can get at least 8 hours of sleep to perform well. When its all said in done you basically have 2 hours left in each workday to use on leisure activities. At least in my experience. And maybe this is the privilege talking, but how is that enough time. And this is if you have the drive to ACTUALLY be able to do the relaxing stuff. Like the girl said its exhausting working. I'd never experienced stress in school because I would work ahead to finish all my assignments and prepare for my tests. You have a rewarding period at the end that you work towards. That's what we were taught in school. But that's not what a 9-5 is like. IT. NEVER. ENDS. There is no test, there's nothing to study for, there's no end. Why the heck are we taught this workflow pattern for our entire lives if that's not what the real world is like? No wonder people don't eat healthy, no wonder they don't work out, no wonder they get poor sleep. Doing all those things to stay healthy takes some work and discipline, but now you're getting yelled at by your boss at work, in a constant state of stress with no end in sight. People don't have the bandwidth for all of that. The other generations having the audacity to call us lazy is myopic to me. At least we had the drive to create some positive change for people to live healthier lives. Just because things have been done a certain way for a long time doesn't make them right. And at least to me, in the present day those methods DON'T work anymore. 

Idk, would love to here any other Gen Z people my age give their thoughts on this. Is this how you're feeling too? I know I'm currently trying to leave my current job and find something where you can actually live a healthy life. Maybe that's why so many people just become influencers. Its a way to have a balanced day, even if its mostly pedaling scam products to impressionable people or rage baiting. At least you have the opportunity to have some work life balance. Maybe I'm just salty that I wasn't good enough to go pro, or I wasn't networked enough to get a really good job with my masters, but it does kinda feel like I worked really hard for no reason. Well, anyhoo, these videos always help me out a lot when I'm struggling with stuff so keep up with the good content, and I hope some other people get something from my text walls up there haha. GLHF

author: @Madillusionist
text: The point of having undiagnosed medical condition is so true. For a long as I could remember, I was constantly tired during my late teens and early 20s, like the point was i can instantly fall asleep anywhere, and it turns out i had severe sleep apnea. Now that i've got it treated, the difference is night and day. But here's the kicker, i only realised it during covid lockdowns when I had time to focus on myself and realise that my tiredness is not due to not sleeping enough, and I was able to get the necessary treatment because I'm on a good insurance plan and can afford it. So if someone else with less than ideal situation has sleep apnea or other undiagnosed medical condition, they would be struggling for their whole lives not realising they were playing the game of life with a smaller dice.

author: @SillyBoydo
text:
I work retail in new zealand, and earn 80c above minimum wage, which is now $23.50 per hour. I dont get commission or bonuses, just the wage.
I work 38 hours a week, at the end of every week i have about 700 dollars paid after tax and with an accommodation suppliment benefit from the govt. 
I live with a partner who is studying, split rent,  scrape by on bills and neccessities and can still save a hundered bucks a week. At least. And i dont feel like im going anywhere fast but comparitively i feel very privaleged.

If youre living with flatmates or partners and having to pay $1600 out of the $2000 you earn a month, that's just messed up. The system failed you. If youre living alone, in a 2 bedroom apartment then maybe that is a problem that needs to chage. But I doubt its your fault to begin with. 2000usd still expensive as hell and calculating the exchange rate to nz that would be $840 dollar out of my bank a week which is just impossible. or $420 with a flatmate, still terrible considering food and bills will be spent with the rest of my wages without anything to fall back on.

author: @matthewr7593
text:
Part of the issue is us. We weren't taught how to save and invest money, or get real skills, or stop being on our phones for hours a day while they drain our energy. Hell, I'm approaching 40, a lot of kids younger than me have it way harder than me even interacting face to face and getting out of the house. Then there's other things like this garbage housing crisis that they have us blaming on these big funds that buy up houses but really it's mostly (in my opinion) a bunch of NIMBYism across the country where everyone complains about housing prices but no area wants to step up and BUILD houses. I live in a super liberal area, and I'm liberal myself. They wanted to build new apartments here and everyone FLIPPED OUT. It would increased traffic, it would do XYZ. It's like at some point if all these governments and populations and zoning boards don't allow housing to be built, we're gonna be in a situation like we are now where it's super hard to buy a home. 

We are also weaker in many ways fundamentally. My parents both commuted 90 minutes plus back and forth into the city, they'd leave the house around 6:30ish and come home around 7 PM. They didn't grow up with money and they gladly did it for good money. For us now we think going back to the office isn't even a fair thing. I'm not saying it is or it isn't, but things bother us way more now than they ever did before. 

I bet for 90% of us, and I'm not excluding myself, if they audited their average week they have spent at least 30+ hours scrolling on social media, playing video games, watching tv, browsing reddit, etc. We need to figure out how to take our minds and our focus back and it's REALLY difficult. Also is it just me or did 99% of commenters not watch the video and assumed Dr. K said what they think?

author: @CripicalThinking
text: I think this video needs a little more nuance or at least a note of caution - especially since there are now many more people with postviral fatigue conditions following the COVID-19 pandemic, and it has been shown that exercise is actively harmful if you have certain kinds of post viral illness or myalgic encephalomyelitis. There is of course also a psychological component to many kinds of chronic fatigue syndrome, but there have been cases where people have literally died because they have been prescribed graded exercise therapy, because their chronic fatigue was not solely psychological or mental, but rather followed a viral infection which changed the physiological mitochondrial energy metabolism mechanism on a cell level, and we finally have more biomolecular research to to show the physiological mechanisms behind exercise prescriptions harming certain groups of people with MECFS. Given the Dr K is a medical doctor, I would generally expect a little more caution in giving this type of advice to a generation of young people who have just lived through a pandemic that caused post viral illness on an extremely large scale.

author: @WARPAINTandUnicorns
text:
Also factor in how many hours a day do you commute. My Dad would have to commute for 6hrs a day in the 90‚Äôs to his office work because we couldn‚Äôt live close the GTA jobs at the time without working in the negative.

I knew growing up I could not ask help with homework because my Dad was coming home at around 8-9pm every day based on traffic congestion. I was also either an after school day care or a latch key kid when I was 11 so I had to do the work on my own.
 
Also did that 6 hrs a day commute for 4 months and any critical or creative thinking abilities were severely shot with my un diagnosed ADHD needed for my job. This was before social media was sapping our attention in 2008. ü§™

The average person commutes up to 2 hrs per day for work. This is considered normal but also taxes you as you spend those hours hyper focused on the traffic around you just in case someone makes a mistake.

text: I've gotten to the point where even when I'm working over 8 hours some days (over 40 hours a week isn't unsual for me at all) I still have energy to go spar or game with my buddies, spend time with family, and work out. Hell, I usually workout before AND after work.  There's absolutely days that I still fall into fatigue or get very frustrated and question why I'm doing any of it.  But, then I also have a family and friends that care for me and whom I care for as well which makes all the difference in the world. I also have my health now which makes A MASSIVE difference.  I also know what it is like to not have my health, and then making it through work is much much harder and doing anything other than work is a big challenge (yes illness is a major disadvantage). Even though I'm relatively happy with my lot there's deep problems with how things are setup more generally speaking (I'm talking from a USA centric standpoint as well here).

author: @lauraschleifer4721
text: Thank you for acknowledging that the external reality has changed so much for the worse. That being said, why are we looking at the ways to respond to that in such an atomized, individualistic way? The solution to this is not to cultivate the traits of stoicism in order to accept your miserable lot in life, but to band together with others who feel the same way and start building mutually beneficial support systems. There is a whole movement underway to make this happen by building mutual aid based support networks, directly democratic people's assemblies, and collectively owned and run communal lands/housing/schools/food gardens/co-op businesses on the neighborhood, local, regional, national and international levels called the communalist movement. (Not to be confused with the religious factionalism in Asia that is sometimes called 'communalism".) For more information, google Murray Bookchin, the Institute for Social Ecology, Symbiosis Revolution, Cooperation Jackson, Cooperation Vermont, Cooperation Tulsa, Cooperation Humboldt/Denton/etc., the Rojava Revolution, the solarpunk Art Farm in Lexington Kentucky, and the YouTube channels and podcasts Srsly Wrong, Anark and Andrewism.

author: @eddie2000ad
text: i empathize with people struggling right now but honest to god a perspective change is needed for some of these people to survive and then someday thrive, it is true a social contract was broken at some point, we built society to circumvent the REALITY that survival is not guaranteed. at any other point point in history you would be working all day every single day just to survive and it STILL wasn't a guarantee. Yes the system has been unfairly optimized but that can change, and you can also change your circumstances to re-balance it back into your favor, in fact you HAVE to do that. that's what survival is, it is unfair that others might be more privileged or have been in the past but like Dr. K stated complaining about it does NOTHING to help you, and i mean that as sympathetically as i can, i want people to survive and get to a better place, so you have to acknowledge the reality, embrace it, then move forward any way you can to try to change it. this seems to be too emotionally heavy for people to cope with but if you just realize that all of the extra stuff was never guaranteed for most of human history  you might find that even the worst case scenario in modern society is still better than 99% of what humanity had, then you might find the strength to act and move forward. it gets better and if you're resilient and creative enough, you can get ahead

author: @iRiDiKi
text:
"Why You Feel So Drained After Work" Because it's 8 hours of work...?

Jokes aside, let's be real. If you're unhappy in life, if you feel tired as fuck, etc, you need to sit down, think about what needs to change and make those changes. I've been in bad working environments and it sucks, but now I've found a good working environment, life is a lot easier. Same with home situation - had an abusive parent growing up, managed to do the tough thing and get out (after way too long) and it made life so much better and I could actually start my own journey and growth. It's hard to initially make those changes - I get it, the way you feel is inundating and debilitating -  but it's your responsibility to make the actions instead of continuing to push it off and waiting for things to change on their own. I know people will hate hearing this, but if you're unable to save working 40 hours a week, then maybe you need to cut out some overhead costs and budget better or look for a different job or take a comfort cost and share a place or go study something, etc. That discomfort or extra work or material sacrifice that you make, will be a temporary thing because it's working toward a goal of your choosing and believe it or not, is often not as bad as it seems and may even be good for you - you are more capable than you realise you are. It's up to you at the end of the day.

You do not need to be disillusioned. You don't need to trauma dump and make your connection with your own negative feelings stronger in these comments or in some subreddit. Countries of the western world are the best places to live (seriously, romanticising other places or older times and letting that impact your general mood is just arrogant), politicians and peers do hear us and there are plenty of people trying to make things better. Sadly, things do not get better linearly, but they do get better over time. Keep going, keep putting in effort, do your best to be positive, aim for what is important to you and one day you'll feel that you've made it.

But also due to life that hope was then crushed. I promised myself that I will reach the goals I envisioned when I was hopeful, but this feeling of tiredness is overbearing. I am still moving forward, but it feels so sluggish. You're right. My reliance on technology is too high. It is hard when I work a booring office job and not fulfilled with life as is.

author: @goodfortunetoyou
text:
"Human beings aren't good at probabilistic thinking" <- HUGE Understatement. Human beings are famously terrible with probabilities. People find patterns present in random outcomes like stock prices, gambling runs, and goat dice bones. When asked to pick a random number beween 1 and 10, more choose 7 than 1 and 10. 

When students are asked to guess which of a random sequence of coin flips, and a non-random sequence made by hand, is real, they usually choose wrong. People intuitively think the random coin flips have too many runs of heads and tails. So they choose a hand-made option designed to be more uniform.

I absolutely loved the work that I did (croissants, pasta, bread making/baking, etc.) But I had some bad times that included kind of popping off at one of my bosses for his dreadful communication. Recently I decided to go to another place of business where I can see the "vision" just like i could at the bakery, but this time I have a boss that communicates, is very gracious to all of us, and im not lugging around massive amounts of dough. After 4-5 weeks at the new spot I still am not "spiritually" tired at the end of the day and everything is so much easier.

Edit: my other boss is one of the best chefs I've ever known/met in my life. He literally just walks in the room and people work harder, but in a good way, its wild. He gave me his chef knife when I went to my new job. Such an honor.

author: @sivashankarmech
text:
I work in UAE and my work timing is 10 hours. Minimum we work 8 to 5.30. And due to the high cost of living I stay little far & hence morning, evening car drive timing is minimum (30+30 - 1 hours). My office doesn‚Äôt have s parking. So we park far for free parking. So that takes 20 mins. And the time for home to parking adds another 10 mins. So work + commute take 10 to 10.5 hours.

With sleep it goes to 18 to 18.5 hours. Rest is maximum 5.5 to 6 hours max (this is considering no project deadlines & extra work etc.)

And of this 5.5 hours we need to spend time for kids, spouse too.

I want to spend 2 hours daily to play and 30 mins for gym (only 3-4 days) , 1 hour for exercise warmup & cooldown (stretching, meditation, etc.)

I agree fully your concept of 8/8/8 should be the norm (work timing of 8 hours should include commute too. We are commuting for work & not our personal purpose) globally.

But first we have to understand in reality it is impossible for 80-90% of people on this earth.

author: @Gaioehis
text:
Basically, I‚Äôm a dental student in 4th year (the last two years). I‚Äôve always been among the top 3 students, and last year I was actually ranked first. But recently, I‚Äôve been struggling with so many academic problems‚Äîit feels abnormal.

It started with the fact that I can‚Äôt really remember what I study. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs because of the huge amount of information or what, but I‚Äôve reached the stage of clinical practice where I‚Äôm supposed to understand everything and act quickly‚Äîyet my mind feels completely blank.

Another issue is that I regret being among the top students, because:
	1.	The psychological pressure‚Äîeveryone always expects the best from you, while I personally feel like a total failure.
	2.	Jealousy and exclusion from classmates‚Äîbecause my personality is different. I usually just attend lectures, leave, and I only have one close friend. (I also can‚Äôt tolerate the bad behavior and attitude of many of my peers.)

I tried to befriend them but it didn‚Äôt work. Their personalities drain me, and even when I walk away, they still talk about me. And no, this is not a ‚Äúweak personality‚Äù thing. I‚Äôm naturally calm and cold‚ÄîI literally can‚Äôt give any reaction to anything. To the point that classmates doubt how I‚Äôm among the top students, and some even think I get my grades through favoritism, since I‚Äôm quiet, isolated, and socially awkward‚Äîcall it whatever you want.

The important thing is: lately I feel like I have ‚Äúmental decay.‚Äù Even though I live a healthy lifestyle and take care of myself, I just don‚Äôt know why I feel like throwing myself off somewhere to stop the headache in my head.

I‚Äôve also started feeling dumb‚ÄîI can‚Äôt comprehend many things anymore, and I feel like a complete failure. Maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve never been appreciated by my environment, no matter how much effort I put in.

I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôm going with this, but in general, I feel socially stupid yet academically smart‚ÄîI know how to study and get high grades, but I can‚Äôt retain information in my head. And I always feel like everyone else is better than me. That saying, ‚Äútop students are usually stupid,‚Äù is starting to feel true to me.

And honestly, do you want to know why I feel like such a failure? Because I‚Äôm a near-doctor, in 4th year, and yet I didn‚Äôt know how to manage a diabetic teenager who needed an extraction‚ÄîI got a zero. And the professor gave me a look like: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a failure.‚Äù

So yeah, that‚Äôs my situation.

author: @HeavymetalHylian
text:
My husband and I are both experiencing burnout. He wants to lean on me for support, and normally I would want to be there, but I feel like I have nothing left to give. It‚Äôs become an endless loop.

I tend to go emotionally numb and he tends to have heightened emotions. So when something else comes up, he cries, and I am emotionless - he feels like I don‚Äôt care, and I feel like I need to dissociate from my feelings to get through the problem, and I crave the company someone who feels secure (because I feel like I am always the one playing that role and I need a break/switch)

I don‚Äôt feel that either of us is wrong, but I do think we need to find some way to heal besides looking into each other for it. I‚Äôd like to not have to stuff my emotions down and I‚Äôd like for him to not feel tormented by his emotions.

author: @john1215-j3k
text:
I used to wake up tired, drag myself through the day, and crash on the couch at night feeling like I‚Äôd accomplished nothing ‚Äî even though my mind was constantly racing. Coffee didn‚Äôt help anymore, my sleep was broken, and I felt like I was aging twice as fast. I knew I was burnt out but didn‚Äôt know where to start fixing it.
Then I found this book with a 30-day plan that didn‚Äôt ask for perfection ‚Äî just small, daily shifts to reset how I sleep, eat, and deal with stress. Honestly, it helped me reconnect with my body in a way I hadn‚Äôt in years. If anyone feels stuck in that same fog, this is the book that helped me: Reset Your Body and Mind by Morgan Lane.

author: @benjueabba9480
text:
So I've had this for 3 months without stop everyday, all of these symptoms :
Sense of failure and self-doubt.
Feeling helpless, trapped, and defeated.
Detachment, feeling alone in the world.
Loss of motivation.
Increasingly cynical and negative outlook. 
Decreased satisfaction and sense of accomplishment.

Everyday, I sleep 8 hours, at least. But wake up with major stress. I 've taken breaks, I meditate and do yoga daily, I take cold showers and eat only whole foods with regular exercise yet in making decisions, I breakdown and stand there in a melancholic state watching as time passes by at rapid speed. I watch as I develop more and more binge habits and coping habits including this one. I never comment on channels. My memory has faded and my body is becoming more prone to illness. I'm 21. Any suggestions ? other than therapy that I can't afford?

text: I've been struggling with work stress, and it's been a while. I work around 10 hours every day plus the hours I take to commute to my workplace. my workplace is very strict with appearance and customer service. and the thing about my position is that I have a "special" role, and this means I take more work. before I've got this job, I dealt with serious social anxiety, which I wasn't even able to leave my room in that meantime. author: @jkscsgo
text: I'm a university student. I've been experiencing a lot of stress, burnout and on my way to a mental breakdown. Here's the story. I study with full scholarship cause my family is not rich. And in my first year, I failed one important subject, which basically blocked subjects in upcoming semesters. It's okay. I'm going to have to extend my studies by just a semester and likely have to pay for that semester. My family could afford one semester, but not more. What's stressing me out most is that I'm taking this subject again this semester and and I'm afraid of failing it again. I've failed it before just because of a tiny mistake in my lab exam. I've been stressing over it again and again. Because failing it again would be more extension which my family can't afford. Overthinking that I might do mistakes again. But this time, everything is different. I knowy mistake and I'm now even more prepared for that subject. I hope I'll pass this exam and stress will go away. I believe god's on my side. And I want to let everyone who's stressing over exams, work or anything know that nothing is impossible. Just remember: YES WE CAN!

author: @bigman7856
text:
I‚Äôm in the middle of transitioning jobs. I start my new job which offers a standard 8-5 weekday schedule, but my current one is more chaotic and can have me working anytime from 8(almost always 10) through 7:30(8:00 most times). As I make this transition, I am supposed to make use of my free time to travel to the new jobs office and do course work and get accustomed with the role. Though I‚Äôm not necessarily working well over 40 hours, I will have days where I must wake up at 5:00, work from 7AM until 2PM and then go to my current job at 3PM until almost 8PM. It creates the feeling of burnout. 

I feel like the biggest thing I need is a proper diet and sleep schedule. I usually use the latter part of the day for entertainment. Gaming, chatting with friends, spending time with the fam, etc‚Ä¶ though this usually ends up with me staying up later. At my current job, it‚Äôs doable, but the new job‚Äôs work hours are early. I feel like I am constantly rescheduling the times I show up due to how burnt out I feel. If I was working 50+ hours I‚Äôd feel okay about it, but I‚Äôm not even working beyond 40 hours atm.

author: @avoidburnout
text: Avoiding burnout is possible, but unfortunately, burnout can still happen if you let the symptoms go unnoticed.  Pay attention to your mental and physical condition and don't ignore taking care of yourself to reduce your stress. Breaking the cycle of constant stress is a great first action you can take to avoid burnout!

author: @legomaster9190
text:
The realization just hit me quite recently that while I have this and that to do and fix and manage, I should instead start by focusing on my sleep. It's been awfully bad for a longer time now, and (surprise, surprise) it has finally started to affect me. This also for a while now. I'm lucky that I'm at a point in life at the moment that I can turn my somewhat full attention to this.

The rest of the "list" is obviously important too. However, I've learnt that concentrating on a few matters at the time, can provide better results, too. In the past I've done that mistake of trying to fix and avoid stress and so on a multiple level. In turn, that became something that ate itself and caused more harm. So keeping this in mind, I really like the last point that is mentioned in the video, self-love.

author: @STARPHASE
text:
I got a full time job late last year, and work 40 hours, and am AT work for 45 hours a week, as I get an hour long lunch. 
I'm not a morning person, and need to wake up at 7 am to make it to work at 8 am. I had to get myself on a real sleep schedule, as my last job I worked 3 days a week, and didn't have to be there until 10am, and lived a mile away. So, I quickly had to adjust to a reasonable schedule. I'm in bed by 10pm, and wake up at 7am. 

I got to work, I come home and shower, then eat, and from about 7-10 I have 'me' time, in whatever form that takes. I also tend to call out one day a month, and have 2 days planned(and approved) off in March, just to give me a long weekend to unwind and reset. 

And on days where I'm really feeling out of it, I'll take a nap on my lunch. I'll eat, and the time I have left after, usually 45-30 minutes, I'll go to my car and nap in the back seat. I did that everyday for the first 2 months of the job. Now it's just an occasional thing. 

I am certainly not cut out fir a full time job, but I've gotta do what I've gotta do. Things could be worse. I like my job, but that doesn't mean I like working 40 hours a week. So I definitely take the extra steps I need to in order to avoid that burnout.

author: @kritinirmesh1466
text:
I AM suffering from burn-out currently and I can certainly use some help. I am in my last year of senior secondary in India. Exam season is coming closer, and our school just had the 1st pre-board of the season. I have a bunch of competitive exams lined up, starting in January. I thought I was being consistent after experiencing an intense burnout in 11th but ultimately, I am still where I was since the last of board exams in 10th. Honestly, there's some financial issue in my middle-class family and though I love my family, it does not create a good environment for mental health of a teenager who stresses too easily. And if you are an Indian, you would know that Board exams are very crucial for a 12th grader along with the college entrance exams. 

When I talked about my burnout to our school counselor last year exactly around this time, she recommended I take some breaks, try changing my music taste to something upbeat and say positive affirmations. It helped me that time but this time, I'm worried that I've been taking wayyy too many breaks and distracting myself from the stress of studies that I feel like I'm not studying at all. I keep thinking how this is the worst timing for a burnout. And honestly, I think that the burnout never left me since it first affected me in the 2nd term boards of 10th grade.
I my mind I know that I should be studying, but then I suddenly get tired and take a way longer break than intended. I can feel my discipline slipping and when I try to get back at it, I falter in just a few hours. I've been having mental breakdowns because of this recently.

I wanted to discuss this with some sort of professional but considering that I won't be having a normal school day anymore and that I can't afford wasting much time thinking about it, I tried looking online but didn't find anything helpful. So, I am posting my worries in hopes that someone might have some useful advice here...

author: @modernman1240
text:
Burnout essentially means that your own Personal Care has been Sacrificed in pursuit of Outward Rewards. Whether that Pressure has been put on you by yourself or by a boss, take a moment to realize that Nothing is worth your Health 
*Some Preventive measures*
1) Fix the Sleep Schedule
2) Take Sunlight 
3) Vit + Min
4) Avoid Porn & Masturbation (especially Men)
5) Complete yr Responsibilities First 
6) Complete the Stress Cycle: Stress - Rest - Stress - Rest - ......
7) No screen at Night 
8) Meditate before Sleeping

author: @SimplePhysics00
text:
I know that this and other videos focus a lot on Work burnout, but I want to say I believe you can experience social burnout too, perhaps even romantic burnout, especially as an introvert. Currently, I feel like I'm experiencing something between the two. I'm a single male in his 30s now, and it is STRESSING ME THE FFFF OUT that I am single again, and what with casual dating in the state it's in, currently in 2022. I am having trouble falling asleep, can't focus on work, and find my every waking moment is filled with thoughts of "well if I go out and do this or that, maybe I'll meet \*her!\*" or "If I was at this place minding my own business, what would I do if \*she\* walked up to me and started talking?!". I fully realize that these thoughts are just ok - they aren't the healthiest, and they aren't the worst thoughts one could have. But the number/frequency of them that I have, of all different kinds of scenarios... it's just overwhelming. And constant. And honestly annoying. I've gotten to the point where I'm not putting myself out there because I KNOW I'm only doing it to try and do it to find \*her\*. Or someone who I can bother about my needs as a social being. Well, introverted social being, but I still want to be listened to, talked to. I still want to be valued.

So I clicked on this video after several others because I think I'm honing in on this being a burnout problem. I'm burned out over looking for companionship, of hoping to find the *one*, of constantly doubting my every move. I am by no means over this and I have a lot of self work (and self-appreciation) left to do, but this video did make me realize, right at the start, that I need to figure out exactly what is stressing me out, why and how it is doing that, and what I can do to try and resolve it or deal with it. I'm not fully there at the end of that journey yet, but I've started down a path that doesn't look so thick with the weeds of depression or despair. I hope this comment helps someone else find it, and I hope this video finds more people and helps them too. Thanks for reading

author: @TheObsci
text: One thing to keep in mind is that focusing or working for extended periods of time is a skill that needs to be practiced. just like training a muscle or any other skill. It needs to develop incrementally over an extended period of time (basically not in one day). The only other way around this is an extreme intervention or extreme will power.

author: @jeffyeung6103
text:
I've been feeling burnt out for the past 6 months from work. The stress keeps piling on until one day, I went into a mental breakdown. My body triggered some safety mechanism and all my stress melted away, however, at the same time I found it super hard to think straight. That's when I realized if I didn't stop it's going to lead to a long time to recover.

If you're in that state or nearing the state because of constant stress, I recommend taking proper breaks or rest period. No job or school is worth destroying your mental or physical well being. Everything seems so large at that time but later on you realized its not so big at all. I'm quitting my job and going backpacking for awhile. I have enough funds to last me well over a couple months so I'll be taking some time to recuperate. 

If you don't have that opportunity, I recommend following the video. Yet, if its a job, try finding another one. It's not worth destroying your health and well-being over a job. There's plenty out there. If you're in school, follow what the video talks about. Also, maybe think about doing a backpacking trip. You can go on a low budget trip and still experience the world. Don't shirk your responsibility yet make sure it's not the pressure from society, friends, parents or family forcing you into staying at a position you don't want to be.

Burnout is a sign that our body tells us there's something wrong. Something's not right. It's good because then we notice it to start changing our circumstances, routines and lifestyle. You are important and are full of dignity and self-worth. Jesus loves you. You are so important to Him you are worth dying for so that you can know God and be forgiven. Do not give up on yourself. God did not give up on you. You are of great value and worth to Him. Don't give up. If you can't do it, trust in Him. He will give you the strength to keep going each and every day. You are never alone. He is faithful always :) Jesus loves you!

author: @rose.florish
text: Posted this right when I needed it :) I hope you take a small moment out of your day to read this, who ever is reading this, cause I promise you It won't be a waste of your time since it's a helpful piece of advice/information, anxiety is like a fitful child, think of a parent at the store and there child is taking a fit over not being able to get candy in the store they want, if the parent gives into the child yelling and screaming, and gets the candy to make them stop throwing a fit, sure it'll make the child be quiet faster, but then the child will learn that taking a fit gets them what they want and will continue to do so and will even get more persistent with it, but if the parent doesn't get the candy then the child will learn that screaming and taking a fit will not get them what they want, if you think of it this way anxiety is a lot like a fitful child, we tend to give into anxiety witch just teaches it that it can get what it wants by throwing a fit, your anxiety usually wants something from you weather that's not hanging out with a friend cause of social anxiety, or not decluttering cause you don't wanna deal with old things, escaping with playing video games, staying on your phone, or looking up your symptoms on google for a little bit of reassurance cause your anxiety is yelling at you to do so, but if you do it anyways and hang out with your friend or choose not to look up your symptoms your teaching your brain that taking a fit won't solve anything, of course at first this may be annoying to hear this child screaming and yelling at you but if you don't give in and keep persistence eventually you will be dealing with little to no anxiety and your fitful child will understand that taking a fit doesn't get them what they want :) hope this helps <3 (tried making it as gender neutral as possible)

author: @dailydoseofmedicinee
text:
Emotional signs and symptoms of burnout:

Sense of failure and self-doubt.
Feeling helpless, trapped, and defeated.
Detachment, feeling alone in the world.
Loss of motivation.
Increasingly cynical and negative outlook.
Decreased satisfaction and sense of accomplishment.

author: @AsadulAli-s2z
text: I'll be real‚Äîafter finishing Nixorus by Dorian Caine, my first thought was "how the hell is this book even allowed?" It straight-up ripped apart everything school, family, and society taught me about money. No fluff, no motivational clich√©s, just hard, raw truths you won't hear anywhere else. Now I get why this book isn't mainstream‚Äîit's too real. If you find it, grab it before it's gone.

author: @nikkyfacts100k
text: I kept scrolling past people swearing by Nixorus books‚Äîsaying it's stuff "they" don't want us seeing. I got skeptical but still tried. I'm actually annoyed I didn't read it sooner. These books literally made me rethink everything about money. Seriously worth the hype.

author: @tanmay_ratnaparkhi
text: I never had money growing up‚Äîjust constant stress about bills, arguments, and being told "we can't afford it." Honestly, I thought something was wrong with me, until I stumbled across Nixorus books. The moment I started reading, I felt this anger rise‚Äîrealizing I'd spent my entire life kept clueless about money on purpose. It literally felt like discovering a secret I wasn't meant to know. I'm still shocked no one's banned this yet.

author: @Aigenrerated-l4e
text: Saw a ton of hype around Nixorus, they are acting like it changed their whole life overnight. Decided to test it myself. It didn‚Äôt disappoint. Legitimately the first book about money that didn‚Äôt feel fake or watered-down. No regrets at all.

author: @Shekh-vj6vn
text: Man, I thought I knew the rules: work hard, hustle, save every cent. But I always felt stuck. Then someone casually mentioned Nixorus books in a comment somewhere, and I swear‚Äîit felt like accidentally stumbling onto forbidden knowledge. It made me question every single thing I'd been taught about money, wealth, and success. Not gonna lie, I felt like I was cheating the system just by reading it.

author: @southnewmoviee01
text: Kept bumping into comments about Nixorus books, everyone saying they're dangerously honest and almost banned-level info. Eventually, I caved and checked it out. They're right‚Äîthis stuff hits different. It's weirdly addictive, probably because it feels like knowledge you're not supposed to find.

author: @SquaredRooter
text:
A very large percentage of children from this generation were misdiagnosed and prescribed medication they never should have been on. Once they cease taking this medication their brain returns to normal functionality. 
A.D.D is neurotransmitter failure. And working out and changing your environment will do nothing to assist you in overcoming the related symptoms. 
Please do not listen to this nonsense if you have been diagnosed by an actual psychiatrist for having adult A.D.D. I spent my entire life without knowing why I was the way I was. Through correct diagnosis and medication I have changed so much. The problem with the internet is you have non medical professionals giving advice to people who will listen to them. Stick to advice of medical professionals who specialise in this field. Psychiatrist and neurologist. Not an online same day diagnosis or your family general practitioner.

author: @SquaredRooter
text:
Pretty sure you don‚Äôt have ADD. 
You were just misdiagnosed and once you stopped taking the medication that you shouldn‚Äôt have been taking to begin with, your life returned to a normal existence.

author: @gggg1122-y5u
text:
Mine's gotten worse as I've gotten older, now mid 40's.  For me anyway, when I've been on , (what I call), "super grind mode on crack," aka having a very unstable job....pay and hours, and no foreseeable upside in site...I doubled down and took ever little bit of hours I could, often traveling between 3 - 4 different counties a day, for a couple hours each...well did that for 16 years, straight, no days off, ever....the field got worse, I actually got worse, financially via taxes because on paper I did ok but it cost me a lot of extra $$$ to streamline things to achieve that can of schedule.

Very long story short, my subconscious kicks me out of life, so to speak, and shuts me down, physically, like narcolepsy type shut down, if I attempt that ish more than 3 consecutive days in a row.  3 days = 1 day of crashing, 4 or 5, (if I push it chemically with my "lab rat"), 2 days of complete shut down.

Very frustrating as I can achieve a lot within the "on days," just the rest of the world definitely does it operate like this, and thus I'm trying to learn to totally reconfigure my life, once again, ugh.

author: @Kais-o1r
text:
Hello Dan,

I‚Äôm 15 years old boy with ADHD and I absolutely love your videos‚ÄîI‚Äôve watched most of them and I‚Äôve been using your FYP trick (thank you for that!).

This summer, I‚Äôm starting my own business offering car washing and odd jobs around my neighbourhood. I‚Äôve made a logo and I‚Äôm working on a leaflet, but I‚Äôll mainly be doing door-to-door sales so I can learn and practise the skills you‚Äôve taught me.

I don‚Äôt have any social media because of my parents, so I can‚Äôt expand online or get into e-commerce just yet. I also have my GCSEs coming up, and my parents are telling me to focus on studying. I‚Äôm going to try and balance both, as well as going to the gym with my friend.

I also have a mentor who‚Äôs a franchiser, and I‚Äôm learning about investing on the side too. Do you think I‚Äôm doing too much?

My goal is to make ¬£2,400 so I can buy a vending machine and earn some passive income while I‚Äôm at school. I‚Äôm planning to make a deal with my headmaster to place it in the lunch room.

Thanks so much for all the value you give‚Äîit‚Äôs genuinely changed the way I think.

text: I would recommend meds to anyone to try , but I think it‚Äôs too common that people find initial relief wears off over time. Adhd is so exhausting so when you first start taking the meds it‚Äôs almost like your brain will shut off any negative side effects because the relief you feel is so strong off the medication within the 1st few months‚Ä¶ just don‚Äôt kid yourself if you are considering medication , and don‚Äôt ignore it if you start to feel even just a bit of a ‚Äúcrash‚Äù. On medication I don‚Äôt lose my phone (I used to lose several a year) but I am also more agitated. Initially the medication helps with anxiety relief etc , however the meds are most helpful with things like doing work, not losing/breaking things. But it does come with side effects and you shouldn‚Äôt kid yourself because long term it will bite back

author: @FlintAntlers1
text: I've been on ADHD meds since I started grade school, when I graduated I decided I would try my absolute best to become independent off of them. One year later of struggling with brain fog and barely being able to even hold a relaxed conversation. Unable to find a job or make any friends, I caved in to the stress and restarted onto my medication. Since then literally everything in my life has improved, but I still feel terrible that I'm relying on being doped up on a controlled substance to functionally survive no more than anyone else. Not to mention that all the issues return as it wears off each day. I wish I could live without it.

author: @Applevivo14Pro
text:
"During my college enrollment, I initially chose History, Geography, and Political Science as my subjects. However, I soon became uncertain and was influenced by a friend who had opted for English Literature instead of Geography. I decided to follow suit and switched to English Literature, abandoning Geography.

Interestingly, prior to college, I had chosen Mathematics in my 11th and 12th grades, but later regretted not pursuing it further. Instead, I reapplied to reinstate Geography as one of my subjects. After two to three months, I redeveloped an interest in English Literature and decided to pursue it alongside Geography and Economics, in addition to History.

Throughout this process, I experienced persistent confusion, indecisiveness, and an inability to maintain focus on a single subject. These symptoms have led me to wonder if I might be experiencing Adult Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)."

Additional points to consider:

- Do you experience difficulties with organization, time management, and meeting deadlines?
- Have you noticed challenges with self-regulation of emotions, leading to mood swings or irritability?
- Are you prone to impulsive decisions or actions, which might be detrimental to your personal or professional life?
- Do you find it hard to maintain focus during conversations, reading, or other activities?

If you identify with several of these points, it may be helpful to consult a mental health professional for a comprehensive evaluation and guidance.

author: @kaydeleshropshire724
text:
So important to discover the superpower of adhd and thrive. 

I am 49 and female.   So adhd diagnosis wasn‚Äôt a thing while I was a struggling kid.   So to avoid being in trouble constantly I learned hacks

Later in life I sought out the diagnosis and treatment (because females will find the hacks stop working later in life because estrogen regulates dopamine)

But‚Ä¶.i digress (as most good adhd‚Äôrs do)

Along my career journey I stumbled into something a few years ago called agile (bet Dan knows this).   Boy did that framework make sense.  Got mg scrum master and then my coach certs.   

Today I teach mature ages (and also young when interested) what I call being agilistik.   I reimagined the framework for day to day life 

All becomes of ADHD!!! Thank you  Neurospicy Brain!!

author: @StuartHollingsead
text:
If that is the case, i have been on burn out since 2014. Men work differently than women. 
A blizzard in Canada, it is 1950. One power line goes into a town of fifty people. The power goes out. The electrical line worker goes out to the break, climbs 25 feet into the air and fixes the line in 50 mile hour winds. If the line is not repaired, 50 people die. He freezes to death on the pole, but by God almighty, he got the line fixed.
Men operate and work differently. What you call burn out, i call saving a life.

author: @stephanielu7694
text:
I isolate myself because I can't handle people anymore. I can barely handle myself and what's going on in my life. 
As far as self care, I purposely try very hard to always do it to some degree. I know that if I stop that then I've given up everything. I can't always change the circumstances I'm going through that are causing my burn out. But I CAN always choose to take care of myself every day in at least a small way. Self care helps keep me on track, focused on positivity and feeling good about myself. Which in time will help motivate me to do bigger things. 
Self care is like a piece of drift wood I hold onto when I'm out in the ocean drowning in life's circumstances. It's not big, it won't get me out of the water. But it's a little something I can hold onto to at least keep my head a bit above water till my circumstances change and I can finally get out of the ocean

author: @EvelynHazel1
text:
I had these signs a couple years ago so I went to see a therapist. I had been with therapists before but they all said I just need to push through. And I kept thinking ok, but it keeps getting worse and worse. Finally I start ending up in the nurse a lot, finding myself out of class or skipping classes, or something to avoid school. And people kept telling me to push through and my anxiety will relieve with time. And I find a therapist at one point and she understands me and she helpes me. And she diagnoses me with A.D.D. And when I was with the school therapist she never helped me she always said ‚Äúyour have responsibilities and you need to fulfill them. School is a priority‚Äù and I swear I have always thought society thinks school and education and work is more important than your health‚Ä¶ and when I told the school therapist, at this point my mind felt overwhelmed with emotion and I just wanted to end my life but the school therapist said this over my health ‚ÄúA.D.D. Isn‚Äôt real and that doesn‚Äôt mean you can keep avoiding classes‚Äù


‚Ä¶

I have a condition. That‚Äôs an excuse. And that was my burnout point.



Now I‚Äôm doing better. Ive been on medication to help with my A.D.D. Stoped skipping classes. And protested against that school therapist for running my life. 


























But now that I think about it‚Ä¶ my burnout point was the moment I started to get anxiety and skipping classes and such. Because people weren‚Äôt listening to me.




























:)

author: @skybug1706
text: it's hard to know how to get out of this kind of rut. You can rest for a while but eventually you need to start hauling yourself through the behaviors and building habits and patterns again, right? Like, you can't wait forever to feel "ready" to get your life together again, and you have to force yourself manually to go through those motions of self discipline, exercise, duties. I find this very hard and I keep falling off the horse with small successes in between. Hopefully with time and commitment it gets easier, but I do worry I'm doing it wrong and just burning myself out more. But what else can you do yknow?

Self care out the window exercise diet sleep,

author: @Misspellednumbers
text:
Yeah... it's already hit bad for me. I felt so burnt out over the last three years, and it all came to ahead this half year. All I did was play one game, go to sleep, and wake up to do the same. My hobbies were nonexistent, my major was nonexistent,  and my classes plummeted. No matter how much I wanted to keep up with life, time sort of flew past me and now I'm paying the consequences. 
I wish I could've taken a break from school, but since I rely on my parents, a "break" would've been work or an alternative choice of school. 
In the end, part of my feels grateful for letting things fall apart. Although I felt stuck, I felt like I could breathe. Then again, I know future me will have to deal with the consequences of it. So I don't want to regret this. It honestly felt like my only way out.

I get distracted easily by social media and find my self scroll the days away. I also feel like I can‚Äôt have a normal conversation with anyone because I feel like I‚Äôm weird and I also have signs of social anxiety. I feel guilty about it because my family doesn‚Äôt expect all of this from me and I  don‚Äôt want it to seem like I want attention. I feel disconnected by family too. At home I am this silly goofy person but I don‚Äôt want my family seeing this side of me. To make matters worse I am horrible at math and I have this huge test which has consequences if I fail. My teacher even told us that barely anyone failed that test so now I want to pass that test because I don‚Äôt want people thinking I‚Äôm dumb and I don‚Äôt want to retake that whole class. I literally flunk almost all the test my teacher gives me. And I‚Äôve procrastinated in making an effort to go seek help. There‚Äôs never a time where I don‚Äôt feel anxious. I just want to know what‚Äôs wrong with me.

author: @pokeliv345
text:
Hi Julie,
My name is Olivia and I‚Äôm 13 years old.
Last summer I was diagnosed with depression anxiety and panic disorder.
This video I can definitely relate to because I noticed that I go through all the things in the video but for me the worst one is sleep.
I would go to see a therapist but I‚Äôm too scared to ask my parents as I‚Äôm afraid of them but there are people who I trust, but I can‚Äôt contact them because my parents took my phone away from me. I ha e also been self harming and I‚Äôve had suicidal thoughts they keep coming and going. It‚Äôs getting really annoying and stressful but I just get on with it. I do have a couple of video ideas which are more mindfulness because it really helps me before bed and in the morning and the other one is how to get over your fear because my fear is a balloon and I can‚Äôt go near them or look at a picture of them. I have also brought your book and I‚Äôm on chapter 6 and I‚Äôm in love with it. It‚Äôs really detailed and you have put so much effort in it. I wish I could meet you one day but I don‚Äôt think we can. Thank you for all you do, keep up the good work.
Stay safe and sending love and positive vibes to you. Xx üòò

author: @j.rosadahlia3960
text: Sy milenial, dan sering saya lihat orang yg mengeluhkan Gen Z lupa bahwa yang membesarkan Gen Z adalah orangtuanya dulu yg seperti Wanda Ponika: workaholic, kerja keras, hidupnya gak pernah balance, anak2 dikasih sama nanny/pengasuh, ngajarin anak2 dikasih sama guru les, kadang dibawa ke kantor krn gak ada yg jaga, dsb. Itu hasilnya jadi Gen Z. Begitu gen Z ini udah masuk work force, para orangtua itu juga yg mengeluhkan sifat mereka. Kadang orang2 gak ngaca saat mengeluhkan generasi di bawahnya. Orang2 seperti Wanda Ponika juga suka lupa: di jaman sekarang kritikan terhadap generasi bisa bergaung di media sosial dan efeknya lebih mengerikan dibanding generasi dulu, ketika seorang influencer ngeluh tentang gen Z, dengan mudahnya banyak orang lain ikutan mengkritik gen z. Faktanya setiap generasi punya oknum-oknum pemalas, bedanya kritikan dulu cuman mulut ke mulut, sekarang media ke media.

author: @mainbarenganici
text:
nb: gw gen milenial..
menit ke 14an : Kurang setuju dengan masalah jam kerja yg untuk bersaing harus ready 24 jam, beda cerita kalau freelance/serabutan memang harus ready terus.. kalau sudah office hour 9-5 trus diluar jam kerja dituntut untuk standby terus juga ga setuju, itu perusahaannya sudah ngga sehat !! Kalau mau dikontak diluar jam kerja ya boleh, tapi jangan berharap fast respon aja.. 

Ngga usah bilang me time, healing, dll.. Bilang aja family time, terkadang kita diluar jam kerja ga bisa dikontak, ya karena mungkin kita lagi mengembangkan diri dengan baca buku, main game, bersosialisasi dengan teman diluar kantor, bisa aja lagi family time dengan suami/istri/anak/mertua, dan masih banyak lagi..

Jadi buat perusahaan klo mau 9-5 ya diluar jam kerja ga usah nuntut aneh2, kecuali ga usah 9-5 sekalian, dijadiin WFH, itu lebih bisa menurutku.

author: @yvonnev0n
text:
Ga semua gen Z, tapi setelah berhubungan dg beberapa orang gen Z (baik di lingkup kerja maupun di lingkup belajar), memang rata2 mereka susah diajak komunikasi. Cuma dikasih tau, ga pake ngegas, ga ada nada menghakimi, eh masih aja di mindset mereka yg nasehati tuh MARAHIN. Tp kalo yg ngasih tau sesuai dg cara yg mereka mau, mereka terkesan ngeremehin (diiyain, tp ga dilakuin). Udah dikasih tau sebelumnya, eh bilangnya ga ada info. Jelas2 salah dan banyak saksinya, eh tetep aja denial.
Gen Z yg punya integritas tinggi lumayan susah dicari.

author: @velmafenita2011
text: Saya millenial disini, dulu mikir gen Z manja bener, saya anggap kerja grinding pagi sampe malem wajar, idup saya buat prusahaan, once kena pandemi perusahaan mikirin saya enggak. Di lay off gitu aja. Tau gitu dulu mindset saya kayak gen Z aja gak usah grinding sampe setres dan mending dari awal itung2an sama perusahaan jadi gak sakit ati kalo ada apa2 misal kayak lay off. Terus puji Tuhan saya ada kesempatan pindah negara, after pandemi, mana ada saya kerja kantoran sekarang harus grinding pagi malam lagi, work life balance dijamin. Rekan kerja saya gen Z dan milenial semua punya kinerja bagus, gak ada nuntut2 selama work life balance mereka dijamin. Perusahaaan dan karyawan fair, gak ada lembur gak dibayar, gak ada lembur sampe weekend digangguin via whatsapp. Saya rasa yang salah bukan gen Z banyak nuntut, yang salah, upah kerja di Indonesia kecil dan demand kerja tinggi gak masuk akal, budaya lembur dan grinding pagi malam dibiasakan, itu yang harus diubah.

author: @presylial
text: Terima kasih, sangat memberkati dan menguatkan. Bbrp relate untuk saya yg generasi X ini dimana harus berhadapan dengan generasi dibawah saya, bagaimana hrs bisa mencoba memahami tipe mereka tapi sekaligus hrs bisa mencoba mengajarkan hal yg baik (entah diterima atau diabaikan itu pilihan). author: @i.ak.1684
text: Can someone help me understand better? - The whole breathing technique thing.. To me, vigor is flow rate and length is obviously length as a function of time sooooo, if you want to (for example) "exhale longer and or with more vigor than you inhale", you are leaving with a net negative of air, right? haha. When I try doing this myself, I feel like it's an equation; I'm either exhaling long and inhaling quicker, but with more vigor to compensate or .. holding my breath? .. does the average tightness of the diaphragm across time have  higher coefficient towards the stress release than vigor of its movement? It would have to be so, right? so if i am trying to reduce stress, i'd breath out and hold my breath a little afterwards, right?

author: @MysteryChildOfficial
text:
21:00 - Eye dilation.  For anyone who wants to do this here are the steps:

In a stressful moment(cold shower, running, biking, whatever you choose to do), pause and soften your eyes.

Without moving your head, notice objects in your peripheral vision ‚Äî left, right, above, and below.

Keep breathing normally.

Within 30‚Äì60 seconds, many people notice heart rate and tension drop.
