author: @ether4211
text: So the cause of 'burnout' is called psycosocial hazards in Australia and should be addressed as part of occupational health and saftey. The very first individual 'treatment' is to see it as a workplace problem not a 'you' problem!! Because if your burnt out odds are your co-workers are suffering too, so reach out to your peers and support one another to get help! Your industry/job should have a 'occupational health and saftey rep' or first aid officer you can talk to about the problems, and can provide support and help to fixing them. If you don't have this check online to find out what laws apply in your country/state and reach out to a union (or form a group at work or with peers to help support you and fight for change). It is total nonsense to expect a person with burnout to 'go it alone' in quitting work or fighting a unsafe workplace, instead reach out, talk about your problems and make friends - because you are not alone, and together it's much easier to fight back or get treatment when you know your legal rights, have people to support you and use workers compensation or laws to 'fix' the problems.

author: @sgringo
text:
As a former software engineer, the notion of "emotional burnout" resonates strongly with me. I experienced it in the final job of my career. (I retired early because of it.)

If you've ever experienced sleep paralysis, that's what burnout felt like to me. When I would sit down at my computer to start working, my arms felt paralyzed; it took all of my will to lift my hands to the keyboard to start working.

That was five years ago. Even today, the thought of putting together a resume and starting the interview process for another engineering job feels daunting and stress-inducing. Even worse, the experience was systemic; it left me unmotivated and apathetic toward all aspects of my life. It's a malaise that persists to this day.

Prior to my last job, I always felt considerable passion for my work. This was such an unfortunate, unexpected end to my career.

author: @chetsims5793
text: As all the comments seem to already observe, these silly concepts like "burnout" (ok, not silly per se, but usually in how it is presented) only serve to normalize American business and capitalisms artificial enforcement of scarcity. I recommend David Graeber's talk on here about "bullshit jobs", in which he discusses how feasible a 15 hour work week is (very), and the social consequences of artificially employing people doing nothing but killing time. These videos kill me. We cannot separate social science from mental health any longer. Yes, social workers etc are crucial in times where we need not revolution, but a simple support mechanism to get back on our feet. But this is no world to stand in, because you stand only to take more blows, and doing so repeatedly constitutes for us our self hatred, not some need for a damn vacation. Herbert Marcuse called his concept of revolt "the great refusal," which I think explains itself pretty nicely; and we can refuse modernity's sick socio-logic by criticizing videos like this one for normalizing abusive regimes and economic structures. S/o all my sane homies in the comments feeling the same.

author: @saltykat3533
text:
I suffered clinical burnout, severe clinical depression and diagnosable adrenal fatigue from my job.   Brought on by a toxic boss, working in a pressure cooker, and a hostile work environment.   Coupled with a personal loss, and a work injury that resulted in severe chronic pain, that I had to learn how to absorb/sit in the pain because nothing worked to relieve it.  
I ended up struggling for another year, concentrated on eliminating my monthly outflow of cash (bills), paid off credit cards and cancelled them.  And saved as much as I could.   
I was able to quit work for two months and then found a part time job.   I would ride my motorcycle almost daily.  Sleep as long as I wanted and just sit in my hammock and watch the birds for hours.  It was bare bones living but I somewhat healed my body, mind and soul.   That was 3 years ago.  I still struggle when I feel the least bit stressed.   It is a long road to recovery, of which I really don't know if I will ever completely recover from.  
I now try to live the most peaceful, calm, drama-free life I can.  I have walked away from people and jobs to maintain my peace and contentment.  Your mental health, people is one of your most precious resources.

author: @fuzzmeister
text: Excellent piece of content. I think it would be very useful if Human Resource Departments had concrete education and official frameworks (ie via recognised standards/certifications) to help them identify the symptoms of burnout,  so they can then work with psychologists to help workers suffering from this condition. It should be part of ESG reform. Your comment on the sabbatical to re-align oneself resonates :). Thankyou for this piece. Mental health management of the workforce is probably ''underweight'' in most boardroom agendas, yet it is so critical to long term performance of staff - arguably helping to reduce un-necessary ''churn' and is arguably a pre-requisite for creating a healthy work atmosphere which ultimately makes the workplace a more happy and productive environment., When humans are committed, they can create the magic via 'healthy and happy'' hard work that takes businesses to the next level. My suspicion is that many just quit, get fired or just get pushed aside when all they needed was correct diagnosis then treatment of sorts.  Human Resource departments and psychologists maybe need closer ''mandatory'' ties.

author: @gdshoe5822
text:
Why do you assume everyone gets angry when they burn out?  That seems really narrow minded.
People respond to stress differently.  Anger is one unhealthy symptom of emotional strain, but it's hardly the only common human response.  
In my own experience: I can either choose to care and become angry, or I can choose not to, and become detached.  Neither is healthy.  My personal inclination is toward detachment.  Does this mean that I don't experience burn out because I'm not constantly primed to explode?

author: @Nylak-Otter
text:
Oh, yeah.  About 8 years ago I hit burnout in my profession, which is extremely emotionally demanding every day along with being physically demanding.  I hated my life, I hated my hopes and dreams, I hated everything I had ever loved.  I was acutely suicidal and finally ended up in the hospital with acute alcoholic hepatitis at 25 years old with 2 days to live.

So that got me off work for about 5 years, since I couldn't exist outside the hospital for a few days until about a year after finally receiving a liver transplant.  And boy howdy, try living with survivor's guilt after some specialists fought tooth and nail for you, even though you were a staggering, suicidal alcoholic.  "But she's so young and works in an extremely valuable field!  We need to care for the caretakers!  She's intelligent and highly motivated, so she has a low chance of recidivism!  We can use her as a headlining example for our new study with alcoholics and longterm recovery!  Guilt guilt guilt!!"

I'm back to it, and the burnout came back within 6 months this time.  I don't lnow what to do.  I wish I hadn't survived.  But now I have a transplant that they didn't need to give me, and I need to do what I'm on this stupid rock to do, but it's impossible to make any lasting change.  I feel like I'm trying to empty the ocean with a thimble.

And, unfortunately, this burnout isn't just with my job; my job is *ME.*  It's all I am, and all I've wanted to do since I was about 5 years old.  I hate being me.

And now I can't even chug a liter or two of vodka to help me sleep at night, because I'm skullfuckingly sober forever now.

Lucky if you can ensure you're still eating regularly, maintaining personal hygiene and can think straight for longer than 10mins at a time. From the title I thought this video would have "clinical" solutions. But it's yet another content piece diminishing a serious condition. Not helpful - employers will watch a video like this and think burnout is a fancy word for "tired".

author: @pjotrtje0NL
text:
FYI: scientifically speaking, there is no such thing as a clinical burnout. Or a burnout for that matter. What ppl call a burnout is actually just severe stress that should be addressed as stress, with origins in both work and private related issues. Since the origin is so complicated, the path out of it is never straightforward and of a prescribed length.
There are *feelings* of burnout, but those we all feel, once in a while. But usually those go away, when a project with tight and ‚Äòimpossible‚Äô deadlines has ended, or after a series of exams has concluded. In that case, there is no reason to seek professional help.

author: @pamelatify
text:
So, my extreme emotional exhaustion, my new found anger and resentment towards my boss of decades, my new onset of defensiveness and that feeling that I should quit my long career to work at Walmart to rescue my sanity ‚Äî it‚Äôs burnout? And I need to take a sabbatical and/or play guitar hero? 

Nah. What I did instead is tell my boss he has overloaded me by quadrupling my workload over the years without providing resources. When he didn‚Äôt fix the problem after years, I just quit doing the extra work. I warned him something bad would happen if he kept this up, and then it did. Now that he has seen the absence of my efforts, as he watches his personal empire crumble, he finally believes me and has a newfound respect for my well-being. Well, he acts like he does. He is hiring additional staff to support me. Somehow the respect and recognition is curative. I‚Äôm still on the middle of the burnout symptoms, the stress, the exhaustion, and the overload. But setting new boundaries is working. Now if I want to run away to Walmart, I can.  Can you imagine a 30 year career in business and asset management and all I can think of is how happy I would be making zero decisions behind the check out counter at Walmart! üòÇ

author: @ilfordino-fordfiestatutori8725
text:
So it turns out that I experienced burn out syndrome last year. I was mobbed in my previous job and I decided to move to another workplace closer to my home, hoping that things would finally get better. God I was wrong. I was feeling exausted and I thought all I needes was a vacation so I went to Prague with some friend and had good time. A week later I started the new job buy something was off: I was feeling out of context with no purpose, asking myself "what the hell am I doing here? These guys are way better than me!" and all this kind of stuff. The context in the office wasn't relaxed at all with that underlying sense of tension between collegues and the manager. So I started to get anxious and feel like I had fever, I was very hot all the time and sweating. I hated the job. It went for a couple of months until I lost the job for low productivity. And THANK GOD! When they told me It was my last day I felt like a massive burden on my shoulders was finally gone. I was HAPPY!
I then took for rent a house in the mountains for a month with some friends and I think I'm better now. I get the chance to study and hopefully I'll get to chase my passion: cars.

author: @Clint945
text:
As a fellow academic, i find it really very insulting that she said "oh i just took a sabbatical to fix my issues". Most people can't do that, and suggestions like that are utterly pointless. The burnout stems *from* an inability to stop working, an inability to control your circumstances, little to no reward for your work, and the apathy that comes with those things.

This speaker is a professor, head of department (i.e. has been heavily rewarded for their work), and was able to take a sabbatical (i.e. has complete control of their workflow) and they have the audacity to pretend that this is any sort of solution for the vast majority of people?

Further, while she does - very briefly - talk about organisations needing to change their approach to work, she spends most of her time talking about how *you* need to change *your* approach to work. Cause clearly, its the worker that's mostly at fault here. *You* haven't managed *your* workload effectively, *you* haven't taken time for *your* hobbies and interests, *you* identify too strongly with *your* work. Shifting blame and responsibility onto the worker and not the employer or the structural systems behind the work...

Horrible attitude. Even worse that its held by a researcher in the field.

author: @trstefani
text: I‚Äôve been practicing medicine in both private practice and the government for 20 years.  More significantly, I‚Äôve practiced in primary care all that time.  Life is a marathon, not a sprint.  Many physicians come out of residency with a full time or 1.0 FTE.  Within a year the majority reduce their FTE.  Those that stay full time and stay until retirement set limits and work toward balance.  Get enough sleep, exercise, take vacation time, eat a balanced diet, and limit or avoid alcohol.  Prioritizing family, friends, hobbies, and spiritual health are all vital.  Stay true to your values and morals.  Don‚Äôt waiver.  Realize that the exam room is there for the patient.  You need to be tolerant of diversity but you don‚Äôt need to accept or assimilate others values as your own.  Separate the person from their behavior.  You can dislike the drug seeker, borderline, pedophile, or emotionally draining person; but don‚Äôt hate the person.  A sense of humor helps.  Personally, I‚Äôve shunned social media.  Stay clear of politics.

author: @DanielWahlig
text: As someone born in the US, but living the last 4 years in the Netherlands - it's very interesting to see how differently the subject of burnout is addressed in each country.  In the US, the best burnout treatment most people can hope for is a compassionate boss that will help prioritize your mental health by making small, temporary adjustments to your workload.  In the Netherlands, you're able to take up to two years off with a government mandated 70% minimum of your pay to allow you to focus on your mental health and truly treat your symptoms.  And many companies will even add additional pay up to 100% of your salary.  And yes, we do pay high taxes for the privilege of prioritizing mental health, other healthcare, transportation, education, etc - but in my mind - it's absolutely worth every penny to know that if and when I need help, I'm able to seek it - regardless of pre-existing conditions or financial pressures. Not trying to push this structure on anyone else, just some food for thought for those that might share a similar vision for a balanced and secure human existence.

author: @desiv1170
text:
I think the second one can be tricky...  The "it feels like if there's one more request, you're just gonna lose it and freak out."
Because while I sometimes feel like if there's one more request, I don't know what I can do...  I know I won't "lose it and freak out" because that's not what I do...  Ever...  It's not in my personality type to do that...  I help.  I fix things.  I help other people.  I don't lose it and freak out...  That's not an option...
Maybe I'll shut down?  Maybe I'll quit?  Maybe I'll get sick, tho I hate that because the last thing I need is time away from work where things keep piling up while I'm not there....  
Not sure...  But probably more likely I'll just try to do whatever is needed/expected and keep those feelings internal...  Thinking that at some point in the future, maybe something will get better...
Even tho it hasn't in three years...  And I know that...
And when someone asks me how things are going, I'll say "It's crazy....   But we'll get there..."  Because I can't just say the first part...

author: @MomoSimone22
text: This was a great video, but I dislike how burnout is always discussed specifically in work contexts. I burned out earlier this year when completing my PhD, but had also started a Masters at the same time, and was working as well to earn an income. I didn't have the physical or emotional energy to take care of myself and I didn't have the option to take breaks. I would love for more information about how long it can take to recover from burnout and different ways recovering can look. I've been on break now for the past three weeks and it's the first break I've had in four years. I don't want to do a single thing, but feel guilty for not being more productive. So, this is why I'd love for someone to discuss burnout from a perspective other than work burnout, because the advice is often very workplace specific (e.g., make changes in the workplace, etc).

author: @TriAngles3D
text:
Here, where you are now, turns out to be something else than you had expected. And, not for the better...

Go back to the beginning. Ask yourself what was that that first inspired you. What gave you the energy to do what you do best. Go back to that. Rediscover that.

 In my view the biggest mistake you can make is going past your boundaries. Gradually at first and then systematically. Your mind is warning you. But you are not listening. 

Mind and body decouple. Without a sense of intrinsic boundaries you have lost a sense of yourself. You are lost. Everything else becomes too much.

You know what you feel you just don't now why you feel the way you do anymore. You can't pint point it. And, that only amplifies the ill condition.

Counseling, coaching, therapy? Yeah, that helps some. But not all. Short-term solution. A more sustainable solution is re-programming yourself.

The mind is probability calculation machine. You need to re-learn that what you do has high probability of a positive return. 

Find what first inspired you. Start very simple. Do it over and over again and build on that until your mind re-learns that you have a positive effect on yourself and environment.

In my case I fixed a cabinet door and ended up renovating my house. At each iteration my mind gets to take in a tangible result of my efforts. A positive and constructive feedback.  

Mind and body re-align. 

Very good information. Being able to clarify or otherwise validate what you are experiencing is the first step towards gaining some sense of relief and formulating a plan to recovery.

author: @jimwilliams3816
text:
I would have liked a last piece about recovering from established long term burnout. This is the hardest, because the preventative measures probably still apply, but they take on the quality of more things you ‚Äúare supposed to be doing‚Äù ‚Äî more demands. My one criticism of the piece is that I think limiting burnout to work factors creates an incomplete picture. Personal demands can definitely play a role. Single moms is probably the most often cited, though in my case an elderly parent was the biggest factor.

The reason I got served this clip is that long term burnout is a big topic at the moment on the neurodivergent channels, ADHD and autism. Neurodivergence adds some tricky variables; it certainly can make you more vulnerable to burnout, and certain neurodivergent traits strongly resemble the symptoms of burnout, which makes untangling what is a result of what that much harder. Not least because some of the traits that resemble burnout may in fact come from experiencing the causes of burnout throughout all areas of a neurodivergent person‚Äôs life. These days, this type of ongoing stress is often misattributed as trauma, and I appreciate that this piece talks about stress as a root. I do feel a need to clarify one last thing about that, however: burnout as an outcome is distinguishable from stress, but it flows from persistent stress. If you are trying to preempt burnout, it‚Äôs very important not to fall into looking at your situation and going ‚Äúit‚Äôs just stress.‚Äù There‚Äôs nothing ‚Äújust‚Äù about stress. No one can live a stress free life, just as no one can avoid being exposed to any carcinogens. But too much of either too constantly is likely to lead to health problems, and in the case of stress, those problems are often mental health related. Alas, the concerns often get applied only to whether you have a heart attack or a stroke. But many of us can tell you that breakdowns can be debilitating too. Persistent stress does damage to all systems, especially the prefrontal cortex. It is long past time for business and society to stop pretending that ‚Äúwhat does not kill us makes us stronger.‚Äù

author: @WildflowerAnn
text:
As an ICU RN, we are all well aware of burn out, or Moral Injury as it‚Äôs been rebranded by some who get it. 
It was interesting that most of the docs never understood, nor did they care, until they got thrown under the bus too during COVID. Not until then did anyone really take notice. 
Don‚Äôt we all wish we could take a sabbatical. As a single Mom and now a single empty nester, I have to pay my own way. No one is doing it for me.
Think of the millions of Americans who make far less money than even me. That‚Äôs truly living a pipe dream. 
You just keep getting up every day and keep on doing it. Pull up your big girl panties, tough it up and carry on.
Hopefully you come through it okay at the end.

author: @bens5859
text:
A separate but related condition is called "bore-out." Unlike "burnout," it is not caused by overworking or work-life imbalance, but rather under stimulation & lack of purpose despite a manageable workload.

I'm not sure how controversial this concept is among experts, but I suppose it is a better descriptor for my own situation than "burnout" is.

author: @annegregory3613
text: This sounds a lot like the consequences of oppression and helplessness which I think more and more people are feeling these days due the current state of things in the US and the world. The shrinking middle class, concentration of wealth, inflation, massive corporations, the manipulation of the everyday consumer by using human psychology against them, climate change, political turmoil, pervasive corruption in leadership, Russia vs. Ukraine, the fact that the Doomsday Clock is closer than it's ever been to midnight....In short it doesn't feel like the hits are going to stop coming anytime soon. If you can take a sabbatical that's great. Most can't. I think if anything the best mode of thinking for times like these is stoicism and also mental toughness.  Unfortunately, the past few generations including my own have not been conditioned for mental toughness. We can't do a ton right away about the state of the world, but we can harden ourselves a bit so that we do not feel as helpless and are more effective in rough times. Accept the things you cannot change, take a breath, then get to work on the things you can. Now is not the time to be idle even though everything feels so heavy. Keep moving.

author: @mustafagunes5740

Stress is the a measure of what the material feels from externally applied forces. It is simply a ratio of the external forces to the cross sectional area of the material.

This is the definition of stress in engineering or scientifically.

So lots of stress burns people out. If anyone thinks they are going to pull themselves away from this should immediately wake up to reality. Because industrial era evolved to the point we are in now. We simply became a part of the social machine.

And the most of the billionaires are anthropologist for a reason. They study this for a reason.

You are just another gear in their wealth machine and replaceable as soon as burned out.

So treat your colleagues kindly. You need each other to reduce stress. It's not your boss or job stressing. You become external forces to the cross sectional area for each other.

We should realize and beware of the situation. Because we are all in this now.

author: @nancyneyedly4587
text: We need to change the language here describing burnout.  Constatnly referring to "job" or "work" negates those who are suffereing form burnout due to life circumstances.  So yes an unpaid "job" like caring for sick loved ones is a "job" nonethelss it isn't a choice.  That lack of choice in your direction adds another dimension to burnout.  So while people can comit to a career that leads them to burnout, others have to work at a "job" and have demands beyond the norm outside of working, like caring for sick or special needs people in their lives and that is a whole other level of burnout.  The reference to unfairness in the video touches on an important point, often the lack of control and with no reward is draining.

author: @nikmanousos8460
text: Yes

author: @nogf42069
text: What an eye opener. I started a new job 9 months ago 'cause my old company downsized and I needed to make rent and since then my mental (and even physical) health went downhill real fast. This new job doesn't let me do what I do best, I provide almost no value, and I'm even doing something that I wasn't hired for. Some days there's literally zero work to do but I still feel the pressure to do something. Most people would say "oh cool you get paid for doing nothing" but the kind of stress and emotional drain coming from feeling useless and doing things wrong just because the company works a certain way it's eating me up from the inside. I've been sleeping either 2 hours or 12, snapping at friends and family and just generally dreading going into work at 9.

author: @josequezada519
text: üëéI have no degree or neither am I doctor of any kind. But in my opinion I don't agree with these definitions. When I talk to others about burnout which I've gotten quite a bit (ask anyone in design or marketing) they usually talk about the exhaustion of not being able to care of yourself. For example, working on a project for so long that you haven't showered, haven't had time to do any hobbies, and missed family events and on Monday you still gotta go in and get more stuff on your plate. That's burntout there's  no other emotions other than anger, you're just angry you gotta work this hard to keep your job and make someone richer than you. That's the state I've found plenty of people in...I do agree with the rewards part, it adds to it. These signs/definitions sound more like depression then burnout..again burnout is the point where you can't sleep properly because your job/responsibilities are hunting you = you can't take care of yourself. I'm sorry but I just can't agree with these signs,  I know she talks about stress and burnout being different but I they've evolved in today's era. I'll try to look at the studies but to me these don't make sense.

author: @351cleavland
text:
There is obviously a lot of frustration and anger surrounding this issue about work/life/emotions culture in modern day times. 
Yes, its profoundly screwed up. 

Some of her suggestions are not going to apply for some people in attending to their needs. There is no "cure" but there are things to consider to help tip the scale in the other direction.

1) Add one item a day to your diet that is Nourishing to your body. If something unhealthy gives you pleasure keep it but add in the nourishment.
2) Move your body for 10 minutes to get circulation going when NOT working.
3) Monitor your self-talk. If I think, in a moment of quiet, that I am such a failure I say in my "STOP!"
I then have trained myself to say "I am not a failure because I did not accomplish this one thing. I have accomplished a lot."

care for yourself with intention to be caring.
Are you worth it?
Yes.

The moment you raise concern on the same, you are seen as incompetent in handling everyday work. author: @lafandenuel5605
text: great resignation is fantastic response to be on that "verge of burnout" in my opinion. If you don't feel valued and appreciated, before you lose your own sense of value and let yourself be wounded, just runaway. You'll find someplace else, they'll find someone else. Nobody can be asked to sacrifice themselves or their health for a project. Because without your health you can't work and you'll have no income to put a roof over your head or food on your plate.

author: @highland42
text: I don't doubt her expertise on the subject however it was confusing when she would say "Burnout is not stress" but then describe a lot of symptoms and features of burnout that could just as easily be labeled stress. It would be helpful for me to hear the differences between the two such as "burnout is more long term" or "stress is more surface level". I had trouble understanding how the two weren't the same when they were being described in very similar ways.

author: @nobody983
text: I burned out, got laid off from work, employer made sure that I never got another job. Job search for more than 6 years itself created a chronic burnout which is beyond all definitions. It is a privilege to sit there and tell people what is the definition of burnout and what they should do. Let me add to their knowledge that there exists a next stage of burnout as well. It is when burnout persists for many years resulting in you becoming literally a dead person. You feed yourself the bare minimum, force yourself to only have the most basic life needs. You stop caring if you died the next moment, in-fact you develop such a wish. And funny thing is that it was done to me by such "academics" like herself.

author: @mnmlst1
text: Lol this is so disproportionally out of touch with reality. We are poor. We can't afford therapy and proper care. I'm from Latin America btw. Not even public Healthcare or public universities have good mental Healthcare programs that could help people. In my case I'm autistic and ADHD, and it's hard as fuck to find care for adults like me even if you have the money because everyone treats kids only. Most people are too busy to make ends meet, we can't afford to save our minds.

author: @M-3-L-O-N
text:
Meanwhile quit quitting is everywhere because nobody feels like their valued or is payed what their owed regardless of how much they give. Our success is most often than not, not in our hands. We rely on others to elevate us to where we wanna go, and today hard work is not rewarded. So we become pissed off, cynical, depressed, nihilistic. 

For me? Its pissed off, because ive always stood everyone up regardless of lvl of experience or qualification without feeling like its hard in every working environment ive been in, and yet im tired of petty, insignificunts who wont move asside because their ego or delusions cant handle it. So i distance myself from society because people make me tired, i dont deal with slackers or anyone who cant keep up. I think allot of young people are tired of old methods, traditions, amd our fates decided by the older generations who dumped their problems onto us and then have the audacity to call us weak. Like yeah its my fault i cant afford a house when you could at my age. Russia, Japan even South Africa, and more, the youth are subject to decisions made by their older peers that hinder our lives. Hence we are all so fked in the head these days.

Our entire species is burned out.

author: @robertdouglas8895
text:
This burnout happens when you think the world is against you, as she says you think people have bad intentions against you and that you will suffer because of that. As  individuals, we can feel incompetent.But we are not individuals. We are created in the likeness of God and have God protecting  us. When we separate ourselves from God, we think that He has bad intentions against us, too. The guilt piles up. The solution is to forgive everyone for what they are not doing to you. We are all masters of our fate and joining with God gives us the right way to proceed with compassion.
The root word of "sabbatical" is sabbath.  It's a time to reunite with God.
